I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Megan Hays, Director, Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team. Our fourth quarter earnings and corporate pr
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team. 
Our fourth quarter earnings and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements this morning
Also some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in those earnings release and corporate presentation. 
I understand it's a busy morning, so thank you, again, for taking the time to listen to our call. 
Now I'll turn it over to  Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks, again, for joining us on this busy morning. By now you've heard many metaphors describing the commodity price environment from choppy waters to rough terrain. The backdrop we find ourselves in is volatile and dynamic, but the Concho
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks, again, for joining us on this busy morning. By now you've heard many metaphors describing the commodity price environment from choppy waters to rough terrain. The backdrop we find ourselves in is volatile and dynamic, but the Concho team has experienced succeeding when prices are low. 
We're building the company that can thrive at any point in the cycle. We consolidate high quality properties in the Permian Basin and have an exceptional track record of profitably growing production, reserves and resorts. And while the past year has been challenging, we view the macro environment as an opportunity to extend our lead in the Permian and make our business stronger by focusing on how we can control and strategically consolidating acreage on our core areas. 
We believe this approach enables Concho to deliver on our near-term objectives, while providing our shareholders with a solid investment for long-term value creation. 
From both an operational and a financial perspective, Concho delivered exceptional results for 2015, demonstrating the quality of our team and assets. As oil price continue to its volatile and protracted decline, we reduced capital spending from an initial budget of $3 billion to $2 billion, and we expected annual production growth to be less than 20%. 
We ended up delivering more with less. Daily production volumes for 2015 increased 28%, with crude oil growing by 31%, while exploration and development capital totaled only $1.8 billion for the year. 
The results of our 2015 program highlight our improved capital efficiency, driven by lower service cost, shorter cycle times, long laterals and completion intensity. 
I'm proud of how well our operational teams performed given all the moving parts. Their focus drove better well performance across all our assets and resulted in per unit cost that were in line or below the low end of our guidance range. 
Proved reserves held steady despite the 50% decline in SEC prices used to calculate crude reserves. And we replaced 290% of production at a drillbit finding cost of $11.66 per barrel. We've been focused on the Permian for a long time. It's a resource rich basin and our teams generate more economic drilling opportunities on our assets each year. 
Over the past 2 years, our drilling program has unlocked more resource as we convert vertical drilling locations to horizontal locations, derisk multizone potential and successfully test denser well spacing. 
In total, the captured resource for the company increased by 35% during 2015 to 25 billion Boes, including proved reserves. And we've identified approximately 18,000 horizontal drilling locations. 
Approximately 30% of these locations are in 20% or greater rate of return at a flat $40 oil price. This is a function of moving down the cost curve, refining our drilling and completion techniques and improving well performance. 
Given our focus on in the best assets and development efforts, each of our core areas contributed to expanding our resource potential. In the Northern Delaware Basin, results from our drilling program, optimizing completion techniques and downspacing increased our inventory. 
They also made significant progress in the Southern Delaware Basin and in the Midland Basin. In both areas, field infrastructure improved our economics. And in the Southern Delaware, we derisking the play combined with acreage trades and acquisitions, expanded our long lateral drilling inventory, increased our confidence in the growth potential of this asset.
Our enthusiasm for the New Mexico Shelf has not Horizontal results through past expectations. These low-cost, shallow opportunities have some of the best economics in our portfolio. And while we have success defining and expanding our resource space, we're drilling at a slower space. 
We reduced our activity level over the course of 2015, such that our cash flow exceeded drilling and completion capital by approximately $225 million in the second half of the year. The capital activity aligned with the lower commodity price environment,  a premier asset base, a robust hedge position and a strong balance sheet, we're approaching 2016 with confidence that we can continue to take advantage of the current environment. 
And a strategy we've executed in the second half of '15 is what you're going to see from us in 2016 as low commodity prices continue to demand capital discipline and patience. 
We believe oil prices will ultimately move higher, but for now, we remain committed to a plan of balancing our entire capital spend, excluding potential acquisitions within estimated cash flow. 
This is a strategy that's been successful for Concho. They will maintain our financial strength and preserve our high-quality inventory through this down cycle. 
We've lowered our 2016 capital plan from a base budget of $1.4 billion to a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. The current capital plan for 2016 represents a 35% reduction compared to 2015. Our production outlook for 2016 is driven by timing and transitioning to forefeel development. The last 2 years we've grown production at a compound rate of 25% annually. 
In the second half of '15, we significantly reduced operating activity and will again reduce activity in 2016. 
Importantly, over the past 2 years, our drilling program successfully defined multizone potential broadly across our operating areas, resulting in substantial resource discovery. 
As we look to further increase the efficiency of our ongoing development program, a substantial portion of our 2016 program will utilize pad bad drilling and long lateral development. 
The combined effect of the exceptional growth over the past 2 years, followed by a slowdown in activity and transition to pad drilling have a more pronounced impact on -- in 2016, but we'll continue to demonstrate our ability to deliver capital efficient growth over the long term. 
Based on the current market outlook for commodity prices and continuing to spend within cash flow, we expect to deliver double-digit production growth in 2017. 
Let me say that again. Based on the current market outlook for commodity prices and continuing to spend within cash flow, we expect to deliver double-digit production growth in 2017. 
Importantly, our plan is flexible, and we're keeping both hands on the steering wheel as we navigate the volatility. 
We have a strong track record of delivering growth and by staying committed to a strong balance sheet and preserving our inventory rather than growing volumes and depleting our resource in a weak prize environment. 
We will be uniquely positioned to grow when conditions improve high-quality assets in the Permian is a key component of our strategy. 
Given the capital chase and acreage in the Permian, property values remained high, but our acquisition efforts in 2015 were disciplined, targeted and privately negotiated. 
We acquired interest in bolt-on acreage to our core areas. These acquisitions expanded our long lateral drilling inventory and enhanced the overall value of our portfolio. 
Our operational expertise in the Permian is a technical advantage when evaluating the acquisitions. We coupled this expertise with discipline. We're looking to consolidate the right assets at the right price at the right time. 
Our team evaluated a lot of opportunities and demonstrated their ability to move on the best deals with the most positive strategic impact. 
We have a deep inventory of drilling projects. At today's drilling pace and current environment, we have more than 2 decades of inventory that generate competitive rates of return and growth. 
The depth and quality of our inventory sets a high bar for future acquisitions. The opportunities we evaluate have to compete with the best projects in our portfolio. 
Our recently announced transactions achieved this objective. The acreage trade and asset acquisition  coupled with the asset sale in Loving County out drilling program, increased our exposure to the best part of the Southern Delaware Basin, while also strengthening our balance sheet. 
Having a strong balance sheet is a key component of our strategy, which continues to serve as well. Recently, our debt ratings were reaffirmed at both S&P and Moody's. I'm also proud to report that Concho is added to the S&P 500 last Friday. 
Concho's addition to the S&P 500 is a testament to the hard work and dedication of our team. Together, we've grown Concho into a leading ENP company, operating in one of the most prolific oil basins in the world. Despite the uncertain backdrop, our strategy and our team enabled Concho to thrive. 
We've demonstrated our ability to rapidly grow production. We have a great asset base and a great machine. Commodity price environment is uncertain, but we believe we can continue to build value through the cycle by keeping a strong balance sheet, prudently investing in the business and staying discipline in order to take advantage of unique opportunities. 
I appreciate your continued confidence in Concho. Now let me turn the call back over to the moderator, I'll look forward to your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question Tim. Last quarter, you mentioned that one of the least appreciated aspects of the acquisitions been making over the past year, so is the ability to execute longer laterals after consolidating acreage, and I know you've talked about sort of
componenttext: First question Tim. Last quarter, you mentioned that one of the least appreciated aspects of the acquisitions been making over the past year, so is the ability to execute longer laterals after consolidating acreage, and I know you've talked about sort of that roughly kind of 2x the oil for 1.5x the cost and sort of longest lines after the Southern Delaware acreage you picked up last month, if you could sort of give a ballpark estimate now and kind of what percentage of that Southern Delaware acreage position you can now do the longer laterals on?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a real blocky acreage there in the sweet spot of the Southern Delaware Basin. So almost all of that acreage down there, we will be drilling longer laterals.
componenttext: Yes, it's a real blocky acreage there in the sweet spot of the Southern Delaware Basin. So almost all of that acreage down there, we will be drilling longer laterals.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: And when I look at the pretty encouraging commentary, at least, preliminarily on the 2017 outlook, I was hoping to get a little bit color on the docs, I know you have docs at the end of the third quarter, maybe if where those stood at the end of '15 and sort of what your preliminary guiding to and where those stand at the end of '16, that's maybe allowing you to go into 2017 pretty strong?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me first describe  that as we ended the year -- last year, we landed our budget the number of uncompleted wells that we had rose modestly, but those as we execute our 2015 capital plan, we'll kind of be worked off in a normal basis down to while
componenttext: Yes, let me first describe  that as we ended the year -- last year, we landed our budget the number of uncompleted wells that we had rose modestly, but those as we execute our 2015 capital plan, we'll kind of be worked off in a normal basis down to while we've indicated in the past is what we'd like to carry as an inventory of uncompleted wells. And then as far as the rest of the timing of the year, one thing I want to make sure everybody understands is the impact of the slowdown in the second half of '15 and how that impacting, affects the overall production for 2016 and then going into '17, because we really are gaining capital efficiencies and have gained them through the last half of '15, and is really driving capital efficient process right now. We're not projecting any additional capital efficiencies going through '16 into '17, but based on the way conditions are today, you're going to see kind of the flattening of production throughout 2016, but then the base economics take over again, we start growing again in 2017 and beyond.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: John, this is Jack that. Just to your first question to on lateral length, we're going to be up about 40% on average over last year to somewhere over 7,000 feet on average per lateral. So that helps in that production profile as well.

componenttext: Thank you. I think the high-level strategic thought is that when you have a portfolio large as there is a constant of the opportunities within that portfolio and the transactions that our team was able to pull off where we bought, sold and traded and then could describe it to you all at the time, I think, highlights how we think about managing our properties. And I think the benefits of that high grading both from cost reductions, better economics, more efficient drilling, locked up acreage, focusing on the sweet spots in the Permian, I think really impact the efficiency of the company going forward and you to expect to see more of that kind of activity, that's not just a one time deal, that's going process.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then my follow-up, Concho historically and is very well hedged compared to peers, I noticed there was no change in the oil hedge percentage quarter-to-quarter, so what are your thoughts on hedging in here even though prices low, but then yo
componenttext: Excellent. And then my follow-up, Concho historically and is very well hedged compared to peers, I noticed there was no change in the oil hedge percentage quarter-to-quarter, so what are your thoughts on hedging in here even though prices low, but then you try to balance that against your typical desire to go ahead and try to get a certain percentage hedged as you look out over the 4, 12 months?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've followed us long enough to know that we tend to think of the hedging program more as a dollar cost averaging than we do on oil prices as a major theme for us. I'll tell you also that we limit our hedging to our PDP decline curve going forward, that
componenttext: You've followed us long enough to know that we tend to think of the hedging program more as a dollar cost averaging than we do on oil prices as a major theme for us. I'll tell you also that we limit our hedging to our PDP decline curve going forward, that curve has been flattening, but also as our drilling activity slows down, the level of oil that you need to hedge going forward is less, so you don't see as much hedging activity. Also, I would tell you that our hedging philosophy leaves a little room and therefore, our discretion to kind of interpret the market conditions and we've exercised some of that discretion in the recent past.

componenttext: Yes, we're talking about the and I would tell you I want to add that color because I didn't want 2016 to be misinterpreted. componenttext: Well, I think that the cost declines we've seen up to this point, the scenario we're talking about going forward for oils at the strip, I think all those cost declines you maintain those throughout  that business cycle. And so I think the cost efficiency that we've achieved, and I expect it to get better. I think there are still ways that we can improve our cost structure. What was the other question?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do think that in the service sector, there is a large amount of destruction of capacity from smaller companies and smaller operators. And I think that scale is going to be important and that's why I think that we have an advantage by running one of
componenttext: Yes, I do think that in the service sector, there is a large amount of destruction of capacity from smaller companies and smaller operators. And I think that scale is going to be important and that's why I think that we have an advantage by running one of the larger programs, and so I think the services will be there for the companies that have been there through the cycle.

Gas differentials got into a little bit wider in 2016, can you just speak to that, and then maybe a little bit broader here on sort of the capital outlay that you have for the Alpha Crude Connector and other infrastructure items, just remind me of how that trends and how that changes 2015, 2016, and 2017 and beyond?

componenttext: Yes, sure. On the gas differentials really tied to NGL pricing. So improvement there would lead to better gas price realization. componenttext: Let me take a stab at that one, because I to think base decline is a factor. And I wouldn't -- I want to say there is not a major factor. There is a combination of a bunch of things. Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. Q4 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Megan Hays, Director, Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO, and members of the Concho senior management team.Our fourth quarter earnings release and corpo
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO, and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our fourth quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in both the earnings release and corporate presentation.
I understand it's a busy morning, so thank you, again, for taking the time to listen to our call.
Now I'll turn it over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks, again, for joining us on this busy morning. By now you've heard many metaphors describing the commodity price environment from choppy waters to rough terrain. The backdrop we find ourselves in is volatile and dynamic, but the Concho
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks, again, for joining us on this busy morning. By now you've heard many metaphors describing the commodity price environment from choppy waters to rough terrain. The backdrop we find ourselves in is volatile and dynamic, but the Concho team has experience succeeding when prices are low.
We're building a company that can thrive at any point in the cycle. We consolidate high-quality properties in the Permian Basin and have an exceptional track record of profitably growing production, reserves and resource. And while the past year has been challenging, we view the macro environment as an opportunity to extend our lead in the Permian and make our business stronger by focusing on what we can control and strategically consolidating acreage in our core areas. We believe this approach enables Concho to deliver on our near-term objectives, while providing our shareholders with a solid investment for long-term value creation.
From both an operational and a financial perspective, Concho delivered exceptional results for 2015, demonstrating the quality of our team and assets. As the oil price continued its volatile and protracted decline, we reduced capital spending from an initial budget of $3 billion to $2 billion, and we expected annual production growth to be less than 20%. We ended up delivering more with less. Daily production volumes for 2015 increased 28%, with crude oil growing by 31%, while exploration and development capital totaled only $1.8 billion for the year.
The results of our 2015 program highlight our improved capital efficiency, driven by lower service cost, shorter cycle times, long laterals and completion intensity.
I'm proud of how well our operational teams performed given all the moving parts. Their focus drove better well performance across all our assets and resulted in per unit cost that were in line or below the low end of our guidance range.
Proved reserves held steady despite the 50% decline in SEC prices used to calculate proved reserves. And we replaced 290% of production at a drill bit finding cost of $11.66 per barrel. We've been focused on the Permian for a long time. It's a resource-rich basin and our teams generate more economic drilling opportunities on our assets each year.
Over the past 2 years, our drilling program has unlocked more resource as we convert vertical drilling locations to horizontal locations, derisk multizone potential and successfully test denser well spacing.
In total, the captured resource for the company increased by 35% during 2015 to 5 billion Boes, including proved reserves. And we've identified approximately 18,000 horizontal drilling locations. Approximately 30% of these locations earn a 20% or greater rate of return at a flat $40 oil price. This is a function of moving down the cost curve, refining our drilling and completion techniques and improving well performance.
Given our focus on acquiring the best assets and development efforts, each of our core areas contributed to expanding our resource potential. In the Northern Delaware Basin, results from our drilling program, optimizing completion techniques and downspacing increased our inventory.
We also made significant progress in the Southern Delaware Basin and in the Midland Basin. In both areas, field infrastructure improved our economics. And in the Southern Delaware, derisking the play, combined with acreage trades and acquisitions, expanded our long lateral drilling inventory and increased our confidence in the growth potential of this asset.
Our enthusiasm for the New Mexico Shelf hasn't waned. Horizontal results surpassed expectations. These low cost, shallow opportunities have some of the best economics in our portfolio. And while we've had success at defining and expanding our resource base, we're drilling at a slower pace.
We reduced our activity level over the course of 2015, such that our cash flow exceeded drilling and uncompleted capital by approximately $225 million in the second half of the year. With capital activity aligned with the lower commodity price environment, a premier asset base, a robust hedge position and a strong balance sheet, we're approaching 2016 with confidence that we can continue to take advantage of the current environment.
And a strategy we've executed in the second half of '15 is what you're going to see from us in 2016 as low commodity prices continue to demand capital discipline and patience.
We believe oil prices will ultimately move higher, but for now, we remain committed to a plan of balancing our entire capital spend, excluding potential acquisitions, within estimated cash flow. This is a strategy that's been successful for Concho. It will maintain our financial strength and preserve our high-quality inventory through this down cycle.
We've lowered our 2016 capital plan from a base budget of $1.4 billion to a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. The current capital plan for 2016 represents a 35% reduction compared to 2015. Our production outlook for 2016 is driven by timing and transitioning to full field development.
The last 2 years, we've grown production at a compound rate of 25% annually. In the second half of '15, we significantly reduced operating activity and will again reduce activity in 2016. Importantly, over the past 2 years, our drilling program successfully defined multizone potential broadly across our operating areas, resulting in substantial resource discovery.
As we look to further increase the efficiency of our ongoing development program, a substantial portion of our 2016 program will utilize pad drilling and long lateral development.
The combined effect of exceptional growth over the past 2 years, followed by a slowdown in activity and transition to pad drilling will have a more pronounced impact on 2000 -- in 2016, but we'll continue to demonstrate our ability to deliver capital-efficient growth over the long term.
Based on the current market outlook for commodity prices and continuing to spend within cash flow, we expect to deliver double-digit production growth in 2017.
Let me say that again. Based on the current market outlook for commodity prices and continuing to spend within cash flow, we expect to deliver double-digit production growth in 2017.
Importantly, our plan is flexible, and we're keeping both hands on the steering wheel as we navigate the volatility.
We have a strong track record of delivering growth and by staying committed to a strong balance sheet and preserving our inventory rather than growing volumes and depleting our resource in a weak price environment, we will be uniquely positioned to grow when conditions improve.
Acquiring high-quality assets in the Permian is a key component of our strategy. Given the capital chasing acreage in the Permian, property values remain high, but our acquisition efforts in 2015 were disciplined, targeted and privately negotiated. We acquired interest in bolt-on acreage to our core areas. These acquisitions expanded our long lateral drilling inventory and enhanced the overall value of our portfolio.
Our operational expertise in the Permian is a technical advantage when evaluating acquisitions. We couple this expertise with discipline. We're looking to consolidate the right assets at the right price at the right time.
Our team evaluated a lot of opportunities and demonstrated their ability to move on the best deals with the most positive strategic impact.
We have a deep inventory of drilling projects. At today's drilling pace and current environment, we have more than 2 decades of inventory that generate competitive rates of return and growth.
The depth and quality of our inventory sets a high bar for future acquisitions. The opportunities we evaluate have to compete with the best projects in our portfolio.
Our recently announced transactions achieved this objective. The acreage trade and asset acquisition, coupled with the asset sale in Loving County, high graded our drilling program, increased our exposure to the best part of the Southern Delaware Basin, while also strengthening our balance sheet.
Having a strong balance sheet is a key component of our strategy, which continues to serve us well. Recently, our debt ratings were reaffirmed at both S&P and Moody's.
I'm also proud to report that Concho was added to the S&P 500 last Friday. Concho's addition to the S&P 500 is a testament to the hard work and dedication of our team. Together, we've grown Concho into a leading E&P company, operating in one of the most prolific oil basins in the world. Despite the uncertain backdrop, our strategy and our team enable Concho to thrive. We've demonstrated our ability to rapidly grow production. We have a great asset base and a great machine.
The commodity price environment is uncertain, but we believe we can continue to build value through the cycle by keeping a strong balance sheet, prudently investing in the business and staying disciplined in order to take advantage of unique opportunities.
I appreciate your continued confidence in Concho. Now let me turn the call back over to the moderator, and I look forward to your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: First question, Tim. Last quarter, you mentioned that one of the least appreciated aspects of the acquisitions you all have been making over the past year or so is the ability to execute longer laterals after consolidating the acreage. And I know you've talked about sort of that roughly kind of 2x the oil for 1.5x the cost. And sort of along those lines after the Southern Delaware acreage you picked up last month, if you could sort of give a ballpark estimate now and kind of what percentage of that Southern Delaware acreage position you can now do the longer laterals on?

componenttext: Yes, it's a real blocky acreage there in the sweet spot of the Southern Delaware Basin. So almost all of that acreage down there, we will be drilling long laterals.

componenttext: And when I look at the pretty encouraging commentary, at least preliminarily on the 2017 outlook, I was hoping to get a little bit of color on the DUCs. I know we have 30 DUCs at the end of the third quarter. Maybe if where those stood at the end of '15 and then sort of what you're preliminarily guiding to and where those stand at the end of '16 that's maybe allowing you to go into 2017 pretty strong?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me first describe that as we ended the year last year, we land at our budget. The number of uncompleted wells that we had rose modestly, but those -- as we execute our 2015 capital plan will kind of be worked off in a normal basis down to what we
componenttext: Yes, let me first describe that as we ended the year last year, we land at our budget. The number of uncompleted wells that we had rose modestly, but those -- as we execute our 2015 capital plan will kind of be worked off in a normal basis down to what we've indicated in the past is what we like to carry as an inventory of uncompleted wells. And then as far as the rest of the timing of the year, one thing I want to make sure everybody understands is the impact of the slowdown in the second half of '15 and how that impact then affects the overall production for 2016 and then going into '17. Because we really are gaining capital efficiencies and have gained them through the last half of '15 and is really driving a capital-efficient process right now. We're not projecting any additional capital efficiencies going through '16 into '17, but based on the way conditions are today, you're going to see kind of a flattening of production throughout 2016, but then the base economics take over again and we start growing again in 2017 and beyond.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and John, this is Jack. Just to tie that to your first question, too, on lateral length. We are going to be up about 40% on average over last year to somewhere over 7,000 feet on average per lateral. So that helps in that production profile as well.
componenttext: Yes, and John, this is Jack. Just to tie that to your first question, too, on lateral length. We are going to be up about 40% on average over last year to somewhere over 7,000 feet on average per lateral. So that helps in that production profile as well.

componenttext: Tim, I was hoping you could provide some high level strategic thoughts around the recent acreage transactions that you all announced in January. And what do you think investors may not fully appreciate about some of the transactions and the advantages for Concho longer term?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you. I think the high level strategic thought is that when you have a portfolio as large as ours, there is a constant high grading of the opportunities within that portfolio. And the transactions that our team was able to pull off, where we bou
componenttext: Yes. Thank you. I think the high level strategic thought is that when you have a portfolio as large as ours, there is a constant high grading of the opportunities within that portfolio. And the transactions that our team was able to pull off, where we bought, sold and traded and then could describe it to you all at the time, I think, highlights how we think about managing our properties. And I think the benefits of that high grading both from cost reductions, better economics, more efficient drilling, locked-up acreage, focusing on the sweet spots in the Permian, I think really impact the efficiency of the company going forward. And you ought to expect to see more of that kind of activity. That's not just a onetime deal. That's kind of a normal process.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then my follow-up, Concho historically and is very well hedged compared to peers, I noticed there was no change in the oil hedge percentage quarter-to-quarter. So what are your thoughts on hedging in here even though price is low, but then
componenttext: Excellent. And then my follow-up, Concho historically and is very well hedged compared to peers, I noticed there was no change in the oil hedge percentage quarter-to-quarter. So what are your thoughts on hedging in here even though price is low, but then you try to balance that against your typical desire to go ahead and try to get a certain percentage hedged as you look out over the forward 12 months?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've followed us long enough to know that we tend to think of the hedging program more as a dollar cost averaging than we do a call on oil prices as a major theme for us. I'll tell you also that we limit our hedging to our PDP decline curve going forwar
componenttext: You've followed us long enough to know that we tend to think of the hedging program more as a dollar cost averaging than we do a call on oil prices as a major theme for us. I'll tell you also that we limit our hedging to our PDP decline curve going forward. That curve has been flattening. But also as our drilling activity slows down, the level of oil that you need to hedge going forward is less, so you don't see as much hedging activity. Also, I would tell you that our hedging philosophy leaves a little room and therefore, our discretion to kind of interpret the market conditions and we've exercised some of that discretion in the recent past.

componenttext: Well, I think that the cost declines that we've seen up to this point, the scenario we are talking about going forward where oil is at the strip, I think all those cost declines you maintain those throughout that business cycle. componenttext: Yes, I do think that in the service sector, there is a large amount of destruction of capacity from smaller companies and smaller operators. And I think that scale is going to be important. And that's why I think that we have an advantage by running one of the larger programs. componenttext: Okay. And then last one on my end was just around M&A. But I'm just curious on your perspective on the seller side, are you seeing any -- are you aware of any signs of, let's say, emerging distress in the current environment that might help narrow up that bid-ask after this latest leg down?

componenttextpreview: That's right. I think Concho is -- not all assets are created equal. so we're focused on kind of what we believe are the fairways in the Permian, and I think we have something unique to offer. And our ability to offer participation going forward as we did
componenttext: That's right. I think Concho is -- not all assets are created equal. so we're focused on kind of what we believe are the fairways in the Permian, and I think we have something unique to offer. And our ability to offer participation going forward as we did in this last trade, I think we're a pretty good partner. And so I think that gives us an advantage. And we've drilled a lot of wells before. We got strong opinions about where we ought to be drilling. So in general though, you're going to see a lot of activity in the Permian Basin. There's -- people have started talking about it in terms of Tier 1, Tier 2, Tier 3 acreage and things like that. And clearly, I think that we have been focused on accumulating Tier 1 acreage, and that's going to be where our focus is going forward.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: Tim, maybe just to follow on to Michael's question. You talked a lot about being a consolidator in the M&A market, but you also have a pretty big inventory that is economic at fairly low prices. You sold some assets in January. So is that a strategy we should expect you to continue doing as well? And if so, are there any specific areas that we should expect you to focus divestitures on?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Portfolio management is something you ought to expect us to continue to do. And you're aware of where our Tier 1 and sweet spots are. So everything outside of that is on the table for being traded or high graded. I don't know how you want to think about i
componenttext: Portfolio management is something you ought to expect us to continue to do. And you're aware of where our Tier 1 and sweet spots are. So everything outside of that is on the table for being traded or high graded. I don't know how you want to think about it, but that's the way our portfolio management will look going forward.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And in terms of just HBP requirements in 2016, is there any acreage at this point that you might let go?
componenttext: And in terms of just HBP requirements in 2016, is there any acreage at this point that you might let go?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, I mean, not just in this period, but throughout our history, there's always acreage that's expiring because we elect not to drill it for one reason or another. So it's -- there's always a component of that. If you look at our capital budget though, we
componenttext: Oh, I mean, not just in this period, but throughout our history, there's always acreage that's expiring because we elect not to drill it for one reason or another. So it's -- there's always a component of that. If you look at our capital budget though, we have a great amount of flexibility on how we allocate our capital. And a very small amount of our -- of capital budget this year has to be dedicated to things to perpetuate acreage.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And last one for me is just in the Yeso, it looks like you saw a pretty big sequential improvement in those well results. Is there anything that you guys did on the completion side there? Is it just a certain area you drilled geographically? What
componenttext: Got it. And last one for me is just in the Yeso, it looks like you saw a pretty big sequential improvement in those well results. Is there anything that you guys did on the completion side there? Is it just a certain area you drilled geographically? What was driving that big improvement?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess it's all those things. It's the way we complete the wells and extending the boundaries of the play. So it's -- we talked for a long time, that's an exciting area, multizone, lots of oil stone, the oil column, horizontal drilling is a application t
componenttext: I guess it's all those things. It's the way we complete the wells and extending the boundaries of the play. So it's -- we talked for a long time, that's an exciting area, multizone, lots of oil stone, the oil column, horizontal drilling is a application that unlocks new oil potential there. So that's -- it's a great area.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: So Tim, if I just add one more on the M&A question. I mean, you guys did mention about, they're not greedy, but the number of distressed companies out there and certainly, you guys have a well above average financials. Your thoughts not only in the Permian, but would you consider looking outside at another basin if the price is right or be an accretive acquisition?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there are so many opportunities in the Permian and we carry such an advantage here I think that focusing outside the Permian would be taking our eye off the ball to some extent. We talked in the past though that sometimes you end up getting some o
componenttext: I think there are so many opportunities in the Permian and we carry such an advantage here I think that focusing outside the Permian would be taking our eye off the ball to some extent. We talked in the past though that sometimes you end up getting some other assets that come with Permian assets, that hasn't really changed. But clearly, we talk about Concho in terms of being a Permian Basin company, a Permian Basin-focused company.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. And then just one last one, if I could. You mentioned about just the progress you're seeing, definitely, in the Midland. Obviously, a lot of the extended reaches depend also on the Southern Del. Your thoughts on how much you guys are tar
componenttext: That makes sense. And then just one last one, if I could. You mentioned about just the progress you're seeing, definitely, in the Midland. Your thoughts on how much you guys are targeting, specifically more in that -- in just in that Northern Harpoon acquisition area that you added not terribly long ago?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, North Harpoon is some of the best returns we're drilling within the company. Locking up acreage is very important there. We've got lots of running room. So it's -- it competes with anything we have. We like that. We've signaled in past quarte
componenttext: Yes, I mean, North Harpoon is some of the best returns we're drilling within the company. Locking up acreage is very important there. We've got lots of running room. So it's -- it competes with anything we have. We like that. We've signaled in past quarters that, that was an area we like and we will continue to add to it.

componenttext: Okay. Okay. Just one more follow-up. As we think about the potential to ramp on the back end, Tim, if you put -- if you say tomorrow, hey, I want to put additional rig in the field, what's the lead time now before you start to see in production just given where we're at today versus a couple years ago, what's that look like?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we've always talked about how we didn't think that people well understood the cycle time from how long it took -- from the time you hit the button that said I want to deploy capital to how long it takes for the cash flow to actually show up on you
componenttext: I mean, we've always talked about how we didn't think that people well understood the cycle time from how long it took -- from the time you hit the button that said I want to deploy capital to how long it takes for the cash flow to actually show up on your the balance sheet. I think that time period is lengthening because pad drilling and other things like longer laterals all that, the economics are better, but the time cycles are lengthened. And I think that's an important component that will work its way through all the models and things like that.

componenttext: Got it. And then the last one for me is just that you talked about, I think, the increase in lateral length going to almost 7,000 feet on average in '16. componenttext: Yes, the average pad is going to be from 2 to 4 typically, David. And I think we talked about the progression up to about 40% pad drilling this year compared to less than half of that last year. And so I think you'll continue to see that type of progression.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked and answered, but I just wanted to get a quick sense on infrastructure and differentials. Gas differentials got a little bit wider in 2016. Can you just speak to that? And then maybe a little bit broader here on sort o
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered, but I just wanted to get a quick sense on infrastructure and differentials. Gas differentials got a little bit wider in 2016. Can you just speak to that? And then maybe a little bit broader here on sort of the capital outlay that you have for the Alpha Crude Connector and other infrastructure items, just remind me of how that trends and how that sort of changes 2015, 2016, into 2017 and beyond?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. On the -- the gas differential is really tied to NGL pricing. So improvement there would lead to better gas price realization. As far as the infrastructure spend on ACC and any other projects, 2016 spending is relatively similar to '15 as we fi
componenttext: Yes, sure. On the -- the gas differential is really tied to NGL pricing. So improvement there would lead to better gas price realization. As far as the infrastructure spend on ACC and any other projects, 2016 spending is relatively similar to '15 as we finish out that project and some other midstream investments that will result in over 80% of our oil being on pipe. And so as we look forward beyond that, I don't expect the same level of spending on midstream into 2017.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Sullivan from Alembic Global Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Sullivan from Alembic Global Advisors.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could go back just very quickly to the '17 growth. And obviously, I appreciate you guys don't want to go into too much detail on this, but when I think about the things that could drive the growth rate higher, obviously, I'm thinking about moderating
componenttext: If I could go back just very quickly to the '17 growth. And obviously, I appreciate you guys don't want to go into too much detail on this, but when I think about the things that could drive the growth rate higher, obviously, I'm thinking about moderating base decline. You do have strip $5 or $6 higher, whatever it might be. Productivity gains. DUCs rolling off of older service contracts. There's a lot of things, but you guys have said that you don't think base decline, I think, in answering an earlier question, would be a major factor, nor DUCs. Productivity gains might be something. Could you kind of rank order what are the things that are allowing you to grow given the base decline is not going to be a major factor, grow at so much higher rate in '17 versus '16?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a stab at that one because I do think base decline is a factor. And I wouldn't -- I'm going to say there's not a major factor. There's a combination of a bunch of things. And we would be growing today at that rate if it weren't for the timing
componenttext: Let me take a stab at that one because I do think base decline is a factor. And I wouldn't -- I'm going to say there's not a major factor. There's a combination of a bunch of things. And we would be growing today at that rate if it weren't for the timing of slowing down at the end of the second half of last year. And so we're not projecting any change of the circumstance that changes the returns on these wells. So it's just -- it's a function of timing. And then as you say, the cash flows modeled in from the commodity price at the strip, the base decline, the timing of things like the pad drilling and the wells we're going to be drilling kind of yield that kind of growth that we would expect in 2017.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. That's good color. Just a very quick modeling question. So from macro to micro here. You guys had suggested on previous calls that with ACC coming online, oil realizations would improve with trucking costs falling. Your guidance for oil reali
componenttext: Okay. Great. That's good color. Just a very quick modeling question. So from macro to micro here. You guys had suggested on previous calls that with ACC coming online, oil realizations would improve with trucking costs falling. Your guidance for oil realizations was flattish, I think, year-on-year for about $4 off TI. Can you just remind me, is the gathering, the trucking cost or pipe cost, is that in the -- reflected in the realization or is that coming out of an expense line item?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it is reflected in the realization and you will -- as we add more barrels throughout the first half of the year on to that pipeline system, you will see continued benefit from that. One bit of noise going on and way in the details here is the pricing
componenttext: No, it is reflected in the realization and you will -- as we add more barrels throughout the first half of the year on to that pipeline system, you will see continued benefit from that. One bit of noise going on and way in the details here is the pricing mechanism used to bring a futures price back to a spot price is negatively impacted when you have a contango market like we do now versus last year where the market was backwardated most of the year and you had a positive benefit. So that creates a little noise, but we are seeing the benefits from ACC and we'll continue to throughout the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. great. So it's not exactly writable for the year. It sounds like what you're saying is that benefit will come in [indiscernible].
componenttext: Okay. great. So it's not exactly writable for the year. It sounds like what you're saying is that benefit will come in [indiscernible].

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. Q4 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms.
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. Q4 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Megan Hays, Director, Investor Relations. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.Our fourth quarter earnings release and corpo
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our fourth quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements this morning. Also some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in both the earnings release and corporate presentation.
I understand it's a busy morning, so thank you, again, for taking the time to listen to our call.
Now I'll turn it over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks, again, for joining us on this busy morning. By now you've heard many metaphors describing the commodity price environment from choppy waters to rough terrain. The backdrop we find ourselves in is volatile and dynamic, but the Concho
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks, again, for joining us on this busy morning. By now you've heard many metaphors describing the commodity price environment from choppy waters to rough terrain. The backdrop we find ourselves in is volatile and dynamic, but the Concho team has experience succeeding when prices are low.
We're building a company that can thrive at any point in the cycle. We consolidate high-quality properties in the Permian Basin and have an exceptional track record of profitably growing production, reserves and resource. And while the past year has been challenging, we view the macro environment as an opportunity to extend our lead in the Permian and make our business stronger by focusing on what we can control and strategically consolidating acreage in our core areas. We believe this approach enables Concho to deliver on our near-term objectives, while providing our shareholders with a solid investment for long-term value creation.
From both an operational and a financial perspective, Concho delivered exceptional results for 2015, demonstrating the quality of our team and assets. As the oil price continued its volatile and protracted decline, we reduced capital spending from an initial budget of $3 billion to $2 billion, and we expected annual production growth to be less than 20%. We ended up delivering more with less. Daily production volumes for 2015 increased 28%, with crude oil growing by 31%, while exploration and development capital totaled only $1.8 billion for the year.
The results of our 2015 program highlight our improved capital efficiency, driven by lower service cost, shorter cycle times, long laterals and completion intensity.
I'm proud of how well our operational teams performed given all the moving parts. Their focus drove better well performance across all our assets and resulted in per-unit cost that were in line or below the low end of our guidance range.
Proved reserves held steady despite the 50% decline in SEC prices used to calculate proved reserves. And we replaced 290% of production at a drill bit finding cost of $11.66 per barrel. We've been focused on the Permian for a long time. It's a resource-rich basin, and our teams generate more economic drilling opportunities on our assets each year.
Over the past 2 years, our drilling program has unlocked more resource as we convert vertical drilling locations to horizontal locations, derisk multizone potential and successfully test denser well spacing.
In total, the captured resource for the company increased by 35% during 2015 to 5 billion Boes, including proved reserves. And we've identified approximately 18,000 horizontal drilling locations. Approximately 30% of these locations earn a 20% or greater rate of return at a flat $40 oil price. This is a function of moving down the cost curve, refining our drilling and completion techniques and improving well performance.
Given our focus on acquiring the best assets and development efforts, each of our core areas contributed to expanding our resource potential. In the Northern Delaware Basin, results from our drilling program, optimizing completion techniques and downspacing increased our inventory.
We also made significant progress in the Southern Delaware Basin and in the Midland Basin. In both areas, field infrastructure improved our economics. And in the Southern Delaware, derisking the play, combined with acreage trades and acquisitions, expanded our long lateral drilling inventory and increased our confidence in the growth potential of this asset.
Our enthusiasm for the New Mexico Shelf hasn't waned. Horizontal results surpassed expectations. These low-cost, shallow opportunities have some of the best economics in our portfolio. And while we've had success at defining and expanding our resource base, we're drilling at a slower pace.
We reduced our activity level over the course of 2015 such that our cash flow exceeded drilling and completion capital by approximately $225 million in the second half of the year. With capital activity aligned with the lower commodity price environment, a premier asset base, a robust hedge position and a strong balance sheet, we're approaching 2016 with confidence that we can continue to take advantage of the current environment.
And the strategy we've executed in the second half of '15 is what you're going to see from us in 2016, as low commodity prices continue to demand capital discipline and patience.
We believe oil prices will ultimately move higher, but for now, we remain committed to a plan of balancing our entire capital spend, excluding potential acquisitions, within estimated cash flow. This is a strategy that's been successful for Concho. It will maintain our financial strength and preserve our high-quality inventory through this down cycle.
We've lowered our 2016 capital plan from a base budget of $1.4 billion to a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. The current capital plan for 2016 represents a 35% reduction compared to 2015. Our production outlook for 2016 is driven by timing and transitioning to full field development.
The last 2 years we've grown production at a compound rate of 25% annually. In the second half of '15, we significantly reduced operating activity and will again reduce activity in 2016. Importantly, over the past 2 years, our drilling program successfully defined multizone potential broadly across our operating areas, resulting in substantial resource discovery.
As we look to further increase the efficiency of our ongoing development program, a substantial portion of our 2016 program will utilize pad drilling and long lateral development.
The combined effect of exceptional growth over the past 2 years followed by a slowdown in activity and transition to pad drilling will have a more pronounced impact on 2000 -- in 2016, but we'll continue to demonstrate our ability to deliver capital-efficient growth over the long term.
Based on the current market outlook for commodity prices and continuing to spend within cash flow, we expect to deliver double-digit production growth in 2017.
Let me say that again. Based on the current market outlook for commodity prices and continuing to spend within cash flow, we expect to deliver double-digit production growth in 2017.
Importantly, our plan is flexible, and we're keeping both hands on the steering wheel as we navigate the volatility.
We have a strong track record of delivering growth, and by staying committed to a strong balance sheet and preserving our inventory rather than growing volumes and depleting our resource in a weak price environment, we will be uniquely positioned to grow when conditions improve.
Acquiring high-quality assets in the Permian is a key component of our strategy. Given the capital chasing acreage in the Permian, property values remain high; but our acquisition efforts in 2015 were disciplined, targeted and privately negotiated. We acquired interest and bolt-on acreage to our core areas. These acquisitions expanded our long lateral drilling inventory and enhanced the overall value of our portfolio.
Our operational expertise in the Permian is a technical advantage when evaluating acquisitions. We couple this expertise with discipline. We're looking to consolidate the right assets at the right price at the right time.
Our team evaluated a lot of opportunities and demonstrated their ability to move on the best deals with the most positive strategic impact.
We have a deep inventory of drilling projects. At today's drilling pace and current environment, we have more than 2 decades of inventory that generate competitive rates of return and growth.
The depth and quality of our inventory sets a high bar for future acquisitions. The opportunities we evaluate have to compete with the best projects in our portfolio.
Our recently announced transactions achieved this objective. The acreage trade and asset acquisition, coupled with the asset sale in Loving County, high graded our drilling program, increased our exposure to the best part of the Southern Delaware Basin, while also strengthening our balance sheet.
Having a strong balance sheet is a key component of our strategy, which continues to serve us well. Recently, our debt ratings were reaffirmed at both S&P and Moody's.
I'm also proud to report that Concho was added to the S&P 500 last Friday. Concho's addition to the S&P 500 is a testament to the hard work and dedication of our team. Together, we've grown Concho into a leading E&P company, operating in one of the most prolific oil basins in the world. Despite the uncertain backdrop, our strategy and our team enable Concho to thrive. We've demonstrated our ability to rapidly grow production. We have a great asset base and a great machine.
The commodity price environment is uncertain, but we believe we can continue to build value through the cycle by keeping a strong balance sheet, prudently investing in the business and staying disciplined in order to take advantage of unique opportunities.
I appreciate your continued confidence in Concho. Now let me turn the call back over to the moderator, and I look forward to your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from John Freeman from Raymond James.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from John Freeman from Raymond James.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, Tim. Last quarter, you mentioned that one of the least-appreciated aspects of the acquisitions y'all been making over the past year or so is the ability to execute longer laterals after consolidating the acreage. And I know you've talked a
componenttext: First question, Tim. Last quarter, you mentioned that one of the least-appreciated aspects of the acquisitions y'all been making over the past year or so is the ability to execute longer laterals after consolidating the acreage. And I know you've talked about sort of that roughly kind of 2x the oil for 1.5x the cost. And sort of along those lines, after the Southern Delaware acreage you picked up last month, if you could sort of give a ballpark estimate now and kind of what percentage of that Southern Delaware acreage position you can now do the longer laterals on?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a real blocky acreage there in the sweet spot of the Southern Delaware Basin. So almost all of that acreage down there, we will be drilling long laterals.
componenttext: Yes, it's a real blocky acreage there in the sweet spot of the Southern Delaware Basin. So almost all of that acreage down there, we will be drilling long laterals.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when I look at the pretty encouraging commentary, at least preliminarily on the 2017 outlook, I was hoping to get a little bit of color on the DUCs. I know we have 30 DUCs at the end of the third quarter. Maybe if where those stood at the end of '15 a
componenttext: And when I look at the pretty encouraging commentary, at least preliminarily on the 2017 outlook, I was hoping to get a little bit of color on the DUCs. I know we have 30 DUCs at the end of the third quarter. Maybe if where those stood at the end of '15 and then sort of what you're preliminarily guiding to and where those stand at the end of '16 that's maybe allowing you to go into 2017 pretty strong?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me first describe that as we ended the year last year, we land at our budget. The number of uncompleted wells that we had rose modestly, but those as we execute our 2015 capital plan will kind of be worked off in a normal basis down to what we've
componenttext: Yes, let me first describe that as we ended the year last year, we land at our budget. The number of uncompleted wells that we had rose modestly, but those as we execute our 2015 capital plan will kind of be worked off in a normal basis down to what we've indicated in the past is what we like to carry as an inventory of uncompleted wells. And then as far as the rest of the timing of the year, one thing I want to make sure everybody understands is the impact of the slowdown in the second half of '15 and how that impact then affects the overall production for 2016 and then going into '17. Because we really are gaining capital efficiencies and have gained them through the last half of '15, and it's really driving a capital-efficient process right now. We're not projecting any additional capital efficiencies going through '16 into '17, but based on the way conditions are today, you're going to see kind of a flattening of production throughout 2016, but then the base economics take over again, and we start growing again in 2017 and beyond.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and John, this is Jack. Just to tie that to your first question, too, on lateral length. We are going to be up about 40% on average over last year to somewhere over 7,000 feet on average per lateral. So that helps in that production profile as well.
componenttext: Yes, and John, this is Jack. Just to tie that to your first question, too, on lateral length. We are going to be up about 40% on average over last year to somewhere over 7,000 feet on average per lateral. So that helps in that production profile as well.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond from Simmons & Company.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, I was hoping you could provide some high-level strategic thoughts around the recent acreage transactions that you all announced in January. And what do you think investors may not fully appreciate about some of the transactions and the advantages for
componenttext: Tim, I was hoping you could provide some high-level strategic thoughts around the recent acreage transactions that you all announced in January. And what do you think investors may not fully appreciate about some of the transactions and the advantages for Concho longer term?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thank you. I think the high-level strategic thought is that when you have a portfolio as large as ours there is a constant high grading of the opportunities within that portfolio. And the transactions that our team was able to pull off where we bough
componenttext: Yes. Thank you. I think the high-level strategic thought is that when you have a portfolio as large as ours there is a constant high grading of the opportunities within that portfolio. And the transactions that our team was able to pull off where we bought, sold and traded and then could describe it to you all at the time, I think highlights how we think about managing our properties. And I think the benefits of that high grading both from cost reductions, better economics, more-efficient drilling, locked-up acreage, focusing on the sweet spots in the Permian, I think really impact the efficiency of the company going forward. And you ought to expect to see more of that kind of activity. That's not just a onetime deal. That's kind of a normal process.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then my follow-up. Concho historically and is very well hedged compared to peers. I noticed there was no change in the oil hedge percentage quarter-to-quarter. So what are your thoughts on hedging in here even though price is low, but then
componenttext: Excellent. And then my follow-up. Concho historically and is very well hedged compared to peers. I noticed there was no change in the oil hedge percentage quarter-to-quarter. So what are your thoughts on hedging in here even though price is low, but then you try to balance that against your typical desire to go ahead and try to get a certain percentage hedged as you look out over the forward 12 months?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've followed us long enough to know that we tend to think of the hedging program more as a dollar cost averaging than we do a call on oil prices as a major theme for us. I'll tell you also that we limit our hedging to our PDP decline curve going forwar
componenttext: You've followed us long enough to know that we tend to think of the hedging program more as a dollar cost averaging than we do a call on oil prices as a major theme for us. I'll tell you also that we limit our hedging to our PDP decline curve going forward. That curve has been flattening. But also as our drilling activity slows down, the level of oil that you need to hedge going forward is less, so you don't see as much hedging activity. Also I would tell you that our hedging philosophy leaves a little room in there for our discretion to kind of interpret the market conditions, and we've exercised some of that discretion in the recent past.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Arun Jayaram from JPMorgan.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to first start off in the Midland Basin, Tim. It looks like you're increasing the mix of spending towards the Midland Basin. I know that historically you've drilled perhaps shorter laterals despite your blocky acreage position, but it sounds like
componenttext: I wanted to first start off in the Midland Basin, Tim. It looks like you're increasing the mix of spending towards the Midland Basin. I know that historically you've drilled perhaps shorter laterals despite your blocky acreage position, but it sounds like you're moving towards 10,000-foot laterals. I was wondering if you could perhaps comment on why you're increasing your CapEx here and just maybe thoughts of your overall Midland Basin acreage because this seems to be in the core of the core.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, this is Jack. Thank you. We are increasing our capital allocation to the Midland Basin. And that's the culmination of learning, infrastructure and our ability to really have a full program with these long laterals. And so I would expect a conti
componenttext: Yes, Arun, this is Jack. Thank you. We are increasing our capital allocation to the Midland Basin. And that's the culmination of learning, infrastructure and our ability to really have a full program with these long laterals. And so I would expect a continuation of that.

componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And just, obviously, a pretty provocative comment on the 2017 growth, double digits within cash flows. So just wondering if you can maybe give us a little bit more color around that because that's quite a bit higher than The Street. Is this just well productivity? You talked a little bit about the DUCs. And also I just wanted to say, is this at the strip? Today, the oil price is $42. As you think about the 2017 strip, what oil prices are you thinking about when talking about double-digit growth in '17?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we were talking about at the strip. And I would tell you, I wanted to add that color because I didn't want 2016 to be misinterpreted. I mean, we're doing some really good things right now in 2016. And as -- timing is a big effect on when we do 1-year
componenttext: Yes, we were talking about at the strip. And I would tell you, I wanted to add that color because I didn't want 2016 to be misinterpreted. I mean, we're doing some really good things right now in 2016. And as -- timing is a big effect on when we do 1-year time slices and look at the production growth within those time slices. So we're really encouraged by what we're seeing in our field right now. And 2017 tells you a lot about what's going on in 2016 that you might not be able to see just from looking at production growth in this 1-year time slice.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. If I can sneak one more in,. You guys talked about some disruptions in the first quarter regarding weather in midstream. Is this just kind of a Q1 impact? Or could there be any lingering impact as we think about Q2?
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. If I can sneak one more in,. You guys talked about some disruptions in the first quarter regarding weather in midstream. Is this just kind of a Q1 impact? Or could there be any lingering impact as we think about Q2?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, as we know it today, there may be some modest impact in the second quarter, but really the main impact should be in the first quarter.
componenttext: Yes, Arun, as we know it today, there may be some modest impact in the second quarter, but really the main impact should be in the first quarter.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the cost declines and efficiencies that you have seen and you think about potentially going back to double-digit growth at the strip, do you view the cost declines -- or what percent of the cost declines and efficiencies that you see do y
componenttext: When you look at the cost declines and efficiencies that you have seen and you think about potentially going back to double-digit growth at the strip, do you view the cost declines -- or what percent of the cost declines and efficiencies that you see do you view as secular? And also as you and potentially others in the Permian think about ramping up again, what is your level of confidence that the service infrastructure will be there in full force?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the cost declines we've seen up to this point -- the scenario we are talking about going forward where oil is at the strip, I think all those cost declines you maintain those throughout that business cycle. And so I think the cost effic
componenttext: Well, I think that the cost declines we've seen up to this point -- the scenario we are talking about going forward where oil is at the strip, I think all those cost declines you maintain those throughout that business cycle. And so I think the cost efficiency that we've achieved -- and I expect it to get better. I think there are still ways that we can improve our cost structure. What was the other question?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: The services infrastructure and whether you think that, that will be in full force as you and others start to ramp up again if oil prices improve?
componenttext: The services infrastructure and whether you think that, that will be in full force as you and others start to ramp up again if oil prices improve?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do think that in the service sector, there is a large amount of destruction of capacity from smaller companies and smaller operators. And I think that scale is going to be important. And that's why I think that we have an advantage by running one o
componenttext: Yes, I do think that in the service sector, there is a large amount of destruction of capacity from smaller companies and smaller operators. And I think that scale is going to be important. And that's why I think that we have an advantage by running one of the larger programs. And so I think the services will be there for the companies that have been there through this cycle.
