componenttext: Okay. And then last one on my end was just around M&A generally in the Permian. I'm just curious, we hear a lot about -- how you hear the buy side of the market is given the remaining large capital, still they're looking at the region. But I'm just curious on your perspectives on the seller side. Are you seeing any -- are you aware of any signs of, let's say, emerging distress in the current environment that might help narrow up that bid-ask after this latest lag down?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in this environment, I think everybody is distressed.
componenttext: Well, in this environment, I think everybody is distressed.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Relative degrees of distress?
componenttext: Relative degrees of distress?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right. I think Concho is -- not all assets are created equal. so we're focused on kind of what we believe are the fairways in the Permian, and I think we have something unique to offer. And our ability to offer participation going forward, as we di
componenttext: That's right. I think Concho is -- not all assets are created equal. so we're focused on kind of what we believe are the fairways in the Permian, and I think we have something unique to offer. And our ability to offer participation going forward, as we did in this last trade, I think we're a pretty good partner. And so I think that gives us an advantage. And we've drilled a lot of wells before. We got strong opinions about where we ought to be drilling. So in general though, you're going to see a lot of activity in the Permian Basin. There's -- people have started talking about it in terms of Tier 1, Tier 2, Tier 3 acreage and things like that. And clearly, I think that we have been focused on accumulating Tier 1 acreage, and that's going to be where our focus is going forward.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Smith from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: Tim, maybe just to follow on to Michael's question. You talked a lot about being a consolidator in the M&A market, but you also have a pretty big inventory that is economic at fairly low prices. You sold some assets in January. So is that a strategy we should expect you to continue doing as well? And if so, are there any specific areas that we should expect you to focus divestitures on?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Portfolio management is something you ought to expect us to continue to do. And you're aware of where our Tier 1 and sweet spots are. So everything outside of that is on the table for being traded or high graded. I don't know how you want to think about i
componenttext: Portfolio management is something you ought to expect us to continue to do. And you're aware of where our Tier 1 and sweet spots are. So everything outside of that is on the table for being traded or high graded. I don't know how you want to think about it, but that's the way our portfolio management will look going forward.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: And in terms of HBP requirements in 2016, is there any acreage at this point that you might let go?

componenttext: Oh, I mean, not just in this period, but throughout our history, there's always acreage that's expiring because we elect not to drill it for one reason or another. So it's -- there's always a component of that. If you look at our capital budget though, we have a great amount of flexibility on how we allocate our capital. And a very small amount of our -- of capital budget this year has to be dedicated to things to perpetuate acreage.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And last one for me is just, in the Yeso it looks like you saw a pretty big sequential improvement in those well results. headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's all those things. It's the way we complete the wells and extending the boundaries of the play. So it's -- we talked for a long time, that's an exciting area, multizone, lots of oil stone, the oil column. Horizontal drilling is a application that unlo
componenttext: It's all those things. It's the way we complete the wells and extending the boundaries of the play. So it's -- we talked for a long time, that's an exciting area, multizone, lots of oil stone, the oil column. Horizontal drilling is a application that unlocks new oil potential there. So that's -- it's a great area.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: So Tim, if I just add one more on the M&A question. I mean, you guys did mention about -- then I agree with you about the number of distressed companies out there. Your thoughts not only in the Permian, but would you consider looking outside at another basin if the price is right or be an accretive acquisition?

componenttext: I think there are so many opportunities in the Permian and we carry such an advantage here I think that focusing outside the Permian would be taking our eye off the ball to some extent. We talked in the past though that sometimes you end up getting some other assets that come with Permian assets. That hasn't really changed. But clearly, we talk about Concho in terms of being a Permian Basin company, a Permian Basin-focused company.

componenttext: That makes sense. And then just one last one, if I could. You mentioned about just the progress you're seeing, definitely, in the Midland. Your thoughts on how much you guys are targeting, specifically more in that -- in just in that Northern Harpoon acquisition area that you added not terribly long ago?

componenttext: Yes, I mean, North Harpoon is some of the best returns we're drilling within the company. Blocking up acreage is very important there. We've got lots of running room. So it's -- it competes with anything we have. We like that. We've signaled in past quarters that, that was an area we like and we will continue to add to it.

componenttext: Okay. Okay. Just one more follow-up. As we think about the potential to ramp on the back end, Tim, if you put a -- if you say tomorrow, hey, I want to put additional rig in the field, what's the lead time now before you start to see production, just given where we're at today versus a couple years ago, what's that look like?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016

componenttext: I mean, we've always talked about how we didn't think that people well understood the cycle time from how long it took -- from the time you hit the button that said I want to deploy capital to how long it takes for the cash flow to actually show up on your the balance sheet. I think that time period is lengthening because pad drilling and other things like longer laterals all that the economics are better, but the time cycles are lengthened. And I think that's an important component that will work its way through all the models and things like that.

componenttext: No, David, you said it exactly right. It's -- it is a function of lower activity, and just beginning to have more new production over the next couple of years should modestly tick that back up.

componenttext: Yes, the average pad is going to be from 2 to 4 typically, David. And I think we talked about the progression up to about 40% pad drilling this year compared to less than half of that last year. And so I think you'll continue to see that type of progression.

componenttext: Okay. Fine. That's helpful. Slide 11 highlighted advancing the Lower Spraberry program. componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Oatman from Cowen.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked and answered, but I just wanted to get a quick sense on infrastructure and differentials. Gas differentials guided a little bit wider in 2016. Can you just speak to that? And then maybe a little bit broader here on sor
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered, but I just wanted to get a quick sense on infrastructure and differentials. Gas differentials guided a little bit wider in 2016. Can you just speak to that? And then maybe a little bit broader here on sort of the capital outlay that you have for the Alpha Crude Connector and other infrastructure items, just remind me of how that trends and how that sort of changes 2015, 2016, into 2017 and beyond?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. On the -- the gas differential is really tied to NGL pricing. So improvement there would lead to better gas price realization. As far as the infrastructure spend on ACC and any other projects, 2016 spending is relatively similar to '15; as we f
componenttext: Yes, sure. On the -- the gas differential is really tied to NGL pricing. So improvement there would lead to better gas price realization. As far as the infrastructure spend on ACC and any other projects, 2016 spending is relatively similar to '15; as we finish out that project and some other midstream investments, that will result in over 80% of our oil being on pipe. And so as we look forward beyond that, I don't expect the same level of spending on midstream into 2017.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Sullivan from Alembic Global Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Sullivan from Alembic Global Advisors.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could go back just very quickly to the '17 growth. And obviously, I appreciate you guys don't want to go into too much detail on this. But when I think about the things that could drive the growth rate higher, obviously, I'm thinking about moderating
componenttext: If I could go back just very quickly to the '17 growth. And obviously, I appreciate you guys don't want to go into too much detail on this. But when I think about the things that could drive the growth rate higher, obviously, I'm thinking about moderating base decline. You do have strip $5 or $6 higher, whatever it might be. Productivity gains. DUCs rolling off of older service contracts. There's a lot of things. But you guys have said that you don't think base decline, I think in answering an earlier question, would be a major factor nor DUCs. Productivity gains might be something. Could you kind of rank order what are the things that are allowing you to grow given the base decline is not going to be a major factor, grow at so much higher rate in '17 versus '16?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a stab at that one because I do think base decline is a factor. And I wouldn't -- I'm going to say there's not a major factor. There's a combination of a bunch of things. And we would be growing today at that rate if it weren't for the timing
componenttext: Let me take a stab at that one because I do think base decline is a factor. And I wouldn't -- I'm going to say there's not a major factor. There's a combination of a bunch of things. And we would be growing today at that rate if it weren't for the timing of slowing down at the end of the second half of last year. And so we're not projecting any change of the circumstance that changes the returns on these wells. So it's just -- it's a function of timing. And then as you say, the cash flow is modeled in from the commodity price at the strip, the base decline, the timing of things like the pad drilling and the wells we're going to be drilling, kind of yield that kind of growth that we would expect in 2017.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. That's good color. Just a very quick modeling question. So from macro to micro here. You guys had suggested on previous calls that with ACC coming online oil realizations would improve with trucking costs falling. Your guidance for oil realiz
componenttext: Okay. Great. That's good color. Just a very quick modeling question. So from macro to micro here. You guys had suggested on previous calls that with ACC coming online oil realizations would improve with trucking costs falling. Your guidance for oil realizations was flattish, I think, year-on-year for about $4 off TI. Can you just remind me, is the gathering, the trucking cost or pipe cost, is that in the -- reflected in the realization? Or is that coming out of an expense line item?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it is reflected in the realization, and you will -- as we add more barrels throughout the first half of the year on to that pipeline system, you will see continued benefit from that. One bit of noise going on and way in the details here is the pricing
componenttext: No, it is reflected in the realization, and you will -- as we add more barrels throughout the first half of the year on to that pipeline system, you will see continued benefit from that. One bit of noise going on and way in the details here is the pricing mechanism used to bring a futures price back to a spot price is negatively impacted when you have a contango market like we do now versus last year where the market was backwardated most of the year and you had a positive benefit. So that creates a little noise, but we are seeing the benefits from ACC and will continue to throughout the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. great. So it's not exactly rateable for the year. It sounds like what you're saying is that benefit will come in [indiscernible].
componenttext: Okay. great. So it's not exactly rateable for the year. It sounds like what you're saying is that benefit will come in [indiscernible].

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 25, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Incorporated 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, does conference may be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Megan
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Incorporated 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, does conference may be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Megan Hays. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho Senior Management team.Our first quarter earnings release and corpora
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho Senior Management team.
Our first quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements this morning. Also some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in both the earnings release and corporate presentation.
Thanks again. Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before I begin the first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before I begin the first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.
We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in the past 30 years. We responded with deep cost to capital budgets. The U.S. rig count is in all-time low since we began keeping records. Meanwhile, the industry's leverage is at historic highs. Lower 48 oil productions is set decline by nearly 1 million barrels per day in 2016, according to EIA's current estimate.
Thinking about what's happened in our industry over the past 2 years. Underinvestment and overstretched balance sheets, mixed with a growing global population, a decline in U.S. oil production and a service sector that's been cut to the bone. The long-term implications to the balance of supply and demand mean more volatility, not less. Amid the volatility, we're focused on aggressively managing the things we can control. Concho delivered another strong quarter and the contrast between the current environment and our results for the first quarter demonstrate our flexibility to respond to lower oil prices, protect our balance sheet, just in operating momentum.
Results this quarter also reflect our high-quality drilling inventory in the Permian Basin, which sits at the low end of the cost curves and continues to be one of the best basis for driving capital efficient growth and creating value for our shareholders. Our robust hedge position provides stability around our cash flows and combined with our strong portfolio, we're well-positioned to keep moving forward, investing in our assets and driving gains and productivity efficiency. And while commodity prices have moved higher recently, we remain committed to a disciplined returns base capital program while spending within cash flow.
Now let me summarize some of the key achievements in the first quarter. Quarterly production increased 6%[ph] year-over-year and exceeded our guidance range. Operating performance this quarter hide is the strength of our portfolio. Each core area is performing well. For full year 2016, we now expect production will be flat compared to 2015 and our capital plans unchanged.
We continue to make progress on our cost structure. Combined unit cost, LOE and G&A were down 9% year-over-year. And importantly, we've reduced our full year outlook for LOE. Cost controls are a priority and set in the right direction. In addition, the Alpha Crude Connector system in New Mexico is improving our oil price realization in the northern Delaware Basin. As a result, guidance range for the pre-hedged oil differentials has improved.
For the third consecutive quarter, we understand operating cash flow, which excludes A&D. Spending within our means fortifies our balance sheet, and it's with this discipline that we find ourselves in a path to emerge stronger when the cycle started.
Also during the first quarter we closed 2 transactions. The previously announced transactions include an acquisition of 12,000 net 2008 acres adjacent to our core North Harpoon prospect in the Southern Delaware for combined combination of equity, cash and drilling carry and the sale of 14,000 net acres in [indiscernible] County for cash proceeds. The net impact of these transactions added cash to the balance sheet, high graded our inventory and improved our returns base capital allocation program by freeing up capital to develop higher return properties.
Our strong balance sheet's a key advantage during periods of volatility. At quarter end, we had $0.5 billion of cash on our balance sheet and a net debt-to-EBITDAX ratio of 1.7x. We have substantial liquidity of $3 billion and our credit facility is undrawn. The total commitment level is $2.5 billion, which was recently reaffirmed by our lender group.
Turning now to our capital plan for 2016. Our plan to spend within cash flow remains unchanged and the capital guidance is still a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. And I don't have the say that our production's going to be down anymore because now we expect 2016 production to be just as robust as 2015. Our average expected rig count for the year is approximately 14. As we mentioned before during 2016, we plan to direct more capital to the Midland Basin, where consisting pretty strong-willed results and good returns across several zones support our development plans.
Drilling more wells enhances our operational scale, expands our opportunity to test new ideas and accelerate development efficiencies. Our commitment to capital discipline is evident. The first quarter of 2016 represents the third consecutive quarter where cash flow exceeded our drilling expenditures. Since our rig count peak in late 2014, development capital has been reduced 70%. Meanwhile production has grown 12% over that same time period and cash operating expenses are lower.
Lower commodity prices great opportunities for Concho. We're actively managing our portfolio by consolidating core acreage and selling lower rate of return assets. The acquisition of 12,000 net acres in the Southern Delaware Basin brings us new drilling locations that moved to the front of the inventory line. We closed this transaction in late March and shifted 2 rigs on to on these properties in April. Acquisitions for assets like these are very competitive. The seller picked Concho as a partner based on our execution strength, and we liked this asset because they increase our exposure to the best part of the southern Delaware Basin and add long lateral drilling locations.
We continue to see good consolidation opportunities to around our core areas. While we possess the financial and operational firepower to move quickly, we will remain disciplined with our acquisition strategy. The acquisitions we evaluate must compete with the best projects in our portfolio and strengthen our financial position. And we're willing to sell assets to high grade our portfolio and to fund transactions.
And importantly, our leverage ratio remains unchanged since late 2014 with $0.5 billion of cash on the balance sheet. This is a direct result of our fundamental strategy to focus on our asset quality, program returns, balance sheet and our team.
The most impactful later that we can affect the value of Concho is by becoming even more efficient. And we're focused on improving the productivity of each capital dollar invested. 2016 is an inflection point for capital efficiency. During the year, our average lateral length will increase by approximately 35% year-over-year and more than 50% of our operated drill wells will be on multi-well pad sites. We continue to optimize well results and returns by fine-tuning completion design for each core area and zone we're drilling. This inflection and capital efficiency also creates an inflection in production, which is demonstrated by our ability to hold production that from an all-time high in 2015 and it allows us to confidently project double-digit production growth in 2017 within cash flow.
This outlook remains unchanged. The strength of our machine is demonstrated by our longer-term view that at current strip pricing, we're capable of delivering differentiated annual production growth while continuing to spend within our cash flow, run a steady rig program and maintain a leverage ratio at/or below 2x.
We're working hard to deliver on our near-term objectives and position the company for your future. Our technical expertise and team facilitate the spread of innovation across our assets. We're uniquely positioned with 4 core areas to compete for capital within the Permian, which is the most robust and cost-efficient basin in North America. We are focused on making smart capital allocation decisions and keeping a strong financial position. The outlook for oil prices remains uncertain, but we've never been in a better position to deliver strong, profitable growth. This is our opportunity to extend our lead.
Thanks for listening and let me turn it back now to the moderator and take your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters
componenttext: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters and particularly this quarter in terms of oil rates adjusted for lateral length. And I want to see if you could comment a bit more on the decision to add rigs in the Midland Basin versus the northern Delaware Basin. You're drilling much longer laterals in the Midland Basin, but wanted to just presence as to is there differentiation in cost or expectations for future well performance that can justify adding activity there relative to ramping in the Northern Delaware.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the Northern Delaware hasn't changed. So 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, the Midland Basin we
componenttext: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the Northern Delaware hasn't changed. So 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, the Midland Basin we see is improving. There have been several efficiency breakthroughs from longer laterals and completion techniques and things like that. We think the Midland Basin properties are getting stronger because of those efficiencies and we'll compete with the northern Delaware Basin and -- we haven't really changed our capital allocation. We're just on a trajectory to wrap up capital in the Midland Basin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it, okay. And just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the environment? And is this the start of more quart
componenttext: Got it. Got it, okay. And just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the environment? And is this the start of more quarterly increases in activities as current oil prices level and higher oil prices play out?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about this is to stay steady as she goes. I don't think we're going to change our capital budget core or rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well h
componenttext: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about this is to stay steady as she goes. I don't think we're going to change our capital budget core or rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well hedged, that gives us some certainty around the amount of cash flow we're going to have from oil prices. So we'll continue the plan that we started at the first of the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Scialla of Stifel.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of cost? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as far
componenttext: Can you talk about just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of cost? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as far as an interference as far as impact on EURs going forward? Can you just address all those?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked about fr
componenttext: That's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked about from our wells, the maximum spacing we had in any of our inventories is 8[ph] across, although we're continuing to test downspacing ideas in all of our areas. And the downspacing testing is pretty high percentage of the total of what we're doing. But no, we wouldn't expect any from pad drilling, any change of interference or drainage or EURs or anything like that from what we've talked about in the past.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had somebody's wells that was pretty good production history, can we start talking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing this quarter's change in the composition of the will come y
componenttext: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had somebody's wells that was pretty good production history, can we start talking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing this quarter's change in the composition of the will come year 3 or 4 in these plays?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique and that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do so. It's a little bit easy a little bit different. But in general, all these zones have in
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique and that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do so. It's a little bit easy a little bit different. But in general, all these zones have increasing GORs over time, and that's kind of baked into our estimates for bot the recoveries and things like that. But we would expect GORs to go up over time.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, if I could just ask question out of your responses and you obviously made the indication that, that activities cannot be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a l
componenttext: Tim, if I could just ask question out of your responses and you obviously made the indication that, that activities cannot be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a little bit to this year, but kept the budget unchanged. So how did you evaluate and that was it more so that you're able to stay within your budget? And so you made a decision to put in some additional rigs? Or was it obviously the improvement in oil prices that also factored into that as well?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties is one
componenttext: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties is one factor. And then the other one is just from quarter-to-quarter kind of the net change and ownership that we have within the properties, that kind of what dictate more or less rigs based on how much capital we're spending. So I wouldn't read too much into that in terms of ramping up activity because of a higher oil prices that's not what really is going on, it's more just a blocking and tackling for these business.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and now the strip increased in. And can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that
componenttext: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and now the strip increased in. And can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that can be achieved? And one of the things that's pretty evident if you look at consents estimate out there right now, certainly it doesn't reflect that. Where do you think the disconnect is where The Street's modeling you versus what you think you can accomplish?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, an increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an efficie
componenttext: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, an increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an efficiency that's hard to model outside the company. And the tweaking of completion designs and optimization of these wells continue to provide growing efficiencies. When we have all those things together when we talk about that 2017, it's kind of based on the efficiency and the cost we know off today. And we can get to that double-digit growth based on what we know today. But also I'm pretty optimistic that with these increasing efficiencies that Concho's going to be able to really differentiate itself within cash flow.

componenttextpreview: I'd like to dispel that notion that we're primarily a Delaware Basin period. When we brought Hendry petroleum in back in 2008 and they were the first movers and recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So we
componenttext: I'd like to dispel that notion that we're primarily a Delaware Basin period. When we brought Hendry petroleum in back in 2008 and they were the first movers and recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So we inherited a lot of that knowledge expertise. I think we're an early mover over there. It's just been with kind of Delaware activity and everything we're doing in the Mexico of all that really good Midland Basin stuff just kind of got lost in the bigger picture. But I think we've got some of the best Midland Basin acreage that there is. Our well results compared with anything than anybody else's is turning out in the Midland Basin. And we now have completed the play so that you can run multirate pad drilling development kind of program. So we're ready to devote more capital there. When we come out of this cycle and things start growing rapidly again, I think it would be good for Concho to have multiple growth drivers. The last time we came through this growth cycle, the growth that the company was really driven by the northern Delaware Basin. I think next time, we'll have multiple growth drivers. I think there will be better a better diversified company.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the
componenttext: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the fluid faster. That was very expensive. And so as we've tried to optimize things, especially at lower oil prices, we'll put pumping units, mechanical pumping units on them earlier and move less fluid that kind of fattens the decline curve. It's not really choking them back, but it's controlling cost and not using as many sub pumps bumps.

componenttext: Yes. I think the Permian's in better shape than the other basins because the Permian seems to be the place right now that's all the equipment wants to come to. And we spoke about the rig count. The rig counts are at historic low right now, there's about 130 rigs. So there's a long way to go to add back equipment and people, even get back half way where we were 2 years ago. So I do think that in general, it will take the industry some time to respond to increased activity, but we need some increased activity just to get back to normal. So I think we have a lot of spare capacity right now and we're likely to have spare capacity for some time to come.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.Our first quarter earnings release and corpora
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our first quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements this morning. Also some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in both the earnings release and corporate presentation.
Thanks again. Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before I begin the first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before I begin the first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.
We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in the past 30 years. We responded with deep cuts to capital budgets. The U.S. rig count is in all-time low since we began keeping records. Meanwhile, the industry's leverage is at historic highs. Lower 48 oil production is set to decline by nearly 1 million barrels per day in 2016, according to EIA's current estimate.
Thinking about what's happened in our industry over the past 2 years, underinvestment and overstretched balance sheets, mixed with a growing global population, a decline in U.S. oil production and a service sector that's been cut to the bone. The long-term implications to the balance of supply and demand mean more volatility, not less. Amid the volatility, we're focused on aggressively managing the things we can control. Concho delivered another strong quarter and the contrast between the current environment and our results for the first quarter demonstrate our flexibility to respond to lower oil prices, protect our balance sheet, and sustain operating momentum.
Results this quarter also reflect our high-quality drilling inventory in the Permian Basin, which sits at the low end of the cost curve and continues to be one of the best basins for driving capital efficient growth and creating value for our shareholders. Our robust hedge position provides stability around our cash flows and combined with our strong portfolio, we're well-positioned to keep moving forward, investing in our assets and driving gains and productivity and efficiency. And while commodity prices have moved higher recently, we remain committed to a disciplined returns base capital program while spending within cash flow.
Now let me summarize some of the key achievements in the first quarter. Quarterly production increased 6% year-over-year and exceeded our guidance range. Our operating performance this quarter highlights the strength of our portfolio. Each core area is performing well. For full year 2016, we now expect production will be flat compared to 2015 and our capital plans unchanged.
We continue to make progress on our cost structure, combined unit cost, LOE and G&A were down 9% year-over-year. And importantly, we've reduced our full year outlook for LOE. Cost controls are a priority and they're set in the right direction. In addition, the Alpha Crude Connector system in New Mexico is improving our oil price realizations in the northern Delaware Basin. As a result, the guidance range for the pre-hedged oil differentials has improved.
For the third consecutive quarter, we understand operating cash flow, which excludes A&D. Spending within our means fortifies our balance sheet, and it's with this discipline that we find ourselves on a path to emerge stronger than when the cycle started.
Also during the first quarter we closed 2 transactions. The previously announced transactions include an acquisition of 12,000 net acres adjacent to our core North Harpoon prospect in the southern Delaware for a combined combination of equity, cash and drilling carry and the sale of 14,000 net acres in Loving County for cash proceeds. The net impact of these transactions added cash to the balance sheet, high graded our inventory and improved our returns base capital allocation program by freeing up capital to develop higher return properties.
Our strong balance sheet is a key advantage during periods of volatility. At quarter end, we had $0.5 billion of cash on our balance sheet and a net debt-to-EBITDAX ratio of 1.7x. We have substantial liquidity of $3 billion and our credit facility is undrawn. The total commitment level is $2.5 billion, which was recently reaffirmed by our lender group.
Turning now to our capital plan for 2016. Our plan to spend within cash flow remains unchanged and the capital guidance is still a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. And I don't have to say that our production is going to be down anymore because now we expect 2016 production to be just as robust as 2015. Our average expected rig count for the year is approximately 14. As we mentioned before during 2016, we plan to direct more capital to the Midland Basin, were consistently strong well results and good returns across several zones support our development plans.
Drilling more wells enhances our operational scale, expands our opportunity to test new ideas and accelerates development efficiencies. Our commitment to capital discipline is evident. The first quarter of 2016 represents the third consecutive quarter where cash flow exceeded our drilling expenditures. Since our rig count peaked in late 2014, development capital has been reduced 70%. Meanwhile production has grown 12% over that same time period and cash operating expenses are lower.
Lower commodity prices is great opportunities for Concho. We're actively managing our portfolio by consolidating core acreage and selling lower rate of return assets. The acquisition of 12,000 net acres in the southern Delaware Basin brings us new drilling locations that moved to the front of the inventory line. We closed this transaction in late March and shifted 2 rigs on to these properties in April. Acquisitions for assets like these are very competitive. The seller picked Concho as a partner based on our execution strength, and we like these asset because they increase our exposure to the best part of the southern Delaware Basin and add long lateral drilling locations.
We continue to see good consolidation opportunities around our core areas. While we possess the financial and operational firepower to move quickly, we will remain disciplined with our acquisition strategy. The acquisitions we evaluate must compete with the best projects in our portfolio and strengthen our financial position. And we're willing to sell assets to high grade our portfolio and to fund transactions.
And importantly, our leverage ratio remains unchanged since late 2014 with $0.5 billion of cash on the balance sheet. This is a direct result of our fundamental strategy to focus on our asset quality, program returns, balance sheet and our team.
The most impactful way that we can affect the value of Concho is by becoming even more efficient. And we're focused on improving the productivity of each capital dollar invested. 2016 is an inflection point for capital efficiency. During the year, our average lateral length will increase by approximately 35% year-over-year and more than 50% of our operated drill wells will be on multi-well pad sites. We continue to optimize well results and returns by fine-tuning completion design for each core area and zone we're drilling. This inflection and capital efficiency also creates an inflection in production, which is demonstrated by our ability to hold production flat from an all-time high in 2015 and it allows us to confidently project double-digit production growth in 2017 within cash flow.
This outlook remains unchanged. The strength of our machine is demonstrated by our longer-term view that at current strip pricing, we're capable of delivering differentiated annual production growth while continuing to spend within our cash flow, run a steady rig program and maintain a leverage ratio at/or below 2x.
We're working hard to deliver on our near-term objectives and position the company for the future. Our technical expertise and team facilitate the spread of innovation across our assets. We're uniquely positioned with 4 core areas to compete for capital within the Permian, which is the most robust and cost-efficient basin in North America. We are focused on making smart capital allocation decisions and keeping a strong financial position. The outlook for oil prices remains uncertain, but we've never been in a better position to deliver strong, profitable growth. This is our opportunity to extend our lead.
Thanks for listening and let me turn it back now to the moderator and take your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters
componenttext: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters and particularly this quarter in terms of oil rates adjusted for lateral length. And I wanted to see if you could comment a bit more on the decision to add rigs in the Midland Basin versus the northern Delaware Basin. You're drilling much longer laterals in the Midland Basin, but wanted to just get a sense as to, is there a differentiation in costs or expectations for future well performance that can justify adding activity there relative to ramping in the northern Delaware?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the northern Delaware hasn't changed still 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, the Midland Basin w
componenttext: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the northern Delaware hasn't changed still 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, the Midland Basin we see is improving. There have been several efficiency breakthroughs from longer laterals and completion techniques and things like that. We think the Midland Basin properties are getting stronger because of those efficiencies and we'll compete with the northern Delaware Basin and will -- we haven't really changed our capital allocation. We are just on a trajectory to ramp-up capital in the Midland Basin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the oil environment? And is this the start of a
componenttext: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the oil environment? And is this the start of a more quarterly increases in activity if current oil prices level and higher oil prices play out?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about us is steady as she goes. And I don't think that we're going to change our capital budget or our rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well hed
componenttext: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about us is steady as she goes. And I don't think that we're going to change our capital budget or our rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well hedged, that gives us some certainty around the amount of cash flow we're going to have from oil prices. So we'll continue the plan that we started at the first of the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Scialla of Stifel.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about -- just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of costs? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as
componenttext: Can you talk about -- just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of costs? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as far as any interference as far as impact on EURs going forward? Can you just address all those?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost, but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked ab
componenttext: Yes, that's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost, but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked about from our wells, is the maximum spacing we have on any of our inventories aid across, although we're continuing to test downspacing ideas in all of our areas. And the downspacing testing is a pretty high percentage of the total of what we're doing. But no, we wouldn't expect any -- from pad drilling, any change of interference or drainage or EURs or anything like that from what we've talked about in the past.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had some of these wells have a pretty good production history, can we start thinking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing as far as change in the composition of the well come year
componenttext: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had some of these wells have a pretty good production history, can we start thinking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing as far as change in the composition of the well come year 3, 4 in these plays?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique and that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do. So it's a little bit -- each zone is a little bit different. But in general, all these zo
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique and that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do. So it's a little bit -- each zone is a little bit different. But in general, all these zones have increasing GORs over time, and that's kind of baked into our estimates of ultimate recoveries and things like that. But you would expect the GORs to go up over time.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, if I could just ask a question of one of your responses and you obviously made the indication that activity is not to be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a l
componenttext: Tim, if I could just ask a question of one of your responses and you obviously made the indication that activity is not to be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a little bit this year, but kept the budget unchanged. So how did you evaluate that? Was it more so that you're able to stay within your budget and so you made a decision to put in some additional rigs? Or was it obviously the improvement in oil prices that also factored into that as well?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So that adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties it
componenttext: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So that adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties it is one factor. And then the other one is just from quarter-to-quarter kind of the net change in ownership that we have within the properties, that kind of what dictate more or less rigs based on how much capital we're spending. So I wouldn't read too much into that in terms of ramping up activity because of a higher oil price, that's not what really is going on, it's more just a blocking and tackling of our base business.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and now the strip increased and can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that can
componenttext: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and now the strip increased and can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that can be achieved? And one of the things that's pretty evident, if you look at consensus estimate out there right now, certainly it doesn't reflect that. Where do you think the disconnect is where the Street's modeling you all versus what you think you can accomplish?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, the increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an effici
componenttext: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, the increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an efficiency that's hard to model outside the company. And the tweaking of completion designs and optimization of these wells continue to provide growing efficiencies that when we stew all those things together -- when we talk about 2017, it's kind of based on the efficiency and the cost we know off today. And we can get to that double-digit growth based on what we know today. But also I'm pretty optimistic that with these increasing efficiencies that Concho is going to be able to really differentiate itself within cash flow.

componenttext: Yes, we're comfortable with what we've come out with before on that, John. So the short answer is, yes, we're still very optimistic about the Avalon and that area.

componenttext: Yes. I really -- I mean, the impact of that property trade for our company was a pretty large impact. Landing them both at the same timing and closing 2 deals on the same day, or announcing 2 deals on the same day is a little bit of a trick. But in general, as we progress through the year, continuing to consolidate Tier 1 core acreage and selloff stuff that is further out in the queue, the drilling queue is kind of an activity that I'm hopeful we continue to see.

componenttext: Say, Tim's notable again when I look at sort of in the press release, the 30-day results when you breakdown for the north and the south. Or I guess, as we go forward, I am just -- we get pleasant surprise to how much now that the south is right in line now with the north when you kind of see those 30-day peak averages.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, right now the north is a lot bigger than the south. We've had good results from second Bone Spring, Avalon and Wolfcamp in the north and primarily what we're doing in the south is Wolfcamp. So I think that we'll be expanding, but we're very pleased with the performance of the North Harpoon area in the southern Delaware Basin that completes with anything we're doing in the northern Delaware. And as we stated, we think that the efficiencies will continue to drive cost lower and production higher. So we like both those areas.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just in terms of reallocating at least some rig activity to the Midland Basin. And, obviously, you're shifting to longer laterals here. What are your thoughts? I mean, obviously you've been more of a Delaware Basin player throughout the c
componenttext: Okay, great. And just in terms of reallocating at least some rig activity to the Midland Basin. And, obviously, you're shifting to longer laterals here. What are your thoughts? I mean, obviously you've been more of a Delaware Basin player throughout the company's history. What are your initial views on the longer laterals and potentially even -- get even more active in the Midland Basin if oil prices surprise to the upside?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to dispel that notion that we've primarily a Delaware Basin player. I mean we bought Henry Petroleum back in 2008 and they were one of the first movers in recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So
componenttext: I'd like to dispel that notion that we've primarily a Delaware Basin player. I mean we bought Henry Petroleum back in 2008 and they were one of the first movers in recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So we inherited a lot of that knowledge expertise. I think we're an early mover over there. It's just been -- it kind of -- with all of our Delaware activity and everything we're doing in New Mexico, of that really good Midland Basin stuff just kind of got lost in the bigger picture. But I think we've got some of the best Midland Basin acreage that there is. Our well results compare with anything that anybody else is turning out in the Midland Basin. And we now have completed the hidden play so that you can run a multi-rig pad drilling development kind of program. So we're ready to devote more capital there. When we come out of this cycle and things start growing rapidly again, I think it would be good for Concho to have multiple growth drivers. The last time we came through this growth cycle, the growth of the company was really driven by the northern Delaware Basin. I think next time, we'll have multiple growth drivers. I think there will be a better more diversified company.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are several legs to the stool. And just quickly in the Midland Basin, how much acreage, Tim, do you think you have in the core?
componenttext: There are several legs to the stool. And just quickly in the Midland Basin, how much acreage, Tim, do you think you have in the core?

componenttext: Arun, we've got 110,000 net acres and we like the great majority of it.

componenttext: Heikkinen Energy. Similarly, lateral lengths aren't quite at 7,000 on average cost of the program in the first quarter. Should we think about the back half as having higher levels relative to the averages for rig counts in lateral lengths? And if so, does that then just continue forward into 2017?

componenttext: Yes is the answer to all those questions. The lateral length, the longer later length is primarily coming from the Midland Basin in the southern Delaware Basin, and that's where we just really put the rigs on.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just think about productivity across all the areas, it looked quite strong relative to lateral lengths. Is there any reason to think that, those levels aren't sustainable or repeatable over the long-term in the next several
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just think about productivity across all the areas, it looked quite strong relative to lateral lengths. Is there any reason to think that, those levels aren't sustainable or repeatable over the long-term in the next several years given your current inventory?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I hope they get better. That's -- one thing you're kind of dealing with the longer laterals though is just the mechanical ability to move that much fluid out of a 2-mile lateral. So I think as the industry goes to longer and longer wells, the initial 24-h
componenttext: I hope they get better. That's -- one thing you're kind of dealing with the longer laterals though is just the mechanical ability to move that much fluid out of a 2-mile lateral. So I think as the industry goes to longer and longer wells, the initial 24-hour, 30-day rates aren't going to move as much as the 60- and 90-day rates because these wells in the first initial days, you just can't make that much more fluid out of a size hole, but I think they'll hold up better and you'll get better economics.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Smith of Bank of America.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you guys completed more wells than you've drilled this quarter. So just curious where is the duck backlog today? And I guess, you guys have typically highlighted a 2x recount as a target, does that still hold as you shift more towards pad drilling?
componenttext: So you guys completed more wells than you've drilled this quarter. So just curious where is the duck backlog today? And I guess, you guys have typically highlighted a 2x recount as a target, does that still hold as you shift more towards pad drilling?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our duck inventories are down to about 30. And general because of the conditions have changed a little bit, there is not as much tightness in the supply for frac spreads. So I don't -- the balance of inventory of wells weighted on being completed and
componenttext: Yes, our duck inventories are down to about 30. And general because of the conditions have changed a little bit, there is not as much tightness in the supply for frac spreads. So I don't -- the balance of inventory of wells weighted on being completed and wells drilling, I don't think you need quite as many wells waiting on completion as you had in the past. There's more flexibility in the system because of excess capacity of frac spreads.

componenttext: It's just basis of partners joining or not joining in the wells and our net interest on those wells at this point in time.

componenttext: Yes, well, I think that our long-term strategy that we've had works well in cycles like this, that the way we think about our balance sheet and our leverage and our activity. And I think what's going to differentiate Concho going forward is our ability to grow within cash flow. And so when you compare us to other companies, I think our growth will be differentiated or better. And we'll be drilling within cash flow while others will probably be out spending the cash flow.

componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick questions, just to go back to a prior comment you guys have made regarding the longer laterals and the rates to 30 days, 60 and 90 days. Have you guys yet experimented with choking back the longer laterals? You probably haven't needed to do t
componenttext: Just 2 quick questions, just to go back to a prior comment you guys have made regarding the longer laterals and the rates to 30 days, 60 and 90 days. Have you guys yet experimented with choking back the longer laterals? You probably haven't needed to do this yet, but just thinking about better managing infrastructure needs for the kind of the very high initial rates?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the
componenttext: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the fluid faster, that was very expensive. And so as we've tried to optimize things, especially at lower oil prices, we'll put pumping units, mechanical pumping units on them earlier and move less fluid that kind of fattens the decline curve. So it's not really choking them back, but it's controlling cost and not using as many sub pumps.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, I was just curious when you look at the Permian as oil prices normalize, [indiscernible] activity comes back into the basin. And how quickly do you think the service companies can respond? I know that we have a lot of equipment, but what about people
componenttext: Tim, I was just curious when you look at the Permian as oil prices normalize, [indiscernible] activity comes back into the basin. And how quickly do you think the service companies can respond? I know that we have a lot of equipment, but what about people? Given how many people have left the industry? Or is the Permian in good shape? Because there's been a lot of people and equipment have moved to that area.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the Permian is in better shape than the other basins because the Permian seems to be the place right now that all the equipment wants to come to. And we spoke about the rig count. The rig counts are at historic low right now, with about 130 r
componenttext: Yes. I think the Permian is in better shape than the other basins because the Permian seems to be the place right now that all the equipment wants to come to. And we spoke about the rig count. The rig counts are at historic low right now, with about 130 rigs. So there's a long way to go to add back equipment and people, even to get back half way to where we were 2 years ago. So I do think that in general, it will take the industry some time to respond to increased activity, but we need some increased activity just to get back to normal. So I think we have a lot of spare capacity right now and we're likely to have spare capacity for some time to come.
