headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.Our first quarter earnings release and corpora
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our first quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements this morning. Also some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in both the earnings release and corporate presentation.
Thanks again. Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before we get into first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before we get into first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.
We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in the past 30 years. We've responded with deep cuts to capital budgets. The U.S. rig count is in all-time low since we began keeping records. Meanwhile, the industry's leverage is at historic highs. Lower 48 oil production is set to decline by nearly 1 million barrels per day in 2016, according to EIA's current estimate.
Think about what's happened in our industry over the past 2 years, underinvestment and overstretched balance sheets, mixed with a growing global population, a decline in U.S. oil production and a service sector that's been cut to the bone. The long-term implications to the balance of supply and demand mean more volatility, not less. Amid the volatility, we're focused on aggressively managing the things we can control. Concho delivered another strong quarter and the contrast between the current environment and our results for the first quarter demonstrate our flexibility to respond to low oil prices, protect our balance sheet, and sustain operating momentum.
Results this quarter also reflect our high-quality drilling inventory in the Permian Basin, which sits at the low end of the cost curve and continues to be one of the best basins for driving capital efficient growth and creating value for our shareholders. Our robust hedge position provides stability around our cash flows and combined with our strong portfolio, we're well-positioned to keep moving forward, investing in our assets and driving gains and productivity and efficiency. And while commodity prices have moved higher recently, we remain committed to a disciplined returns base capital program while spending within cash flow.
Now let me summarize some of the key achievements in the first quarter. Quarterly production increased 6% year-over-year and exceeded our guidance range. Our operating performance this quarter highlights the strength of our portfolio. Each core area is performing well. For full year 2016, we now expect production will be flat compared to 2015 and our capital plans unchanged.
We continue to make progress on our cost structure, combined unit cost, LOE and G&A were down 9% year-over-year. And importantly, we reduced our full year outlook for LOE. Cost control's a priority and it's headed in the right direction. In addition, the Alpha Crude Connector system in New Mexico is improving our oil price realizations in the northern Delaware Basin. As a result, the guidance range for the pre-hedge oil differentials has improved.
For the third consecutive quarter, we under spent operating cash flow, which excludes A&D. Spending within our means fortifies the balance sheet, and it's with this discipline that we find ourselves on a path to emerge stronger than when the cycle started.
Also during the first quarter we closed 2 transactions. The previously announced transactions include an acquisition of 12,000 net acres adjacent to our core North Harpoon prospect in the southern Delaware for a combination of equity, cash and drilling carry and the sale of 14,000 net acres in Loving County for cash proceeds. The net impact of these transactions added cash to the balance sheet, high graded our inventory and improved our returns base capital allocation program by freeing up capital to develop higher return properties.
Our strong balance sheet is a key advantage during periods of volatility. At quarter end, we had $0.5 billion of cash on our balance sheet and a net debt-to-EBITDAX ratio of 1.7x. We have substantial liquidity of $3 billion and our credit facility is undrawn. The total commitment level is $2.5 billion, which was recently reaffirmed by our lender group.
Turning now to our capital plan for 2016. Our plan to spend within cash flow remains unchanged and the capital guidance is still a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. And I don't have to say that our production is going to be down anymore because now we expect 2016 production to be just as robust as 2015. Our average expected rig count for the year is approximately 14. As we mentioned before, during 2016 we plan to direct more capital to the Midland Basin, were consistently strong well results and good returns across several zones support our development plans.
Drilling more wells enhances our operational scale, expands our opportunity to test new ideas and accelerates development efficiencies. Our commitment to capital discipline is evident. The first quarter of 2016 represents the third consecutive quarter where cash flow exceeded our drilling expenditures. Since our rig count peaked in late 2014, development capital has been reduced 70%. Meanwhile production's grown 12% over that same time period and cash operating expenses are lower.
Lower commodity prices create opportunities for Concho. We're actively managing our portfolio by consolidating core acreage and selling lower rate of return assets. The acquisition of 12,000 net acres in the southern Delaware Basin brings us new drilling locations that moved to the front of the inventory line. We closed this transaction in late March and shifted 2 rigs on to these properties in April. Acquisitions for assets like these are very competitive. The seller picked Concho as a partner based on our execution strength, and we like these asset because they increase our exposure to the best part of the southern Delaware Basin and add long lateral drilling locations.
We continue to see good consolidation opportunities around our core areas. While we possess the financial and operational firepower to move quickly, we will remain disciplined with our acquisition strategy. The acquisitions we evaluate must compete with the best projects in our portfolio and strengthen our financial position. And we're willing to sell assets to high grade our portfolio and to fund transactions.
And importantly, our leverage ratio remains unchanged since late 2014 with $0.5 billion of cash on the balance sheet. This is a direct result of our fundamental strategy to focus on our asset quality, program returns, balance sheet and our team.
The most impactful way that we can affect the value of Concho is by becoming even more efficient. And we're focused on improving the productivity of each capital dollar invested. 2016 is an inflection point for capital efficiency. During the year, our average lateral length will increase by approximately 35% year-over-year and more than 50% of our operated drill wells will be on multi-well pad sites. We continue to optimize well results and returns by fine-tuning completion design for each core area and zone we're drilling. This inflection and capital efficiency also creates an inflection in production, which is demonstrated by our ability to hold production flat from an all-time high in 2015 and it allows us to confidently project double-digit production growth in 2017 within cash flow.
This outlook remains unchanged. The strength of our machine is demonstrated by our longer-term view that at current strip pricing, we're capable of delivering differentiated annual production growth while continuing to spend within our cash flow, run a steady rig program and maintain a leverage ratio at/or below 2x.
We're working hard to deliver on our near-term objectives and position the company for the future. Our technical expertise and team facilitate the spread of innovation across our assets. We're uniquely positioned with 4 core areas to compete for capital within the Permian, which is the most robust and cost-efficient basin in North America. We are focused on making smart capital allocation decisions and keeping a strong financial position. The outlook for oil prices remains uncertain, but we've never been in a better position to deliver strong, profitable growth. This is our opportunity to extend our lead.
Thanks for listening and let me turn it back now to the moderator and take your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters
componenttext: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters and particularly this quarter in terms of oil rates adjusted for lateral length. And I wanted to see if you could comment a bit more on the decision to add rigs in the Midland Basin versus the northern Delaware Basin. You're drilling much longer laterals in the Midland Basin, but wanted to just get a sense as to, is there a differentiation in costs or expectations for future well performance that can justify adding activity there relative to ramping in the northern Delaware?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital that we're, as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the northern Delaware hasn't changed. It's still 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, t
componenttext: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital that we're, as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the northern Delaware hasn't changed. It's still 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, the Midland Basin we see as improving. There have been several efficiency breakthroughs from longer laterals and completion techniques and things like that. We think the Midland Basin properties are getting stronger because of those efficiencies and will compete with the northern Delaware Basin and we will -- we haven't really changed our capital allocation. We are just on a trajectory to ramp-up capital in the Midland Basin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the oil environment? And is this the start of a
componenttext: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the oil environment? And is this the start of a more quarterly increases in activity if current oil prices level and higher oil prices play out?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about us is steady as she goes. And I don't think that we're going to change our capital budget or our rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well hed
componenttext: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about us is steady as she goes. And I don't think that we're going to change our capital budget or our rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well hedged, that gives us some certainty around the amount of cash flow we're going to have from oil prices. So we'll continue the plan that we started at the first of the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Scialla of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Scialla of Stifel.

componenttext: Tim, you had mentioned I think you said 50% of your drilling this year was on pads. Just as you look into next year, trying to get a sense of where you think that will be? Do you go more towards development? Or is there more delineation still to be done?

componenttext: I think as we continue to roll forward in a normal environment, it's going to become more and more development like, so I would expect that number to do nothing, but go up.

componenttext: Mike, it's Jack. There really was no change that would have caused that, it's just kind of well location.

componenttext: Okay. And then just last one for me. It look like you had some pretty positive results on the stack laterals in the Wolfcamp A and B in the Midland. Any implications for your drilling inventory there? Or was that already kind of baked in?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about -- just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of costs? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as
componenttext: Can you talk about -- just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of costs? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as far as any interference as far as impact on EURs going forward? Can you just address all those?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost, but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked ab
componenttext: Yes, that's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost, but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked about from our wells, is the maximum spacing we have on any of our inventories, 8 across, although we're continuing to test downspacing ideas in all of our areas. And the downspacing testing is a pretty high percentage of the total of what we're doing. But no, we wouldn't expect any -- from pad drilling, any change of interference or drainage or EURs or anything like that from what we've talked about in the past.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had some of these wells have a pretty good production history, can we start thinking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing as far as change in the composition of the well come year
componenttext: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had some of these wells have a pretty good production history, can we start thinking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing as far as change in the composition of the well come year 3, 4 in these plays?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique in that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do. So it's a little bit -- each zone is a little bit different. But in general, all these zon
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique in that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do. So it's a little bit -- each zone is a little bit different. But in general, all these zones have increasing GORs over time, and that's kind of baked into our estimates of ultimate recoveries and things like that. But you would expect the GORs to go up over time.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, if I could just ask a question off one of your responses and you obviously made the indication that activity is not to be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a
componenttext: Tim, if I could just ask a question off one of your responses and you obviously made the indication that activity is not to be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a little bit this year, but kept the budget unchanged. So how did you evaluate that? Was it more so that you're able to stay within your budget and so you made a decision to put in some additional rigs? Or was it obviously the improvement in oil prices that also factored into that as well?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So that adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties it
componenttext: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So that adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties it is one factor. And then the other one is just from quarter-to-quarter kind of the net change in ownership that we have within the properties, that kind of would dictate more or less rigs based on how much capital we're spending. So I wouldn't read too much into that in terms of ramping up activity because of a higher oil price, that's not what really is going on, it's more just a blocking and tackling of our base business.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and how the strip increased and can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that can
componenttext: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and how the strip increased and can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that can be achieved? And one of the things that's pretty evident, if you look at consensus estimate out there right now, certainly it doesn't reflect that. Where do you think the disconnect is where the Street's modeling you all versus what you think you can accomplish?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, the increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an effici
componenttext: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, the increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an efficiency that's hard to model outside the company. And the tweaking of completion designs and optimization of these wells continue to provide growing efficiencies that when we stew all those things together -- when we talk about 2017, it's kind of based on the efficiency and the cost we know off today. And we can get to that double-digit growth based on what we know today. But also I'm pretty optimistic that with these increasing efficiencies that Concho is going to be able to really differentiate itself within cash flow.

componenttext: Yes. I really -- I mean, the impact of that property trade for our company was a pretty large impact. Landing them both at the same timing and closing 2 deals on the same day, or announcing 2 deals on the same day is a little bit of a trick. But in general, as we progress through the year, continuing to consolidate Tier 1 core acreage and selloff stuff that is further out in the queue, the drilling queue is kind of an activity that I'm hope we'll continue to see.

componenttext: Say, Tim, it's notable again when I look at sort of in the press release, the 30-day results when you breakdown for the north and the south. Obviously, north remains strong, but now even the southern continue. Could you maybe give your thoughts on, do you see both of those sort of continuing to trend in line? Or I guess, as we go forward, I am just -- we get pleasant surprised how much now that the south is now right in line now with the north when you kind of see those 30-day peak averages.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, right now the north is a lot bigger than the south. We've had good results from second Bone Spring, Avalon and Wolfcamp in the north and primarily what we're doing in the south is Wolfcamp. So I think that we'll be expanding, but we're very p
componenttext: Yes. I mean, right now the north is a lot bigger than the south. We've had good results from second Bone Spring, Avalon and Wolfcamp in the north and primarily what we're doing in the south is Wolfcamp. So I think that we'll be expanding, but we're very pleased with the performance of the North Harpoon area in the southern Delaware Basin. It completes with anything we're doing in the northern Delaware. And as we've stated, we think that their efficiencies will continue to drive cost lower and production higher. So we like both those areas.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Well, the Avalon oil is just as -- I mean, the rates of return, the productivity, the prospectivity is just as good as anything we have. We're really high on it.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just in terms of reallocating or least some rig activity to the Midland Basin. And, obviously, you're shifting to longer laterals here. What are your thoughts? I mean, obviously you've been more of a Delaware Basin player throughout the c
componenttext: Okay, great. And just in terms of reallocating or least some rig activity to the Midland Basin. And, obviously, you're shifting to longer laterals here. What are your thoughts? I mean, obviously you've been more of a Delaware Basin player throughout the company's history. What are your initial views on the longer laterals and potentially even -- get even more active in the Midland Basin if oil prices surprise to the upside?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to dispel that notion that we've primarily a Delaware Basin player. I mean we bought Henry Petroleum back in 2008 and they were one of the first movers in recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So
componenttext: I'd like to dispel that notion that we've primarily a Delaware Basin player. I mean we bought Henry Petroleum back in 2008 and they were one of the first movers in recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So we inherited a lot of that knowledge, expertise. I think we're an early mover over there. It's just been -- it kind of -- with all of our Delaware activity and everything we're doing in New Mexico, all that really good Midland Basin stuff just kind of got lost in the bigger picture. But I think we've got some of the best Midland Basin acreage that there is. Our well results compare with anything that anybody else is turning out in the Midland Basin. And we now have completed the Midland [ph] play so that you can run a multi-rig pad drilling development kind of program. So we're ready to devote more capital there. When we come out of this cycle and things start growing rapidly again, I think it would be good for Concho to have multiple growth drivers. The last time we came through this growth cycle, the growth of the company was really driven by the northern Delaware Basin. I think next time, we'll have multiple growth drivers. I think there will be a better, more diversified company.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are several legs to the stool. And just quickly in the Midland Basin, how much acreage, Tim, do you think you have in the core?
componenttext: There are several legs to the stool. And just quickly in the Midland Basin, how much acreage, Tim, do you think you have in the core?

componenttext: Heikkinen Energy. Similarly, lateral lengths aren't quite at 7,000 on average across of the program in the first quarter. Should we think about the back half as having higher levels relative to the averages for rig counts in lateral lengths? And if so, does that then just continue forward into 2017?

componenttext: Yes, is the answer to all those questions. The lateral length, the longer later length is primarily coming from the Midland Basin and the southern Delaware Basin, and that's where we just really put the rigs on.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just think about productivity across all the areas, it looked quite strong relative to lateral lengths. Is there any reason to think that, those levels aren't sustainable or repeatable over the long-term in the next several
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just think about productivity across all the areas, it looked quite strong relative to lateral lengths. Is there any reason to think that, those levels aren't sustainable or repeatable over the long-term in the next several years given your current inventory?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I hope they get better. That's -- one thing you're kind of dealing with the longer laterals though is just the mechanical ability to move that much fluid out of a 2-mile lateral. So I think as the industry goes to longer and longer wells, the initial
componenttext: No, I hope they get better. That's -- one thing you're kind of dealing with the longer laterals though is just the mechanical ability to move that much fluid out of a 2-mile lateral. So I think as the industry goes to longer and longer wells, the initial 24-hour, 30-day rates aren't going to move as much as the 60- and 90-day rates because these wells in the first initial days, you just can't make that much more fluid out of that size hole, but I think they'll hold up better and you'll get better economics.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason Smith of Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason Smith of Bank of America.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you guys completed more wells than you've drilled this quarter. So just curious where is the DUC backlog today? And I guess, you guys have typically highlighted a 2x recount as a target, does that still hold as you shift more towards pad drilling?
componenttext: So you guys completed more wells than you've drilled this quarter. So just curious where is the DUC backlog today? And I guess, you guys have typically highlighted a 2x recount as a target, does that still hold as you shift more towards pad drilling?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, our DUC inventory is down to about 30. And general because of the conditions have changed a little bit, there is not as much tightness in the supply for frac spreads. So I don't -- the balance of inventory of wells waited on being completed and wells
componenttext: Yes, our DUC inventory is down to about 30. And general because of the conditions have changed a little bit, there is not as much tightness in the supply for frac spreads. So I don't -- the balance of inventory of wells waited on being completed and wells drilling, I don't think you need quite as many wells waiting on completion as you had in the past. There's more flexibility in the system because of excess capacity of frac spreads.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one quick follow-up on the Midland and capital allocation, it looks like CapEx is not increasing as a percent of the total for the year within the Midland, despite guiding the raise. Can you just maybe help us reconcile why that is?
componenttext: And one quick follow-up on the Midland and capital allocation, it looks like CapEx is not increasing as a percent of the total for the year within the Midland, despite guiding the raise. Can you just maybe help us reconcile why that is?

componenttext: It's just basis of partners joining or not joining in the wells and our net interest on those wells at this point in time.

componenttext: Yes. So as we've said in the past, we've come down significantly from '15 to '16. And going from '16 to '17, there may be some modest shallowing in that decline curve, but not anything comparable to the change between '15 and '16.

componenttext: Okay. And then on the longer-term comments about growth combining with the likelihood for continued volatility in crude. How do you balance those goals? And is there any additional specific detail you can provide on, on which your view differentiated production growth could imply?

componenttext: I'm sorry, could you try that again?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just trying to balance out comments that crude will continue to see volatility going forward, yet you continue to focus on differentiated growth. Looking at what could differentiated growth imply as well as how do you respond to increased volatility in cr
componenttext: Just trying to balance out comments that crude will continue to see volatility going forward, yet you continue to focus on differentiated growth. Looking at what could differentiated growth imply as well as how do you respond to increased volatility in crude when you are trying to grow?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I think that our long-term strategy that we've had works well in cycles like this, that the way we think about our balance sheet and our leverage and our activity. And I think what's going to differentiate Concho going forward is our ability to
componenttext: Yes, well, I think that our long-term strategy that we've had works well in cycles like this, that the way we think about our balance sheet and our leverage and our activity. And I think what's going to differentiate Concho going forward is our ability to grow within cash flow. And so when you compare us to other companies, I think our growth will be differentiated or better. And we'll be drilling within cash flow while others will probably be out spending their cash flow.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Sullivan of Alembic Global.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Sullivan of Alembic Global.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick questions, just to go back to a prior comment you guys had made regarding the longer laterals and the rates to 30 days, 60 day and 90 rates. Have you guys yet experimented with choking back the longer laterals? You probably haven't needed to
componenttext: Just 2 quick questions, just to go back to a prior comment you guys had made regarding the longer laterals and the rates to 30 days, 60 day and 90 rates. Have you guys yet experimented with choking back the longer laterals? You probably haven't needed to do this yet, but just thinking about better managing infrastructure needs for the kind of the very high initial rates?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the
componenttext: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the fluid faster, that was very expensive. And so as we've tried to optimize things, especially at lower oil prices, we'll put pumping units, mechanical pumping units on them earlier and move less fluid, but it kind of fattens the decline curve. So it's not really choking them back, but it's controlling cost and not using as many sub pumps.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Just last quick kind of modeling integrated question, I did notice you guys made another contribution to the JV this quarter. Can you just remind me -- I know it's normal business to talk about this, but what the pace of ACC contributions are
componenttext: Okay, great. Just last quick kind of modeling integrated question, I did notice you guys made another contribution to the JV this quarter. Can you just remind me -- I know it's normal business to talk about this, but what the pace of ACC contributions are likely to be going forward? I think you guys had said that, you guys will be funding incremental additions. But I just want to see what those will likely to be as we're going forward for modeling purposes?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Sure. The pace will slow down markedly and we're going to stay consistent with the budget that we laid out in beginning of the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. So is there a total number that you guys are budgeting just for that particular budget line this year? Or is that -- I just [indiscernible] in my notes here?

componenttext: Yes. It's again consistent with the 10%. It's embedded in that 10% of nondrilling and completion capital in the budget. And I don't believe we broke it out beyond that.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pearce Hammond of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, I was just curious when you look at the Permian as oil prices normalize with hiring, activity comes back into the basin. And how quickly do you think the service companies can respond? I know that we have a lot of equipment, but what about people? Gi
componenttext: Tim, I was just curious when you look at the Permian as oil prices normalize with hiring, activity comes back into the basin. And how quickly do you think the service companies can respond? I know that we have a lot of equipment, but what about people? Given how many people have left the industry? Or is the Permian in good shape because there's been a lot of people and equipment have moved to that area.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the Permian is in better shape than the other basins because the Permian seems to be the place right now that all the equipment wants to come to. And we spoke about the rig count. The rig count's at historic low right now, to about 130 rigs.
componenttext: Yes. I think the Permian is in better shape than the other basins because the Permian seems to be the place right now that all the equipment wants to come to. And we spoke about the rig count. The rig count's at historic low right now, to about 130 rigs. So there's a long way to go to add back equipment and people, even to get back half way to where we were 2 years ago. So I do think that in general, it will take the industry some time to respond to increased activity, but we need some increased activity just to get back to normal. So I think we have a lot of spare capacity right now and we're likely to have spare capacity for some time to come.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm showing no further questions at this time. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Tim Leach for any closing remarks.
componenttext: I'm showing no further questions at this time. I'd like to turn the conference back over to Tim Leach for any closing remarks.

componenttext: All right. Thank you once again. I know it's a busy morning. I appreciate you dialing in to the Concho call. It was really good quarter. We look forward to talking to you again at the end of the second quarter and thanks again for your interest in Concho.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. 2016 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference may be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host Ms. Megan Hays. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.Our first quarter earnings release and corpora
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our first quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements this morning. Also some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in both the earnings release and corporate presentation.
Thanks again. Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before we get into first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. Before we get into first quarter results, I want to talk about the current business environment for our industry.
We're operating in one of the toughest commodity price cycles we've experienced in the past 30 years. We've responded with deep cuts to capital budgets. The U.S. rig count is in all-time low since we began keeping records. Meanwhile, the industry's leverage is at historic highs. Lower 48 oil production is set to decline by nearly 1 million barrels per day in 2016, according to EIA's current estimate.
Think about what's happened in our industry over the past 2 years, underinvestment and overstretched balance sheets, mixed with a growing global population, a decline in U.S. oil production and a service sector that's been cut to the bone. The long-term implications to the balance of supply and demand mean more volatility, not less. Amid the volatility, we're focused on aggressively managing the things we can control. Concho delivered another strong quarter and the contrast between the current environment and our results for the first quarter demonstrate our flexibility to respond to low oil prices, protect our balance sheet, and sustain operating momentum.
Results this quarter also reflect our high-quality drilling inventory in the Permian Basin, which sits at the low end of the cost curve and continues to be one of the best basins for driving capital efficient growth and creating value for our shareholders. Our robust hedge position provides stability around our cash flows and combined with our strong portfolio, we're well-positioned to keep moving forward, investing in our assets and driving gains and productivity and efficiency. And while commodity prices have moved higher recently, we remain committed to a disciplined returns base capital program while spending within cash flow.
Now let me summarize some of the key achievements in the first quarter. Quarterly production increased 6% year-over-year and exceeded our guidance range. Our operating performance this quarter highlights the strength of our portfolio. Each core area is performing well. For full year 2016, we now expect production will be flat compared to 2015 and our capital plans unchanged.
We continue to make progress on our cost structure, combined unit cost, LOE and G&A were down 9% year-over-year. And importantly, we reduced our full year outlook for LOE. Cost control's a priority and it's headed in the right direction. In addition, the Alpha Crude Connector system in New Mexico is improving our oil price realizations in the northern Delaware Basin. As a result, the guidance range for the pre-hedge oil differentials has improved.
For the third consecutive quarter, we under spent operating cash flow, which excludes A&D. Spending within our means fortifies the balance sheet, and it's with this discipline that we find ourselves on a path to emerge stronger than when the cycle started.
Also during the first quarter we closed 2 transactions. The previously announced transactions include an acquisition of 12,000 net acres adjacent to our core North Harpoon prospect in the southern Delaware for a combination of equity, cash and drilling carry and the sale of 14,000 net acres in Loving County for cash proceeds. The net impact of these transactions added cash to the balance sheet, high graded our inventory and improved our returns base capital allocation program by freeing up capital to develop higher return properties.
Our strong balance sheet is a key advantage during periods of volatility. At quarter end, we had $0.5 billion of cash on our balance sheet and a net debt-to-EBITDAX ratio of 1.7x. We have substantial liquidity of $3 billion and our credit facility is undrawn. The total commitment level is $2.5 billion, which was recently reaffirmed by our lender group.
Turning now to our capital plan for 2016. Our plan to spend within cash flow remains unchanged and the capital guidance is still a range of $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion. And I don't have to say that our production is going to be down anymore because now we expect 2016 production to be just as robust as 2015. Our average expected rig count for the year is approximately 14. As we mentioned before, during 2016 we plan to direct more capital to the Midland Basin, were consistently strong well results and good returns across several zones support our development plans.
Drilling more wells enhances our operational scale, expands our opportunity to test new ideas and accelerates development efficiencies. Our commitment to capital discipline is evident. The first quarter of 2016 represents the third consecutive quarter where cash flow exceeded our drilling expenditures. Since our rig count peaked in late 2014, development capital has been reduced 70%. Meanwhile production's grown 12% over that same time period and cash operating expenses are lower.
Lower commodity prices create opportunities for Concho. We're actively managing our portfolio by consolidating core acreage and selling lower rate of return assets. The acquisition of 12,000 net acres in the southern Delaware Basin brings us new drilling locations that moved to the front of the inventory line. We closed this transaction in late March and shifted 2 rigs on to these properties in April. Acquisitions for assets like these are very competitive. The seller picked Concho as a partner based on our execution strength, and we like these asset because they increase our exposure to the best part of the southern Delaware Basin and add long lateral drilling locations.
We continue to see good consolidation opportunities around our core areas. While we possess the financial and operational firepower to move quickly, we will remain disciplined with our acquisition strategy. The acquisitions we evaluate must compete with the best projects in our portfolio and strengthen our financial position. And we're willing to sell assets to high grade our portfolio and to fund transactions.
And importantly, our leverage ratio remains unchanged since late 2014 with $0.5 billion of cash on the balance sheet. This is a direct result of our fundamental strategy to focus on our asset quality, program returns, balance sheet and our team.
The most impactful way that we can affect the value of Concho is by becoming even more efficient. And we're focused on improving the productivity of each capital dollar invested. 2016 is an inflection point for capital efficiency. During the year, our average lateral length will increase by approximately 35% year-over-year and more than 50% of our operated drill wells will be on multi-well pad sites. We continue to optimize well results and returns by fine-tuning completion design for each core area and zone we're drilling. This inflection and capital efficiency also creates an inflection in production, which is demonstrated by our ability to hold production flat from an all-time high in 2015 and it allows us to confidently project double-digit production growth in 2017 within cash flow.
This outlook remains unchanged. The strength of our machine is demonstrated by our longer-term view that at current strip pricing, we're capable of delivering differentiated annual production growth while continuing to spend within our cash flow, run a steady rig program and maintain a leverage ratio at/or below 2x.
We're working hard to deliver on our near-term objectives and position the company for the future. Our technical expertise and team facilitate the spread of innovation across our assets. We're uniquely positioned with 4 core areas to compete for capital within the Permian, which is the most robust and cost-efficient basin in North America. We are focused on making smart capital allocation decisions and keeping a strong financial position. The outlook for oil prices remains uncertain, but we've never been in a better position to deliver strong, profitable growth. This is our opportunity to extend our lead.
Thanks for listening and let me turn it back now to the moderator and take your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters
componenttext: I wanted to ask on capital allocation between the Delaware and the Midland Basin. Based on some of the wells that you reported that the well performance in the northern Delaware Basin looked very, very strong, particularly over the last couple of quarters and particularly this quarter in terms of oil rates adjusted for lateral length. And I wanted to see if you could comment a bit more on the decision to add rigs in the Midland Basin versus the northern Delaware Basin. You're drilling much longer laterals in the Midland Basin, but wanted to just get a sense as to, is there a differentiation in costs or expectations for future well performance that can justify adding activity there relative to ramping in the northern Delaware?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital that we're, as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the northern Delaware hasn't changed. It's still 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, t
componenttext: Right. Well, Brian, the amount of capital that we're, as a percentage basis that we're dedicating to the northern Delaware hasn't changed. It's still 45% of our total capital budget. The returns there are very strong. And as we've indicated in the past, the Midland Basin we see as improving. There have been several efficiency breakthroughs from longer laterals and completion techniques and things like that. We think the Midland Basin properties are getting stronger because of those efficiencies and will compete with the northern Delaware Basin and we will -- we haven't really changed our capital allocation. We are just on a trajectory to ramp-up capital in the Midland Basin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the oil environment? And is this the start of a
componenttext: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just thinking about overall capital levels in addition to the activity levels, obviously, adding rigs here now. But how should we expect your plans to shift at all depending on the oil environment? And is this the start of a more quarterly increases in activity if current oil prices level and higher oil prices play out?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about us is steady as she goes. And I don't think that we're going to change our capital budget or our rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well hed
componenttext: Like we have done in the past, I think the best way to think about us is steady as she goes. And I don't think that we're going to change our capital budget or our rig count based on kind of quarterly swings in oil price. So we will -- we're very well hedged, that gives us some certainty around the amount of cash flow we're going to have from oil prices. So we'll continue the plan that we started at the first of the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mike Scialla of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mike Scialla of Stifel.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Tim, you had mentioned I think you said 50% of your drilling this year was on pads. Just as you look into next year, trying to get a sense of where you think that will be? Do you go more towards development? Or is there more delineation still to be done?

componenttext: I think as we continue to roll forward in a normal environment, it's going to become more and more development like, so I would expect that number to do nothing, but go up.

componenttext: Mike, it's Jack. There really was no change that would have caused that, it's just kind of well location.

componenttext: Okay. And then just last one for me. It look like you had some pretty positive results on the stack laterals in the Wolfcamp A and B in the Midland. Any implications for your drilling inventory there? Or was that already kind of baked in?

componenttext: Yes, it's consistent with our inventory, Mike. And we're just furthering our knowledge there.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about -- just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of costs? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as
componenttext: Can you talk about -- just getting back to the pad drilling, what does it do for you in terms of costs? And then are you thinking 2 to 3 well pads? Or is it more than that when you say multi-well? And then finally on the pads like what should we expect as far as any interference as far as impact on EURs going forward? Can you just address all those?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost, but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked ab
componenttext: Yes, that's a lot of questions. Generally, there are dramatic cost savings from pad drilling, both just reduction in absolute cost, but also efficiency gains. Typically, our pads today are more like 3 or 4 well in size and the spacing that we've talked about from our wells, is the maximum spacing we have on any of our inventories, 8 across, although we're continuing to test downspacing ideas in all of our areas. And the downspacing testing is a pretty high percentage of the total of what we're doing. But no, we wouldn't expect any -- from pad drilling, any change of interference or drainage or EURs or anything like that from what we've talked about in the past.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had some of these wells have a pretty good production history, can we start thinking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing as far as change in the composition of the well come year
componenttext: Okay. And then as we think about now that you've had some of these wells have a pretty good production history, can we start thinking about the GORs over time? Can you talk about what you're seeing as far as change in the composition of the well come year 3, 4 in these plays?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique in that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do. So it's a little bit -- each zone is a little bit different. But in general, all these zon
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're a bit unique in that we have those multiple core areas and multiple basins. So we probably have more zones to talk about than other companies do. So it's a little bit -- each zone is a little bit different. But in general, all these zones have increasing GORs over time, and that's kind of baked into our estimates of ultimate recoveries and things like that. But you would expect the GORs to go up over time.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Hanold of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, if I could just ask a question off one of your responses and you obviously made the indication that activity is not to be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a
componenttext: Tim, if I could just ask a question off one of your responses and you obviously made the indication that activity is not to be dictated, obviously, by the quarterly moves in oil prices. But when you step back and looked at it, you did increase activity a little bit this year, but kept the budget unchanged. So how did you evaluate that? Was it more so that you're able to stay within your budget and so you made a decision to put in some additional rigs? Or was it obviously the improvement in oil prices that also factored into that as well?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So that adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties it
componenttext: No. What looks like a change of activity level has a couple of factors. One is the acquisition and divestiture program we have that I hope will continue throughout the year. So that adding rigs and subtracting rigs based on buying or selling properties it is one factor. And then the other one is just from quarter-to-quarter kind of the net change in ownership that we have within the properties, that kind of would dictate more or less rigs based on how much capital we're spending. So I wouldn't read too much into that in terms of ramping up activity because of a higher oil price, that's not what really is going on, it's more just a blocking and tackling of our base business.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and how the strip increased and can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that can
componenttext: Okay, understand. And you all reiterated your view that 2017 double-digit growth within cash flow at the strip, which is highly consistent with your comments last quarter and how the strip increased and can you maybe discuss that a little bit how that can be achieved? And one of the things that's pretty evident, if you look at consensus estimate out there right now, certainly it doesn't reflect that. Where do you think the disconnect is where the Street's modeling you all versus what you think you can accomplish?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, the increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an effici
componenttext: Yes. I think there are some things that are harder to model. I mentioned in the call, the increased lateral length from 1 year to the next. Also we talked about the shallowing of our base decline rate is an important one as well. Pad drilling is an efficiency that's hard to model outside the company. And the tweaking of completion designs and optimization of these wells continue to provide growing efficiencies that when we stew all those things together -- when we talk about 2017, it's kind of based on the efficiency and the cost we know off today. And we can get to that double-digit growth based on what we know today. But also I'm pretty optimistic that with these increasing efficiencies that Concho is going to be able to really differentiate itself within cash flow.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from John Freeman of Raymond James.

componenttext: Yes, we're comfortable with what we've come out with before on that, John. So the short answer is, yes, we're still very optimistic about the Avalon and that area.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: First question I want to ask, you just in answering John's question, you said that the net -- everything shakes out the net number of wells for 2016 essentially remains the same. componenttextpreview: Yes. I really -- I mean, the impact of that property trade for our company was a pretty large impact. And that's the kind of thing, the kind of asset, high grading that I think we ought to continue to do. Landing them both at the same timing and closing 2
componenttext: Yes. I really -- I mean, the impact of that property trade for our company was a pretty large impact. Landing them both at the same timing and closing 2 deals on the same day, or announcing 2 deals on the same day is a little bit of a trick. But in general, as we progress through the year, continuing to consolidate Tier 1 core acreage and selloff stuff that is further out in the queue, the drilling queue is kind of an activity that I hope we'll continue to see.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Neal Dingmann of SunTrust Robinson.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Say, Tim, it's notable again when I look at sort of in the press release, the 30-day results when you breakdown for the north and the south. Obviously, north remains strong, but now even the southern continue. Could you maybe give your thoughts on, do you
componenttext: Say, Tim, it's notable again when I look at sort of in the press release, the 30-day results when you breakdown for the north and the south. Obviously, north remains strong, but now even the southern continue. Could you maybe give your thoughts on, do you see both of those sort of continuing to trend in line? Or I guess, as we go forward, I am just -- we get pleasant surprised how much now that the south is now right in line now with the north when you kind of see those 30-day peak averages.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, right now the north is a lot bigger than the south. We've had good results from second Bone Spring, Avalon and Wolfcamp in the north and primarily what we're doing in the south is Wolfcamp. So I think that we'll be expanding, but we're very p
componenttext: Yes. I mean, right now the north is a lot bigger than the south. We've had good results from second Bone Spring, Avalon and Wolfcamp in the north and primarily what we're doing in the south is Wolfcamp. So I think that we'll be expanding, but we're very pleased with the performance of the North Harpoon area in the southern Delaware Basin. It completes with anything we're doing in the northern Delaware. And as we've stated, we think that their efficiencies will continue to drive cost lower and production higher. So we like both those areas.

componenttext: Okay, great. And just in terms of reallocating or at least some rig activity to the Midland Basin. And, obviously, you're shifting to longer laterals here. What are your thoughts? I mean, obviously you've been more of a Delaware Basin player throughout the company's history. What are your initial views on the longer laterals and potentially even -- get even more active in the Midland Basin if oil prices surprise to the upside?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to dispel that notion that we've primarily a Delaware Basin player. I mean we bought Henry Petroleum back in 2008 and they were one of the first movers in recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So
componenttext: I'd like to dispel that notion that we've primarily a Delaware Basin player. I mean we bought Henry Petroleum back in 2008 and they were one of the first movers in recognizing the oil potential in the Wolfcamp on the Western side of the Midland Basin. So we inherited a lot of that knowledge, expertise. I think we're an early mover over there. It's just been -- it kind of -- with all of our Delaware activity and everything we're doing in New Mexico, all that really good Midland Basin stuff just kind of got lost in the bigger picture. But I think we've got some of the best Midland Basin acreage that there is. Our well results compare with anything that anybody else is turning out in the Midland Basin. And we now have completed the Midland [ph] play so that you can run a multi-rig pad drilling development kind of program. So we're ready to devote more capital there. When we come out of this cycle and things start growing rapidly again, I think it would be good for Concho to have multiple growth drivers. The last time we came through this growth cycle, the growth of the company was really driven by the northern Delaware Basin. I think next time, we'll have multiple growth drivers. I think there will be a better, more diversified company.

componenttext: No, I hope they get better. That's -- one thing you're kind of dealing with the longer laterals though is just the mechanical ability to move that much fluid out of a 2-mile lateral. So I think as the industry goes to longer and longer wells, the initial 24-hour, 30-day rates aren't going to move as much as the 60- and 90-day rates because these wells in the first initial days, you just can't make that much more fluid out of that size hole, but I think they'll hold up better and you'll get better economics.

There's more flexibility in the system because of excess capacity of frac spreads.

componenttext: Just 2 quick questions, just to go back to a prior comment you guys had made regarding the longer laterals and the rates to 30 days, 60 day and 90 rates. Have you guys yet experimented with choking back the longer laterals? You probably haven't needed to do this yet, but just thinking about better managing infrastructure needs for the kind of the very high initial rates?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the
componenttext: Yes. In general, we're experimenting with everything. But specifically to your question, one thing we've done to reduce expenses early in the process of drilling these wells several years ago, we would put electric sub pumps on the well so we can move the fluid faster, that was very expensive. And so as we've tried to optimize things, especially at lower oil prices, we'll put pumping units, mechanical pumping units on them earlier and move less fluid, but it kind of fattens the decline curve. So it's not really choking them back, but it's controlling cost and not using as many sub pumps.

componenttext: Tim, I was just curious when you look at the Permian as oil prices normalize with hiring, activity comes back into the basin. And how quickly do you think the service companies can respond? I know that we have a lot of equipment, but what about people? Given how many people have left the industry? Or is the Permian in good shape because there's been a lot of people and equipment have moved to that area.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the Permian is in better shape than the other basins because the Permian seems to be the place right now that all the equipment wants to come to. And we spoke about the rig count. The rig count's at historic low right now, to about 130 rigs.
componenttext: Yes. I think the Permian is in better shape than the other basins because the Permian seems to be the place right now that all the equipment wants to come to. And we spoke about the rig count. The rig count's at historic low right now, to about 130 rigs. So there's a long way to go to add back equipment and people, even to get back half way to where we were 2 years ago. So I do think that in general, it will take the industry some time to respond to increased activity, but we need some increased activity just to get back to normal. So I think we have a lot of spare capacity right now and we're likely to have spare capacity for some time to come.
