headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Megan Hays. You may b
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Megan Hays. You may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Concho's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.Our second quarter earnings release and
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Concho's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our second quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectation this morning. Also some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. I kindly refer you to the forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures contained in both the earnings release and corporate presentation. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. The second quarter of 2016 was a good one. Once again, it illustrates the power of our assets, the excellent commitment of our people. While the macro environment is dynamic, we're extending our
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. 
The second quarter of 2016 was a good one. Once again, it illustrates the power of our assets, the excellent commitment of our people. While the macro environment is dynamic, we're extending our track record of working all angles within our business to deliver strong operational and financial performance and position the company for the future. Our performance this quarter highlights our ongoing drive to improve capital efficiency, with a relentless focus on asset performance, cost savings and capital discipline. Let me start by summarizing the key achievements for the quarter. 
Second quarter production increased 4% over the previous quarter and exceeded the high end of our guidance. For 2016, we now expect our annual production to show growth while maintaining our capital budget guidance and underspending cash flow. Our outlook for double-digit production growth in 2017 also remains unchanged and in some ways, improves. Double-digit growth in '17 up a higher production base and a capital program defined by our cash flow at the current strip will be a unique achievement, reflecting the operational momentum and improving capital productivity across our assets. 
For the first half of 2016, lease operating expenses averaged approximately $6.50 per barrel, a 12% reduction compared to LOE in the second half of '15. The decrease in LOE reflects specific actions we're taking to generate sustainable operational efficiencies. 
We're making substantial progress in several areas. For example, there's an asset-wide focus on transporting water disposal volumes by pipe rather than truck, which is more efficiently and reduces transportation costs. In addition, our efforts to optimize production fuel development have reduced pumping cost. Hydrating our inventory also contributes to lower LOE as we acquired assets, complementary to our core positions and infrastructure while we're selling lower return properties. 
As a result of ongoing improvements in operations, we've reduced our cost guidance for LOE to $6.75 per barrel at the midpoint. We also reduced our guidance for both cash and noncash G&A per barrel. Aggressively managing our cost structure, combined with strong asset performance, accelerates capital productivity gains, which increasingly enables us to do more with less. 
In addition to delivering strong production volumes and reducing operating costs, we under spent cash flow for the fourth consecutive quarter, which further strengthened our balance sheet. Our commitment to capital discipline and a strong balance sheet provides us with opportunities to generate differentiated value for our shareholders. The most impactful way we can affect the value of Concho is by becoming even more efficient, and we are focused on improving the productivity of each capital dollar invested. Each of our core areas is contributing to improved capital productivity. 
In the Northern Delaware Basin, where we've drilled more than 600 horizontal wells, our drilling team still finds way to set new records. For example, in the second quarter, average drilling days improved to 19, smashing the prior record by 3 days. We're also advancing the oil-rich Avalon Shale in Lea County where continued improvement is a direct result of refining lateral placement and completion techniques. 
This quarter, we highlighted early results from the density test on the Monet wells and this appears on Slide 9 of the earnings presentation. These 4 wells targeted the upper Avalon zone on 80 acre spacing to the specific focus on optimizing the fluid systems and sand volumes. We're excited about the outstanding performance of these wells as we move into development mode. 
The Red Hills area in Lea County's an area where we targeted both on acquisitions for long lateral development. During the second half of the year, we planned to drill several long lateral wells, targeting the Avalon, and we'll look to replicate our success in the Wolfcamp where we believe significant upside exists. 
In the southern Delaware Basin, we closed the acquisition of 12,000 net acres in our core North Harpoon area at the end of the first quarter. We've added 2 drilling rigs to this acreage at the start of the second quarter, illustrating that anything we bring into the portfolio must be ready to move to the front of the drilling program. 
In the Southern Delaware, we continued to deliver industry-leading well results and the Upper Wolfcamp while continuing to test multi-zone potential. We recently achieved strong results from a third Bone Spring well with plans to drill additional third Bone Spring wells before the end of the year. 
We're also quickly advancing our play in the Midland Basin. The Midland Basin represents our largest opportunity to capture efficiencies as we focus on 2-mile laterals and multi-well pad development. Our efforts to optimize development and maximize the value of this project are ongoing. The 9 wells we drilled this quarter were drilled to a shorter lateral length, which is primarily a function of timing. We drilled these wells in 2015 and our to shift to 2-mile laterals begin at the start of this year. 
We also tested smaller frac jobs on these wells, which provided us valuable information about cost versus well performance that we can use to improve future well economics. 
For the balance of the year, our completion techniques will focus on large profit concentrations. We're currently completing an 8-well density test with 4 wells targeting the Lower Spraberry and 4 wells targeting the Wolfcamp B. These completions will utilize profit concentrations of approximately 2,000 pounds per foot. 
The New Mexico Shelf continues to outperform. During the quarter, well results for the shelf set another record, the second in its many quarters. With just 2 rigs running here, we've managed to advance that's horizontal development of the play and maintained stable production from year-end '15 volumes. 
Our strategy and diversity within the Permian are unique and give us our greatest competitive advantage. We have the ability to allocate capital across our assets and leverage our scale and technical expertise to enhance returns and recoveries. And our relentless focus on improving capital efficiency will have an ever increasing impact on Concho. It will we enable us to drive profitable debt adjusted gross per share in the near and long-term. 
The acquisition market surrounding our core areas is also setting new records and it's nice to have assets in the hottest ZIP Codes in the industry. We currently have the largest and highest quality inventory in our history. Our consolidation activity must compete with our top-tier drilling inventory and strengthen our financial position. While it's a target-rich environment, we will continue to take a disciplined approach in pursuing the right acquisitions to build for the future. 
Cinema is positive among our industry peers and optimism is a driving force in our industry. At Concho, there's a lot to be excited about. But the outlook for commodity prices isn't much different since the last quarterly update. As a result, we maintained our commitment to spend within cash flow. The momentum we're generating reinforces our 2017 outlook for double-digit production growth, while balancing capital and cash flow within the current price outlook. 
The mission of Concho has always been to build something unique, to build a leading energy company that excels in any environment that creates shareholder value by investing capital in the best assets with the highest returns that consistently seeks to improve performance and drive profitable growth per share. Our vision for delivering on this mission today is simple, we believe that we can be the best by executing a disciplined capital program, delivering operational excellence and hydrating our investment opportunities. Our track record of performance confined with focus and disciplined execution of our strategy will enable us to generate value for our shareholders for many years to come. 
Thanks for listening and let me turn it back over to the moderator and take your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Jason Smith of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Jason Smith of Bank of America.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, just on capital allocation. So you've got 6 rigs running in the Midland and 4 in each of the Northern and Southern Delaware. So I guess, as we look forward, is that a fair reflection of how you want to keep the capital allocated? Or given the results
componenttext: Tim, just on capital allocation. So you've got 6 rigs running in the Midland and 4 in each of the Northern and Southern Delaware. So I guess, as we look forward, is that a fair reflection of how you want to keep the capital allocated? Or given the results you saw this quarter in both the Avalon and the Southern Delaware, do you foresee maybe increasing the relative allocation back to the Delaware?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think one of the things that I was referring to is that all of our core areas are delivering really good economics for us right now. So I think the capital allocation that you see today would be a balanced approach going forward. So I think you ough
componenttext: No. I think one of the things that I was referring to is that all of our core areas are delivering really good economics for us right now. So I think the capital allocation that you see today would be a balanced approach going forward. So I think you ought to just expect us to continue allocate capital based on returns and in also areas where we're testing new ideas.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe just a follow-up on that, the new ideas, in the Midland, you discussed the proppants you guys are testing. But maybe when you talk about testing, well spacing and development patters, can you just may be frame for us what the existing co
componenttext: Got it. And maybe just a follow-up on that, the new ideas, in the Midland, you discussed the proppants you guys are testing. But maybe when you talk about testing, well spacing and development patters, can you just may be frame for us what the existing configurations are and what the concepts are that you guys are testing there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's different depending on which zone you're talking about. But in general, when we talk about density test, when we talk about our inventory and things like that, we're still 8 wells per section in general. So it's not as dense as some of our peers
componenttext: Yes. It's different depending on which zone you're talking about. But in general, when we talk about density test, when we talk about our inventory and things like that, we're still 8 wells per section in general. So it's not as dense as some of our peers are talking. But test involve testing spacing, but also the configuration of wells in the zone, whether it's a line rack or a Chevron pattern or something like that, also lateral length and profit and concentrate. There's a big experimentation going on as we've discussed in the past. And I think we've got more data and running 16 rigs is one of the leaders in the industry. So we're gathering data more quickly than most.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I wanted to go back a little bit on the proppant loading. I'm just curious, you made a point, Tim, early in the prepared remarks that you do have a unique view on the Permian Basin, given the asset base you have really all in the different areas.
componenttext: I guess, I wanted to go back a little bit on the proppant loading. I'm just curious, you made a point, Tim, early in the prepared remarks that you do have a unique view on the Permian Basin, given the asset base you have really all in the different areas. What sort of variation in proppant loading response you're seeing across the different areas? Or are some areas more sensitive to proppant loading than others? And I'm just curious what other sort of color you can provide an that context?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we've gotten as low as, I think, as about 1,000 pounds per foot and now we're testing loading at over 2,000 pounds per foot. And as I mentioned on the call, in my prepared remarks, it's different by zone and you're trying to balance that vers
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we've gotten as low as, I think, as about 1,000 pounds per foot and now we're testing loading at over 2,000 pounds per foot. And as I mentioned on the call, in my prepared remarks, it's different by zone and you're trying to balance that versus drainage versus the type of fracs you're getting and the well spacing and configuration that you have. And as you mentioned, we have so many zones in so many of the subbasins that every answer's a little bit different. And generally, of course, the higher that sand loading, the bigger the wells. But that doesn't mean you're optimizing the economics that way. So we've been running experiments on how do we get the best capital efficiency of long laterals really is driving the answer. And then I mentioned a placement in the zone and fluid composition, things like that. So it's a complex experiment, but I would tell you that the results have been very encouraging in all our areas. And we think we can continue to drive efficiency through the things we're learning about the properties in the zones.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. The average lateral length of the completed wells versus the average lateral length of drilled wells that tended to vary in this amount. Just thinking going forward, what sort of lag is there? If we look at what you're drilling today, when is this actually going to get completed?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then on the LOE, very impressive improvements there. It sounds like a lot of that's quite structural. I was wondering if you could comment on the other side, the cyclicality of it all. How are you all thinking about how LOE might
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then on the LOE, very impressive improvements there. It sounds like a lot of that's quite structural. I was wondering if you could comment on the other side, the cyclicality of it all. How are you all thinking about how LOE might behave as we move to the other side of the cycle, hopefully, at some point here?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Some of the changes that we're making are going to last, putting disposal water on pipe versus trucks, changing the lift in the wells. Those types of things should last, cost of goods and services we know move up when there's pressure. But we think s
componenttext: Yes. Some of the changes that we're making are going to last, putting disposal water on pipe versus trucks, changing the lift in the wells. Those types of things should last, cost of goods and services we know move up when there's pressure. But we think some of the important factors are sustainable.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a way to quantify how much is kind of variable associated with the cyclical environment versus more structural component?
componenttext: Is there a way to quantify how much is kind of variable associated with the cyclical environment versus more structural component?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: That's hard. I just watched the rig count and completion count to get a gauge of the industry. But it feels like at least half, if not more, are sustainable.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And last one just around the oil mix in the quarter came down a little bit, it sounds like some new plants are coming on. headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The composition of the wells we're drilling is as oily as ever. I mean, you pointed out the quarter we had that Ramsey plant come back online in the quarter that had a big effect on gas production. But at the same time, as far as timing, when you slow dow
componenttext: The composition of the wells we're drilling is as oily as ever. I mean, you pointed out the quarter we had that Ramsey plant come back online in the quarter that had a big effect on gas production. But at the same time, as far as timing, when you slow down and you don't drill as much, over time the GORs go back up. But as soon activity increases and we continue to build on what we're doing, I think it's going to sit anywhere within our guidance.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: Tim, I was wondering you gave us some outlook comments in terms of growth for 2016, '17. And I know you've held with that double-digit forecast, I think you provided that when it was in the low-40s. So wondered if you could help us think about given some
componenttext: Tim, I was wondering you gave us some outlook comments in terms of growth for 2016, '17. And I know you've held with that double-digit forecast, I think you provided that when it was in the low-40s. So wondered if you could help us think about given some of the well productivity gains, oil has moved a bit. Maybe help us think about what you think growth could be in '17. I think The Street's at 11% and perhaps, I don't know if you inject a thought about a 3- to 5-year kind of outlook for Concho, and if you think this double-digit type of growth level is sustainable over the next 3 to 5 years within cash flows?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're always thinking about the long term, that's kind of how we built the company. We think it's important to be able to talk about how we can grow in the current circumstance with the current price forecast, the current efficiencies that we
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're always thinking about the long term, that's kind of how we built the company. We think it's important to be able to talk about how we can grow in the current circumstance with the current price forecast, the current efficiencies that we've gained on our wells and things like that and then try to make it better. And so I think that areas we're in, the way we're structured, how our cost structure is set up that we will, for the long-term, will be able to compete with anybody in the industry on growth. And we are very pleased to be able to talk about growth within cash flow. And in fact, we've been under spending cash flow for several quarters and still growing. So I think we're well-positioned. And our goal is always to surprise you to the upside.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: That Northern Delaware Basin you're talking about, I have some prepared comments on that and some of the best well results in the industry. componenttext: I mean, there's both the Delaware Basin and the Midland Basin really have some outstanding results. And there are opportunities in both basins, and I think we find the best opportunities in areas that are in and around our core and areas that give us opportunities to drill long laterals and get the efficiencies you get from being a larger operator with pad drilling and lots of activity.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Can you talk a bit more about the Midland opportunity from here? You've highlighted in your comments the efficiency gains that you could see. If we look at the well rates adjusted for lateral length, it seems the Delaware Basin is so much larger than the Midland Basin, I know you've kind of testing the proppant loadings there. But I just wonder what your expectations are for where well rates adjusted for laterals can go and whether you view the Midland rates of return as equal to or better than Delaware?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have projects in the Midland Basin that compete well with the Delaware Basin, just like we do in the Mexico Shale. So -- and return is what we focus on. So I would just answer that by saying, all of the core areas have projects that compete we
componenttext: Well, we do have projects in the Midland Basin that compete well with the Delaware Basin, just like we do in the Mexico Shale. So -- and return is what we focus on. So I would just answer that by saying, all of the core areas have projects that compete well on the rate of return basis, Midland and Delaware.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so what would the efficiency gains that you talked to end up driving Midland basin returns to more widely be competitive with the Delaware? Or ultimately, where the Midland could exceed the Delaware? I'm just trying to think of kind of going back to o
componenttext: And so what would the efficiency gains that you talked to end up driving Midland basin returns to more widely be competitive with the Delaware? Or ultimately, where the Midland could exceed the Delaware? I'm just trying to think of kind of going back to one of the earlier questions on capital allocation and thinking about that over the longer term.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the enhancements we've seen in the Midland Basin, namely water delivery system, ability to drill long laterals, have allowed that asset to compete with the Delaware. Going forward, when I look at that allocation this year, its about 25% to th
componenttext: Yes, I think the enhancements we've seen in the Midland Basin, namely water delivery system, ability to drill long laterals, have allowed that asset to compete with the Delaware. Going forward, when I look at that allocation this year, its about 25% to the Midland Basin. That's a pretty good proxy going forward. As Tim said, we're looking for a balance between the Midland Basin, the Southern Delaware and the Northern Delaware.

componenttext: Tim, a lot has been asked. So let me just go big picture. Oil sitting at $40, I know you guys, I guess, you're at 16 rigs and going to stay -- plan stay, I know you're hedged. componenttext: I mean, we've built our current plan around, as you've said, we are hedged but we've built it around kind of the current strip. So I think it's kind of steady as she goes, that's the way we characterize it when we've started this. And I think the results and economics we're getting are okay at today's oil price.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I know you've talked about this probably a year ago, but when you start thinking about that at $100, before it was we get an equivalent return when oil is at $70 or $60 or whatever the number was on the way down. How should we think about framing up
componenttext: Okay. I know you've talked about this probably a year ago, but when you start thinking about that at $100, before it was we get an equivalent return when oil is at $70 or $60 or whatever the number was on the way down. How should we think about framing up returns? And I guess, in the current environment, what service cost what you've done on the operational efficiencies? headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, one thing at Concho and the rest of the industry, we have really been focused on reducing our cost structure. And we had to do that because of the environment that we were in and what was happening with the cash margins. So we have gotten, we've h
componenttext: I mean, one thing at Concho and the rest of the industry, we have really been focused on reducing our cost structure. And we had to do that because of the environment that we were in and what was happening with the cash margins. So we have gotten, we've had great progress on LOE, G&A, just our total cost burden. And that's helped the economics of all the projects and the economics of the company. I think we told you before that one way Jack characterized it at 50, I'd say it was at 50 things, 50[ph] and above things work-, really well, 40 to 50 things we're okay, and below 40, things weren't any good. And I'd tell you because of the efficiency gains and cost reductions and things like that, I think that all scales, slid now $5 or $10.

componenttext: Yes. I think it's the timing of the completion and the style of wells. I wouldn't read a whole lot into that. We have a pretty steady amount of activity in the first half of the year.

componenttext: Yes. So in general for the year, more than half of our wells are going to be drilled on pads. Some of those we'll be drilling wells in the same zone and some of those we'll be drilling wells in either 2 zones or multiple members of 1 zone. So it's all across-the-board.

I mean, obviously, like the Avalon after the density test and some of the returns you're getting, other parts of the Northern and Southern Delaware as well as the Midland does, I think Jack mentioned this but I just want to comment circle back to the New Mexico Shelf, with those 30-day rates of just sub-500 is because of the cost or did the returns compete there with the other 3 plays that why you're still running the rigs there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The returns are really good, the costs are low. The costs, there was like $2.5 million of well or something like that. So those returns compete with anything we're doing. And we just don't have as big an inventory on the shelf as we do in other place
componenttext: Yes. The returns are really good, the costs are low. The costs, there was like $2.5 million of well or something like that. So those returns compete with anything we're doing. And we just don't have as big an inventory on the shelf as we do in other places and it's all held by production, it's a great asset.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Tim, you did mention, I think, it's Slide 7, it shows how much costs come down since first quarter of '15, it's pretty amazing. Is that now on a go forward, I mean, can we think of that to continuing in most areas? I mean, I guess, what I'm allu
componenttext: And then, Tim, you did mention, I think, it's Slide 7, it shows how much costs come down since first quarter of '15, it's pretty amazing. Is that now on a go forward, I mean, can we think of that to continuing in most areas? I mean, I guess, what I'm alluding to is just basically service costs versus efficiencies. Do you see cost improvements still increasing? And if so, is cost decreasing? And if so, is that more because of continued service costs declining a bit more? Is that more just efficiencies?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the majority of cost savings going forward is going to be deficiencies and service cost providers reducing the cost per specific items. We still have continued to experience lower cost from the service industry. The rig count hit a bottom in the P
componenttext: I think the majority of cost savings going forward is going to be deficiencies and service cost providers reducing the cost per specific items. We still have continued to experience lower cost from the service industry. The rig count hit a bottom in the Permian Basin of, I think, 130 or 140 rigs and now it's up to 190. So we've seen some increase in activity out here. But at the same time, the Permian Basin's kind of where everybody wants to be. So there's been equipment and people moving in here from other basins. So I think we've got plenty of spare capacity in all respects. And so I don't think we feel any costs pressure on the upside and there may still be some room to move lower.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious if you could provide us with any color on as you go ahead into '17, you've talked sort of about the double digits within cash flow staying within cash flow. What should we expect in terms of a progression of lateral length in your current designs?
componenttext: Curious if you could provide us with any color on as you go ahead into '17, you've talked sort of about the double digits within cash flow staying within cash flow. What should we expect in terms of a progression of lateral length in your current designs? Or is that sort of conversation and that guidance is that more based on the current lateral lengths that you're drilling with?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's based on the current lateral length. We have found substantial efficiencies in drilling 2-mile laterals everywhere we can. So where we have the least configurations in the blocky acreage, you will see those kind of lateral lengths and it's predominan
componenttext: It's based on the current lateral length. We have found substantial efficiencies in drilling 2-mile laterals everywhere we can. So where we have the least configurations in the blocky acreage, you will see those kind of lateral lengths and it's predominantly in the Southern Delaware Basin and in the Midland Basin. But the double-digit production growth that we are talking about is kind of event that system that we see today for how we configure our wells and how we drill them.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, can you just remind me, I'm not sure if you've provided this before, but roughly what percentage of your overall acreage at least in the Delaware is amenable to the 2-mile laterals?
componenttext: Tim, can you just remind me, I'm not sure if you've provided this before, but roughly what percentage of your overall acreage at least in the Delaware is amenable to the 2-mile laterals?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you can kind of look at the map. It's in the Southern Delaware's where the majority of that ability would be. In the Northern, I think you'll see us we try to move the lateral length but we're talking hundreds of feet there of increase, not thousan
componenttext: David, you can kind of look at the map. It's in the Southern Delaware's where the majority of that ability would be. In the Northern, I think you'll see us we try to move the lateral length but we're talking hundreds of feet there of increase, not thousands, like you could see in the Southern.

componenttext: Yes, it certainly has improved significantly since [indiscernible] with the cost changes. So yes. And I think you could actually raise the bar above 20% and still have multi-decades type of inventory at this year's pace.

componenttext: No, no. I don't think that's fair necessarily. But I just say if it was 30% before, that number is higher somewhere between 30% and 50%.

componenttext: No, I don't really want to comment on the specific deal. I would tell you though that buying things every quarter and selling things every quarter is kind of the way to machine works. So we ought to -- as we acquire things, we're going to be selling other parts of our portfolio to try to get more concentrated and cored up and it's just the normal part of our business.

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And last one for me. It sounds like you're still testing in most of the areas, is there anywhere in the portfolio that you'd say you're at fulfilled development now that may be that stateline area there? Or you're still testing even there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still testing all the areas. I mean, we have gotten better and better. The more wells we drilled, the more efficiency we've been able to get out of our program. But I think that will continue, I mean, the experimentation will continue, new technolog
componenttext: We're still testing all the areas. I mean, we have gotten better and better. The more wells we drilled, the more efficiency we've been able to get out of our program. But I think that will continue, I mean, the experimentation will continue, new technology will continue, trying things all the time, it's been really encouraging. And I think when somebody starts to say that they've got to crack the code and they got it figured out, that's a sign of danger. So we've continued to get better and the -- but I expect every year that will show some sorts of improvements.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Kelly of Seaport Global.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Concho was early on recognizing the potential merits of the Southern Delaware Basin, it seems like the rest of the industry's catching up 1 year, 1.5 years later. Tim, I'd love to get your thoughts early on just look across the entire Permian right now an
componenttext: Concho was early on recognizing the potential merits of the Southern Delaware Basin, it seems like the rest of the industry's catching up 1 year, 1.5 years later. Tim, I'd love to get your thoughts early on just look across the entire Permian right now and what areas and formations in your mind have the potential to exhibit the greatest positive rate of change if we look out 1 year, 1.5 years going forward now?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Delaware Basin, the entire Delaware Basin is still in early stages. I mentioned we've drilled 600 horizontal wells in the north, that's probably the highest area of concentration of wells and information gathering and we're still learning there.
componenttext: Well, the Delaware Basin, the entire Delaware Basin is still in early stages. I mentioned we've drilled 600 horizontal wells in the north, that's probably the highest area of concentration of wells and information gathering and we're still learning there. And I think there that the Wolfcamp zone is -- hasn't been tested as much. It's probably more widespread than anybody recognizes, holds lots of upside potential. The Southern Delaware Basin is very early as far as getting enough information in wells to delineate all the productive zones. And so we think there's still a tremendous amount of work to be done there. And so we did the Delaware Basin and the top-tier areas of the Delaware Basin continue to grow. And at the Midland Basin has -- there's lots of companies with lots of data and just probably further along, industries understanding of what works and what doesn't work and where the Wolfcamp works best, where the Spraberry works best. So in general I think for both Midland Basin and the Delaware Basin, it's the early innings. And everybody's -- the number of wells the companies are drilling have gone down. It's amazing to me that we have more rigs running in the Permian Basin, I think, just about anybody. And we're only running 16, we're running almost 40 2 years ago. So it's lots of things have changed.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good color. And then secondly for me, you're currently on long-term strategy, it seems like you guys have shifted somewhat to talk more about staying within cash flow growth within cash flow. And I'm curious here, years past, you've said no problem outspe
componenttext: Good color. And then secondly for me, you're currently on long-term strategy, it seems like you guys have shifted somewhat to talk more about staying within cash flow growth within cash flow. And I'm curious here, years past, you've said no problem outspending. And I'm curious what would get you to kind of go back to that mindset potentially look to outspend and push growth more?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would challenge you a little bit on the, we have no problem outspending cash flow. Because I think that was a one-time moonshot kind of project where we saw our balance sheet was delevering naturally, acquisitions looked expensive and we announced that
componenttext: I would challenge you a little bit on the, we have no problem outspending cash flow. Because I think that was a one-time moonshot kind of project where we saw our balance sheet was delevering naturally, acquisitions looked expensive and we announced that 2-by-3 plan where we could double production within 3 years. That was not kind of our normal way we operate, but those were the conditions at the time. And we have great success in that program, we were well on our way to achieving all those goals. Today, it just seems like the kind of time we find ourselves in with the volatility, having a strong balance sheet, being able to demonstrate capital discipline and improving capital efficiency is the way you set yourself apart from the rest of the field. And that's what we're focused on and we think we can show really dramatic results staying within cash flow. And I think we can show growth that's going to be very well received.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Just picking up on the last point about balance sheet. I mean, just looking at various leverage metrics continue to flow[ph] down, I think your total debt to flowing production's down 20% year-on-year. Can you just update us on your thinking on investment grade? I know you guys are very stable with the ratings agencies, been awarded for your conservatism here. headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I think the maintaining our rating in this environment, I think, is very positive and a recognition by the agencies of our business. In terms of investment grade, we think that will be the result of the way we run our business. And depends on which 1 you're talking to, absolute size and reserve base is a big factor. But again I think it would just be a result of the way that the run our business.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. And just kind of to follow up on that. I that one of the things that maybe have been an obstacle or a roadblock have been "asset diversity." I know you think about yourselves as operating in 3 different areas, may be some people look at
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. And just kind of to follow up on that. I that one of the things that maybe have been an obstacle or a roadblock have been "asset diversity." I know you think about yourselves as operating in 3 different areas, may be some people look at you as Permian only and that kind of thing. Is that still a concern? Or how does it evolve at all?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's certainly not a concern of ours. We have 4 core areas in the Permian across several hundred miles. So we feel like it's plenty of diversity.
componenttext: It's certainly not a concern of ours. We have 4 core areas in the Permian across several hundred miles. So we feel like it's plenty of diversity.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add that the Permian's a big plays and it wasn't that long ago that our biggest concern about the Permian, which is takeaway capacity. And that has been solved and with our ability to export crude oil and our access to different markets,
componenttext: Yes. I would just add that the Permian's a big plays and it wasn't that long ago that our biggest concern about the Permian, which is takeaway capacity. And that has been solved and with our ability to export crude oil and our access to different markets, we think if you're going to be -- have concentrated assets, the Permian's the place you want to concentrate.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That absolutely makes sense. Just real quick, as you sort of alluded to this and answered in another question, but as I look at year '17 program, you guys thinking doing cash flow. And I think your weighted average floor price per hedge is about $55 there
componenttext: That absolutely makes sense. Just real quick, as you sort of alluded to this and answered in another question, but as I look at year '17 program, you guys thinking doing cash flow. And I think your weighted average floor price per hedge is about $55 there and actually you guys are just about breakeven there. But it sounds like you guys are saying that with the cost structure coming down, maybe you're unhedged company-wide, cash flow breakeven point might be kind of coming down below $55, maybe $50 or even high 40s. Is that the right way to think about that?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair assessment, yes.
componenttext: I think that's a fair assessment, yes.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tim, just building on your Southern Delaware comments. We've heard from industry, including Anadarko, this quarter the potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would be interested in your take on how you would frame that? And how you currently ranked your 2 d
componenttext: So Tim, just building on your Southern Delaware comments. We've heard from industry, including Anadarko, this quarter the potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would be interested in your take on how you would frame that? And how you currently ranked your 2 delineated intervals in terms of returns?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would argue that there's potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would say that we've tested 2 of them with good results and high productivity. And I think the opportunities that are being identified by industry within the Southern Delaware Basin, within the
componenttext: I would argue that there's potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would say that we've tested 2 of them with good results and high productivity. And I think the opportunities that are being identified by industry within the Southern Delaware Basin, within the Delaware Basin, we certainly agree with, it's just one thing to talk about potential and then another thing to talk about well results and success.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just in terms of how you ranked your 2 delineated intervals to date in terms of returns?
componenttext: And then just in terms of how you ranked your 2 delineated intervals to date in terms of returns?

componenttext: They're both very good. I wouldn't say that we would prefer one over the other based on returns. It's just one's the Upper Wolfcamp was the first thing we started developing, it was the deepest zone that we've started developing and had good results in. And I think that will continue to expand.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Megan Hays. You may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Concho's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.Our second quarter earnings release and
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Concho's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our second quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectations this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. Forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in the earnings release and corporate presentation and can be found at Concho's website.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. The second quarter of 2016 was a good one. Once again, it illustrates the power of our assets, the excellent commitment of our people. While the macro environment is dynamic, we're extending our tr
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. The second quarter of 2016 was a good one. Once again, it illustrates the power of our assets, the excellent commitment of our people. While the macro environment is dynamic, we're extending our track record of working all angles within our business to deliver strong operational and financial performance and position the company for the future. Our performance this quarter highlights our ongoing drive to improve capital efficiency, with a relentless focus on asset performance, cost savings and capital discipline. 
Let me start by summarizing the key achievements for the quarter. Second quarter production increased 4% over the previous quarter and exceeded the high end of our guidance. For 2016, we now expect our annual production to show growth, while maintaining our capital budget guidance and underspending cash flow. Our outlook for double-digit production growth in 2017 also remains unchanged and in some ways, improves. Double-digit growth in '17 up a higher production base and a capital program defined by our cash flow at the current strip will be a unique achievement, reflecting the operational momentum and improving capital productivity across our assets. 
For the first half of 2016, lease operating expenses averaged approximately $6.50 per barrel, a 12% reduction compared to LOE in the second half of '15. The decrease in LOE reflects specific actions we're taking to generate sustainable operational efficiencies. 
We're making substantial progress in several areas. For example, there's an asset-wide focus on transporting water disposal volumes by pipe rather than truck, which is more efficient and reduces transportation cost. In addition, our efforts to optimize production and fuel development that reduce pumping cost. High-grading our inventory also contributes to lower LOE as we acquire assets complementary to our core positions and infrastructure, while we're selling lower returning properties. 
As a result of ongoing improvements in operations, we've reduced our cost guidance for LOE to $6.75 per barrel at the midpoint. We also reduced our guidance for both cash and noncash G&A per barrel. Aggressively managing our cost structure, combined with strong asset performance, accelerates capital productivity gains, which increasingly enables us to do more with less. 
In addition to delivering strong production volumes and reducing operating cost, we underspent cash flow for the fourth consecutive quarter, which further strengthened our balance sheet. Our commitment to capital discipline and a strong balance sheet provides us with opportunities to generate differentiated value for our shareholders. The most impactful way we can affect the value of Concho is by becoming even more efficient, and we're focused on improving the productivity of each capital dollar invested. Each of our core areas is contributing to improved capital productivity.
In the Northern Delaware Basin, where we've drilled more than 600 horizontal wells, our drilling team still finds ways to set new records. For example, in the second quarter, average drilling days improved to 19, smashing the prior record by 3 days. We're also advancing the oil-rich Avalon Shale in Lea County, where continued improvement is a direct result of refining lateral placement and completion techniques. 
This quarter, we highlighted early results from the density test on the Monet wells and this appears on Slide 9 of the earnings presentation. These 4 wells targeted the upper Avalon zone on 80 acre spacing, with a specific focus on optimizing the fluid systems and sand volumes. We're excited about the outstanding performance of these wells as we move into development mode. 
The Red Hills area in Lea County is an area where we've targeted bolt on acquisitions for long lateral development. During the second half of the year, we planned to drill several long lateral wells, targeting the Avalon, and we'll look to replicate our success in the Wolfcamp where we believe significant upside exists. 
In the southern Delaware Basin, we closed the acquisition of 12,000 net acres in our core North Harpoon area at the end of the first quarter. We've added 2 drilling rigs to this acreage at the start of the second quarter, illustrating that anything we bring into the portfolio must be ready to move to the front of the drilling program. 
In the Southern Delaware, we continued to deliver industry-leading well results and the Upper Wolfcamp, while continuing to test multi-zone potential. We recently achieved strong results from a third Bone Spring well with plans to drill additional third Bone Spring wells before the end of the year. 
We're also quickly advancing our play in the Midland Basin. The Midland Basin represents our largest opportunity to capture efficiencies as we focus on 2-mile laterals and multi-well pad development. Our efforts to optimize development and maximize the value of this project are ongoing. The 9 wells we drilled this quarter were drilled to a shorter lateral length, which is primarily a function of timing. We drilled these wells in 2015 and our to shift to 2-mile laterals begin at the start of this year. We also tested smaller frac jobs on these wells, which provided us valuable information about cost versus well performance that we can use to improve future well economics. 
For the balance of the year, our completion techniques will focus on large profit concentrations. We're currently completing an 8-well density test with 4 wells targeting the Lower Spraberry and 4 wells targeting the Wolfcamp B. These completions will utilize profit concentrations of approximately 2,000 pounds per foot. 
The New Mexico Shelf continues to outperform. During the quarter, well results for the shelf set another record, the second in as many quarters. With just 2 rigs running here, we've managed to advance horizontal development of the play and maintain stable production from year-end '15 volumes. 
Our strategy and diversity within the Permian are unique and give us our greatest competitive advantage. We have the ability to allocate capital across our assets and leverage our scale and technical expertise to enhance returns and recoveries. And our relentless focus on improving capital efficiency will have an ever increasing impact on Concho. It will we enable us to drive profitable debt-adjusted growth per share in the near and long-term. 
The acquisition market surrounding our core areas is also setting new records and it's nice to have assets in the hottest ZIP Codes in the industry. We currently have the largest and highest quality inventory in our history. Our consolidation activity must compete with our top-tier drilling inventory and strengthen our financial position. While it's a target-rich environment, we will continue to take a disciplined approach in pursuing the right acquisitions to build for the future. 
Cinema is positive among our industry peers and optimism is a driving force in our industry. At Concho, there's a lot to be excited about. But the outlook for commodity prices isn't much different since the last quarterly update. As a result, we maintained our commitment to spend within cash flow. The momentum we're generating reinforces our 2017 outlook for double-digit production growth, while balancing capital and cash flow within the current price outlook. 
The mission of Concho has always been to build something unique, to build a leading energy company that excels in any environment, that creates shareholder value by investing capital in the best assets with the highest returns, that consistently seeks to improve performance and drive profitable growth per share. 
Our vision for delivering on this mission today is simple, we believe that we can be the best by executing a disciplined capital program, delivering operational excellence and high-grading our investment opportunities. Our track record of performance combined with focus and disciplined execution of our strategy will enable us to generate value for our shareholders for many years to come. 
Thanks for listening and let me turn it back over to the moderator and take your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

Or given the results you saw this quarter in both the Avalon and the Southern Delaware, do you foresee maybe increasing the relative allocation back towards the Delaware?

componenttext: No. I think one of the things that I was referring to in the comments is that all of our core areas are delivering really good economics for us right now. So I think the capital allocation that you see today would be a balanced approach going forward. So I think you ought to just expect us to continue to allocate capital based on returns and also in areas where we're testing new ideas.

componenttext: Got it. And maybe just a follow-up on that. The new ideas, in the Midland, you discussed the proppants you guys are testing. But maybe when you talk about testing, well spacing and development patters, can you just may be frame for us what the existing configurations, are and what the concepts are that you guys are testing there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's different depending on which zone you're talking about. But in general, when we talk about density test, when we talk about our inventory and things like that, we're still 8 wells per section in general. So it's not as dense as some of our peers
componenttext: Yes. It's different depending on which zone you're talking about. But in general, when we talk about density test, when we talk about our inventory and things like that, we're still 8 wells per section in general. So it's not as dense as some of our peers are talking. But the test involve testing spacing, but also the configuration of wells in the zone, whether it's a line rack or a Chevron pattern or something like that. Also, lateral length and profit and concentrate -- there's big experimentation going on as we've discussed in the past. And I think we've got more data and running 16 rigs is one of the leaders in the industry. So we're gathering data more quickly than most.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Hall of Heikkinen Energy.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I wanted to go back a little bit on the proppant loading. I'm just curious, you made the point, Tim, early in the prepared remarks that you do have a unique view on the Permian Basin, given the asset base you have really straddled all the differe
componenttext: I guess, I wanted to go back a little bit on the proppant loading. I'm just curious, you made the point, Tim, early in the prepared remarks that you do have a unique view on the Permian Basin, given the asset base you have really straddled all the different areas. What sort of variation in proppant loading response are you seeing across the different areas? Or are some areas more sensitive to proppant loading than others? And I'm just curious what other sort of color you all can provide in that context?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we've gotten as low, I think, as about 1,000 pounds per foot and now we're testing loading at over 2,000 pounds per foot. And as I mentioned on the call, it's -- or in my prepared remarks, it's different by zone and you're trying to balance t
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we've gotten as low, I think, as about 1,000 pounds per foot and now we're testing loading at over 2,000 pounds per foot. And as I mentioned on the call, it's -- or in my prepared remarks, it's different by zone and you're trying to balance that versus drainage versus the type of fracs you're getting and the well spacing and configuration that you have. So -- and as you mentioned, we have so many zones in so many of the sub basins that every answer's a little bit different. And generally, of course, the higher the sand loading, the bigger the wells. But that doesn't necessarily mean you're optimizing the economics that way. So we've been running experiments on how do we get the best capital efficiency of long laterals really is driving the answer. And then I mentioned a placement in the zone and fluid composition, things like that. So it's a complex experiment, but I would tell you that the results have been very encouraging in all our areas. And we think we can continue to drive efficiency through the things we're learning about the properties in the zones.

componenttext: Yes. Some of the changes that we're making are going to last, putting disposal water on pipe versus trucks, changing the lift in the wells. Those types of things should last. componenttext: The composition of the wells we're drilling is as oily as ever. I mean, you pointed out the quarter we had that Ramsey plant come back online in the quarter that had a big effect on gas production. But at the same time, as far as timing, when you slow down and you don't drill as much, over time the GORs go back up. But as we -- as our activity increases and we continue to build on what we're doing, I think it's going to certainly be within our guidance.

componenttext: Tim, I was wondering you gave us some outlook comments in terms of growth for 2016, '17. And I know you've held with that double-digit forecast, I think you provided that when oil was in the low 40s. So I was wondering if you could help us think about, given some of the well productivity gains, oil has moved a bit. Maybe help us think about what you think growth could be in '17. I think The Street's at 11% and perhaps, I don't know if you and Jack have thought about a 3- to 5-year kind of outlook for Concho, and if you think this double-digit type of growth level is sustainable over the next 3 to 5 years, within cash flows?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're always thinking about the long term, that's kind of how we built the company. We think it's important to be able to talk about how we can grow in the current circumstance with the current price forecast, the current efficiencies that we
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're always thinking about the long term, that's kind of how we built the company. We think it's important to be able to talk about how we can grow in the current circumstance with the current price forecast, the current efficiencies that we've gained on our wells and things like that and then try to make it better. And so I think that the areas we're in, the way we're structured, how our cost structure is set up, that we will, for the long-term, we'll be able to compete with anybody in the industry on growth. And we're very pleased to be able to talk about growth within cash flow. And in fact, we've been under spending cash flow for several quarters and still growing. So I think we're well-positioned. And our goal is always to surprise you to the upside.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Great. Great. And I did want to ask you a little bit about the Wolfcamp and some plans in the second half of '16. It sounded like you maybe doing some testing in the northern Delaware Basin. I was wondering if you could give us some thoughts on some of that delineation activity.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That Northern Delaware Basin, where you're talking about, I have some prepared comments on that and some of the best well results in the industry. And I think our acreage is well-positioned up there and most of our activity has been in the Avalon that we
componenttext: That Northern Delaware Basin, where you're talking about, I have some prepared comments on that and some of the best well results in the industry. And I think our acreage is well-positioned up there and most of our activity has been in the Avalon that we talked about. But we are drilling Wolfcamp and that's a real great area. We feel very encouraged by the well results.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Tim, do you plan to have some specific well results in the back half of this year? Or this maybe bleed in to '17?
componenttext: And, Tim, do you plan to have some specific well results in the back half of this year? Or this maybe bleed in to '17?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It will probably bleed into '17 to get 30 days of production history and have enough data that we think is meaningful.
componenttext: Yes. It will probably bleed into '17 to get 30 days of production history and have enough data that we think is meaningful.

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeb Bachmann of Scotia Howard Weil.

componenttext: Jim, just going back to the Avalon quickly. Can you remind us how much of your Lea County acreage you think is going to be perspective for that zone?

componenttext: Yes. Jeb, we've kind of talked about it in terms of inventory and we're in that oily Avalon, we're probably 750 wells. But the overall Avalon inventory is much larger than that.

componenttext: It's a very thick zone, over 1,000 feet. We've only talked about the upper and the lower -- or actually 2 zones at this point.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess last one for me, on -- a question every quarter on M&A. Just wondering where you guys are seeing the best value right now or in the basin, either side?
componenttext: Okay. And I guess last one for me, on -- a question every quarter on M&A. Just wondering where you guys are seeing the best value right now or in the basin, either side?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, there's both the Delaware Basin and the Midland Basin really have some outstanding results. And there are opportunities in both basins, and I think we find the best opportunities in areas that are in and around our core and areas that give us oppo
componenttext: I mean, there's both the Delaware Basin and the Midland Basin really have some outstanding results. And there are opportunities in both basins, and I think we find the best opportunities in areas that are in and around our core and areas that give us opportunities to drill long laterals and get the efficiencies you get from being a large operator with pad drilling and lots of activity.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the Southern Delaware, can you add more color on the Bone Spring 3, how far south do you think that could extend, and in future testing, including any spacing test?
componenttext: In the Southern Delaware, can you add more color on the Bone Spring 3, how far south do you think that could extend, and in future testing, including any spacing test?

componenttextpreview: We've talked about the Southern Delaware a lot. As far as having rock characteristics that are similar to the North, and we've highlighted that North Harpoon area is kind of the core of the core. And we feel really good about the prospectivity there. And
componenttext: We've talked about the Southern Delaware a lot. As far as having rock characteristics that are similar to the North, and we've highlighted that North Harpoon area is kind of the core of the core. And we feel really good about the prospectivity there. And then as you move south, we're just going to have to test more to get more data on this extent down to the south.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so what are your next steps, further delineate the south of the Harpoon area? Or try to drill more within that area and try to figure the spacing and development plan?
componenttext: And so what are your next steps, further delineate the south of the Harpoon area? Or try to drill more within that area and try to figure the spacing and development plan?

componenttext: Yes, Brian, we're going to continue in that area for the remainder of this year. And then, as Tim said, look to expand beyond that after this year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, can you talk a bit more about the Midland opportunity from here? You highlighted in your comments the efficiency gains that you could see. If we look at the well rates adjusted for lateral length, it seems the Delaware Basin is so much lar
componenttext: Okay. And then, can you talk a bit more about the Midland opportunity from here? You highlighted in your comments the efficiency gains that you could see. If we look at the well rates adjusted for lateral length, it seems the Delaware Basin is so much larger than the Midland Basin. I know you've been kind of testing the proppant loadings there. But I just wonder what your expectations are for where well rates adjusted for laterals can go, and whether you view the Midland rates of return as equal to or better than the Delaware?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have projects in the Midland Basin that compete well with the Delaware Basin, just like we do in the Mexico Shale. So -- and return is what we focus on. So I would just answer that by saying, all of the core areas have projects that compete we
componenttext: Well, we do have projects in the Midland Basin that compete well with the Delaware Basin, just like we do in the Mexico Shale. So -- and return is what we focus on. So I would just answer that by saying, all of the core areas have projects that compete well on a rate of return basis, Midland and Delaware.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so what would the -- would the efficiency gains that you talked to end up driving Midland basin returns to more widely be competitive with the Delaware? Or ultimately, where the Midland could exceed the Delaware? I'm just trying to think of kind of go
componenttext: And so what would the -- would the efficiency gains that you talked to end up driving Midland basin returns to more widely be competitive with the Delaware? Or ultimately, where the Midland could exceed the Delaware? I'm just trying to think of kind of going back to one of the earlier questions on capital allocation and thinking about that over the longer term.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the enhancements we've seen in the Midland Basin, namely water delivery system, ability to drill long laterals, have allowed that asset to compete with the Delaware. Going forward, when I look at the allocation this year, its about 25% to the
componenttext: Yes, I think the enhancements we've seen in the Midland Basin, namely water delivery system, ability to drill long laterals, have allowed that asset to compete with the Delaware. Going forward, when I look at the allocation this year, its about 25% to the Midland Basin. That's a pretty good proxy going forward. As Tim said, we're looking for a balance between the Midland Basin, the Southern Delaware and the Northern Delaware.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, a lot has been asked. So let me just go big picture. Oil sitting at $40, I know you guys had -- I guess, you're at 16 rigs and going to stay -- plans were to stay at that level for the rest of your -- I know you're hedged. But if we're $40 in 3, 4 mo
componenttext: Tim, a lot has been asked. So let me just go big picture. Oil sitting at $40, I know you guys had -- I guess, you're at 16 rigs and going to stay -- plans were to stay at that level for the rest of your -- I know you're hedged. But if we're $40 in 3, 4 months, does that change the way -- does that change the activity level? Or how should we frame that up?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, we've built our current plan around, as you've said, we are hedged, but we build it around kind of the current strip. So we're operating in an area that we kind of planned for when we put this together at the beginning of the year. So I think
componenttext: No, I mean, we've built our current plan around, as you've said, we are hedged, but we build it around kind of the current strip. So we're operating in an area that we kind of planned for when we put this together at the beginning of the year. So I think it's kind of steady as she goes, that's the way we'd characterize it when we started this. And I think the results and economics we're getting are okay at today's oil price.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I know you've talked about this probably a year ago, but when you start thinking about that at $100, before it was hey we get equivalent returns when oil is at $70 or $60 or whatever the number was on the way down. How should we think about fram
componenttext: Okay. And I know you've talked about this probably a year ago, but when you start thinking about that at $100, before it was hey we get equivalent returns when oil is at $70 or $60 or whatever the number was on the way down. How should we think about framing up returns? And I guess, in the current environment, with the service costs where they're at, what you've done on the operational efficiencies? I'm just trying to get a feel for where that breakeven number, how much that's come down for you guys over the last couple of years?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, one thing at Concho and the rest of the industry, we have really been focused on reducing our cost structure. And we had to do that because of the environment that we were in and what was happening with the cash margins. So we have gotten, we've h
componenttext: I mean, one thing at Concho and the rest of the industry, we have really been focused on reducing our cost structure. And we had to do that because of the environment that we were in and what was happening with the cash margins. So we have gotten, we've had great progress on LOE, G&A, just our total cost burden. And that's helped the economics of all the projects and the economics of the company. I think we told you before that one way Jack would characterize was that at $50, let see it was at $50, things worked -- $50 and above things worked really well, $40 to $50 things we're okay, and below $40, things weren't any good. And I'd tell you because of the efficiency gains and cost reductions and things like that, I think that whole scale has slid now $5 or $10.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: In the Southern Delaware, we've seen a number of large acquisitions within the industry recently. You guys actually had that -- a nice swap, I guess, late last year. componenttext: We just made a large acquisition in the first quarter there. And so it was a focus area for us. Yes, there are -- because of the power of long laterals down there, there are opportunities and reasons to block up your acreage.

componenttext: And then North Harpoon has been an area you guys have been focused on for a while. How much delineation do you have left? And are you focused more on optimizing your well design at this point since you should have, I think, a decent amount of well controlled?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I always would like to have more information. I think there's still a large amount of delineation, both aerially to find out where the boundaries are because it's -- we have limited amount of data and then how many zones are productive? And you can re
componenttext: No, I always would like to have more information. I think there's still a large amount of delineation, both aerially to find out where the boundaries are because it's -- we have limited amount of data and then how many zones are productive? And you can read anything, you can come up with as many zones as you want to come up with based on what you read in the press. And -- but frankly, we've gotten really good test results on 2 zones and we'll continue to test other zones.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if we can go over to the Midland Basin for a second. You mentioned spacing pilot in the Spraberry and Wolfcamp. Do you have other pilots planned this year to evaluate spacing across the position? That's just a very large position in the Midland Basin.
componenttext: And if we can go over to the Midland Basin for a second. You mentioned spacing pilot in the Spraberry and Wolfcamp. Do you have other pilots planned this year to evaluate spacing across the position? That's just a very large position in the Midland Basin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, this was an intense one that we were -- we thought was very interesting to talk about. But as we said in past quarters, almost everything we're doing is some sort of spacing test. And that's true for the Midland Basin, especially.
componenttext: Yes. Well, this was an intense one that we were -- we thought was very interesting to talk about. But as we said in past quarters, almost everything we're doing is some sort of spacing test. And that's true for the Midland Basin, especially.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
