componenttext: No, I don't really want to comment on a specific deal. I would tell you though that buying things every quarter and selling things every quarter is just kind of the way the machine works. So we ought to -- as we acquire things, we're going to be selling other parts of our portfolio to try to get more concentrated and cored up and that's just a normal part of our business.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And last one for me. It just sounds like you're still testing in most of the areas, is there anywhere in the portfolio that you'd say you're at full field development now, maybe that state line area there? Or you're still testing even t
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And last one for me. It just sounds like you're still testing in most of the areas, is there anywhere in the portfolio that you'd say you're at full field development now, maybe that state line area there? Or you're still testing even there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still testing all the areas. I mean, we have gotten better and better. The more wells we drilled, the more efficiency we've been able to get out of our program. But I think that will continue, I mean, the experimentation will continue, new technolog
componenttext: We're still testing all the areas. I mean, we have gotten better and better. The more wells we drilled, the more efficiency we've been able to get out of our program. But I think that will continue, I mean, the experimentation will continue, new technology will continue, trying new things all the time, it's been really encouraging. And I think when somebody starts to say that they've got to crack the code and they got it figured out, that's a sign of danger. So we've continued to get better and -- but I expect every year that we'll show some sorts of improvements.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Kelly of Seaport Global.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Kelly of Seaport Global.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Concho was early on recognizing the potential merits of the Southern Delaware Basin, it seems like the rest of the industry's catching up 1 year, 1.5 years later. Tim, I'd love to get your thoughts early on just look across the entire Permian right now an
componenttext: Concho was early on recognizing the potential merits of the Southern Delaware Basin, it seems like the rest of the industry's catching up 1 year, 1.5 years later. Tim, I'd love to get your thoughts early on just look across the entire Permian right now and what areas and formations in your mind have the potential to exhibit the greatest positive rate of change if we look out 1 year, 1.5 years going forward now?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Delaware Basin, the entire Delaware Basin is still in early stages. We -- I mentioned we've drilled 600 horizontal wells in the north, that's probably the highest area of concentration of wells and information gathering and we're still learning
componenttext: Well, the Delaware Basin, the entire Delaware Basin is still in early stages. We -- I mentioned we've drilled 600 horizontal wells in the north, that's probably the highest area of concentration of wells and information gathering and we're still learning there. And I think there the Wolfcamp zone is -- hasn't been tested as much. It's probably more widespread than anybody recognizes, holds lots of upside potential. The Southern Delaware Basin is very early as far as getting enough information in wells to delineate all the productive zones. And so I think there's still a tremendous amount of work to be done there. And so we like the Delaware Basin and the top-tier areas of the Delaware Basin continue to grow. And the Midland Basin has -- there's lots of companies with lots of data and it's probably further along, industry's understanding of what works and what doesn't work and where the Wolfcamp works best, where the Spraberry works best. So in general I think for both the Midland Basin and the Delaware Basin, it's still early innings. And everybody's -- the number of wells that the companies are drilling have gone down. It's amazing to me that we have more rigs running in the Permian Basin, I think than, just about anybody. And we're only running 16. We were running almost 40 2 years ago. So it's -- lots of things have changed.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Good color. And then, secondly for me, just correct me if I'm wrong here, but on the long-term strategy, it seems like you guys have shifted somewhat to talk more about staying within cash flow and growth within cash flow. And I'm curious her
componenttext: Okay. Great. Good color. And then, secondly for me, just correct me if I'm wrong here, but on the long-term strategy, it seems like you guys have shifted somewhat to talk more about staying within cash flow and growth within cash flow. And I'm curious here, years past, you've had no problem outspending. And I'm curious what would get you to kind of go back to that mindset potentially look to outspend and push growth more?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would challenge you a little bit on the we have no problem outspending cash flow. Because I think that was a one-time moonshot kind of project where we saw our balance sheet was delevering naturally, acquisitions looked expensive and we announced that 2
componenttext: I would challenge you a little bit on the we have no problem outspending cash flow. Because I think that was a one-time moonshot kind of project where we saw our balance sheet was delevering naturally, acquisitions looked expensive and we announced that 2-by-3 plan where we could double production within 3 years. That was not kind of our normal way we operate, but those were the conditions at the time. And we had great success in that program. We were well on our way to achieving all those goals. Today, it just seems like in the kind of time we find ourselves in with the volatility, having a strong balance sheet, being able to demonstrate capital discipline and improving capital efficiency is the way you set yourself apart from the rest of the field. And that's what we're focused on and we think we can show really dramatic results staying within cash flow. And I think we can show growth that's going to be very well received.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Sullivan of Alembic Global Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Sullivan of Alembic Global Advisors.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just picking up on the last point about balance sheet. I mean, I'm just looking at various of your leverage metric continue to float down, I think, your total debt to flowing productions down like 20% year-on-year. Can you just update us on your thinking
componenttext: Just picking up on the last point about balance sheet. I mean, I'm just looking at various of your leverage metric continue to float down, I think, your total debt to flowing productions down like 20% year-on-year. Can you just update us on your thinking on investment grade? I know you guys have been very stable with the ratings agencies, been rewarded for your conservatism here. But what are the other metrics you guys are focused on? And is that on the front burner for you as you think about next couple of years?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the -- maintaining our rating in this environment, I think, is very positive and a recognition by the agencies of our business. In terms of investment grade, we think that will be a result of the way we run our business. And it depends on whi
componenttext: Yes. I think the -- maintaining our rating in this environment, I think, is very positive and a recognition by the agencies of our business. In terms of investment grade, we think that will be a result of the way we run our business. And it depends on which one you're talking to, the absolute size and reserve base is a big factor. But again I think it would just be a result of the way that we run our business.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. And just kind of to follow up on that. I know that one of the things that maybe have been an obstacle or a roadblock have been "asset diversity". I know you guys think about yourselves as operating in 3 different areas, and maybe some p
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And just kind of to follow up on that. I know that one of the things that maybe have been an obstacle or a roadblock have been "asset diversity". I know you guys think about yourselves as operating in 3 different areas, and maybe some people look at you as Permian only and that kind of thing. Is that still a concern? Or how does that evolve if at all?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's certainly not a concern of ours. We have 4 core areas in the Permian across several hundred miles. So we feel like it's plenty of diversity.
componenttext: It's certainly not a concern of ours. We have 4 core areas in the Permian across several hundred miles. So we feel like it's plenty of diversity.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add that the Permian's a big place and it wasn't that long ago that our biggest concern about the Permian was just takeaway capacity. And that has been solved and with our ability to export crude oil and our access to different markets.
componenttext: Yes. I would just add that the Permian's a big place and it wasn't that long ago that our biggest concern about the Permian was just takeaway capacity. And that has been solved and with our ability to export crude oil and our access to different markets.  We think if you're going to be -- have concentrated assets, the Permian's the place you want them concentrated.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That absolutely makes sense. So just real quick then, you sort of alluded to this in an answer to another question, but as I look at your '17 program. You guys talk about doing it within cash flow. And I think your weighted average floor price per hedge i
componenttext: That absolutely makes sense. So just real quick then, you sort of alluded to this in an answer to another question, but as I look at your '17 program. You guys talk about doing it within cash flow. And I think your weighted average floor price per hedge is about $55 there and I show you guys at just about breakeven there. But it sounds like you guys are saying that with the cost structure coming down, maybe you're unhedged company-wide, cash flow breakeven point might be kind of coming down below $55, maybe to $50 or even high 40s. Is that the right way to think about that?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's a fair assessment, yes.
componenttext: I think that's a fair assessment, yes.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Derrick Whitfield with GMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Derrick Whitfield with GMP Securities.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tim, just building on your Southern Delaware comments. We've heard from industry, including Anadarko, this quarter the potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would be interested in your take on how you would frame that? And how you currently rank your 2 del
componenttext: So Tim, just building on your Southern Delaware comments. We've heard from industry, including Anadarko, this quarter the potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would be interested in your take on how you would frame that? And how you currently rank your 2 delineated intervals in terms of returns?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't argue that there's potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would say that we've tested 2 of them with good results and high productivity. And it's -- so I think the opportunities that are being identified by industry within the Southern Delaware Basi
componenttext: I wouldn't argue that there's potential for 4 to 8 intervals. I would say that we've tested 2 of them with good results and high productivity. And it's -- so I think the opportunities that are being identified by industry within the Southern Delaware Basin, within the Delaware Basin, we certainly agree with.  It's just one thing to talk about potential and then another thing to talk about well results and success.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just in terms of how you rank your 2 delineated intervals to date in terms of returns?
componenttext: And then just in terms of how you rank your 2 delineated intervals to date in terms of returns?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: They're both very good. I wouldn't say that we would prefer one over the other based on returns. It's just one is -- the Upper Wolfcamp was the first thing we started developing, it was the deepest zone that we've started developing and had good results i
componenttext: They're both very good. I wouldn't say that we would prefer one over the other based on returns. It's just one is -- the Upper Wolfcamp was the first thing we started developing, it was the deepest zone that we've started developing and had good results in. And now we've got 2, and I think that will continue to expand.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, lastly, regarding the Avalon. Any view on how much of your inventory could be developed through longer laterals?
componenttext: Great. And then, lastly, regarding the Avalon. Any view on how much of your inventory could be developed through longer laterals?

componenttextpreview: Yes. We have probably about 1/4 of that inventory that I've mentioned earlier has long lateral potential.
componenttext: Yes. We have probably about 1/4 of that inventory that I've mentioned earlier has long lateral potential.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Inc. Q2 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Megan Hays. You may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Concho's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.Our second quarter earnings release and
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and welcome to Concho's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our second quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website. Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectations this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. Forward-looking statement and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in the earnings release and corporate presentation and can be found at Concho's website.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. The second quarter of 2016 was a good one. Once again, it illustrates the power of our assets, the excellent commitment of our people. While the macro environment is dynamic, we're extending our tr
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks for joining us on this busy morning. The second quarter of 2016 was a good one. Once again, it illustrates the power of our assets, the excellent commitment of our people. While the macro environment is dynamic, we're extending our track record of working all angles within our business to deliver strong operational and financial performance and position the company for the future. Our performance this quarter highlights our ongoing drive to improve capital efficiency, with a relentless focus on asset performance, cost savings and capital discipline. 
Let me start by summarizing the key achievements for the quarter. Second quarter production increased 4% over the previous quarter and exceeded the high end of our guidance. For 2016, we now expect our annual production to show growth, while maintaining our capital budget guidance and underspending cash flow. Our outlook for double-digit production growth in 2017 also remains unchanged and in some ways, improves. Double-digit growth in '17 off a higher production base and a capital program defined by our cash flow at the current strip will be a unique achievement, reflecting the operational momentum and improving capital productivity across our assets. 
For the first half of 2016, lease operating expenses averaged approximately $6.50 per barrel, a 12% reduction compared to LOE in the second half of '15. The decrease in LOE reflects specific actions we're taking to generate sustainable operational efficiencies. 
We're making substantial progress in several areas. For example, there's an asset-wide focus on transporting water disposal volumes by pipe rather than truck, which is more efficient and reduces transportation cost. In addition, our efforts to optimize production and field development that reduce pumping cost. High-grading our inventory also contributes to lower LOE as we acquire assets complementary to our core positions and infrastructure, while we're selling lower returning properties. 
As a result of ongoing improvements in operations, we've reduced our cost guidance for LOE to $6.75 per barrel at the midpoint. We also reduced our guidance for both cash and noncash G&A per barrel. Aggressively managing our cost structure, combined with strong asset performance, accelerates capital productivity gains, which increasingly enables us to do more with less. 
In addition to delivering strong production volumes and reducing operating cost, we underspent cash flow for the fourth consecutive quarter, which further strengthened our balance sheet. Our commitment to capital discipline and a strong balance sheet provides us with opportunities to generate differentiated value for our shareholders. The most impactful way we can affect the value of Concho is by becoming even more efficient, and we're focused on improving the productivity of each capital dollar invested. Each of our core areas is contributing to improved capital productivity.
In the Northern Delaware Basin, where we've drilled more than 600 horizontal wells, our drilling team still finds ways to set new records. For example, in the second quarter, average drilling days improved to 19, smashing the prior record by 3 days. We're also advancing the oil-rich Avalon Shale in Lea County, where continued improvement is a direct result of refining lateral placement and completion techniques. 
This quarter, we highlighted early results from the density test on the Monet wells and this appears on Slide 9 of the earnings presentation. These 4 wells targeted the upper Avalon zone on 80 acre spacing, with a specific focus on optimizing the fluid system and sand volumes. We're excited about the outstanding performance of these wells as we move into development mode. 
The Red Hills area in Lea County is an area where we've targeted bolt on acquisitions for long lateral development. During the second half of the year, we plan to drill several long lateral wells, targeting the Avalon, and we'll look to replicate our success in the Wolfcamp where we believe significant upside exists. 
In the southern Delaware Basin, we closed the acquisition of 12,000 net acres in our core North Harpoon area at the end of the first quarter. We've added 2 drilling rigs to this acreage at the start of the second quarter, illustrating that anything we bring into the portfolio must be ready to move to the front of the drilling program. 
In the Southern Delaware, we continued to deliver industry-leading well results in the Upper Wolfcamp, while continuing to test multi-zone potential. We recently achieved strong results from a third Bone Spring well with plans to drill additional third Bone Spring wells before the end of the year. 
We're also quickly advancing our play in the Midland Basin. The Midland Basin represents our largest opportunity to capture efficiencies as we focus on 2-mile laterals and multi-well pad development. Our efforts to optimize development and maximize the value of this project are ongoing. The 9 wells we added this quarter were drilled to a shorter lateral length, which is primarily a function of timing. We drilled these wells in 2015 and our to shift to 2-mile laterals began at the start of this year. We also tested smaller frac jobs on these wells, which provided us valuable information about cost versus well performance that we can use to improve future well economics. 
For the balance of the year, our completion techniques will focus on large profit concentrations. We're currently completing an 8-well density test with 4 wells targeting the Lower Spraberry and 4 wells targeting the Wolfcamp B. These completions will utilize profit concentrations of approximately 2,000 pounds per foot. 
The New Mexico Shelf continues to outperform. During the quarter, well results for the shelf set another record, the second in as many quarters. With just 2 rigs running here, we've managed to advance horizontal development of the play and maintain stable production from year-end '15 volumes. 
Our strategy and diversity within the Permian are unique and give us our greatest competitive advantage. We have the ability to allocate capital across our assets and leverage our scale and technical expertise to enhance returns and recoveries. And our relentless focus on improving capital efficiency will have an ever increasing impact on Concho. It will we enable us to drive profitable debt-adjusted growth per share in the near and long-term. 
The acquisition market surrounding our core areas is also setting new records and it's nice to have assets in the hottest ZIP Codes in the industry. We currently have the largest and highest quality inventory in our history. Our consolidation activity must compete with our top-tier drilling inventory and strengthen our financial position. While it's a target-rich environment, we will continue to take a disciplined approach in pursuing the right acquisitions to build for the future. 
Sentiment is positive among our industry peers and optimism is a driving force in our industry. At Concho, there's a lot to be excited about. But the outlook for commodity prices isn't much different since the last quarterly update. As a result, we maintain our commitment to spend within cash flow. The momentum we're generating reinforces our 2017 outlook for double-digit production growth, while balancing capital and cash flow within the current price outlook. 
The mission of Concho has always been to build something unique, to build a leading energy company that excels in any environment, that creates shareholder value by investing capital in the best assets with the highest returns, that consistently seeks to improve performance and drive profitable growth per share. 
Our vision for delivering on this mission today is simple, we believe that we can be the best by executing a disciplined capital program, delivering operational excellence and high-grading our investment opportunities. Our track record of performance combined with focus and disciplined execution of our strategy will enable us to generate value for our shareholders for many years to come. 
Thanks for listening and let me turn it back over to the moderator and take your questions.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: No. I think one of the things that I was referring to in the comments is that all of our core areas are delivering really good economics for us right now. So I think the capital allocation that you see today would be a balanced approach going forward. So I think you ought to just expect us to continue to allocate capital based on returns and also in areas where we're testing new ideas.

componenttext: Got it. And maybe just a follow-up on that. The new ideas, in the Midland, you discussed the proppants you guys are testing. But maybe when you talk about testing, well spacing and development patterns, can you just frame for us what the existing configurations, are and what the concepts are that you guys are testing there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's different depending on which zone you're talking about. But in general, when we talk about density test, when we talk about our inventory and things like that, we're still 8 wells per section in general. So it's not as dense as some of our peers
componenttext: Yes. It's different depending on which zone you're talking about. But in general, when we talk about density test, when we talk about our inventory and things like that, we're still 8 wells per section in general. So it's not as dense as some of our peers are talking. But the test involve testing spacing, but also the configuration of wells in the zone, whether it's a line rack or a Chevron pattern or something like that. Also, lateral length and proppant and concentrate -- there's big experimentation going on as we've discussed in the past. And I think we've got more data and running 16 rigs is one of the leaders in the industry. So we're gathering data more quickly than most.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I wanted to go back a little bit on the proppant loading. I'm just curious, you made the point, Tim, early in the prepared remarks that you do have a unique view on the Permian Basin, given the asset base you have really straddles all the differe
componenttext: I guess, I wanted to go back a little bit on the proppant loading. I'm just curious, you made the point, Tim, early in the prepared remarks that you do have a unique view on the Permian Basin, given the asset base you have really straddles all the different areas. What sort of variation in proppant loading response are you seeing across the different areas? Or are some areas more sensitive to proppant loading than others? And I'm just curious what other sort of color you all can provide in that context?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we've gotten as low, I think, as about 1,000 pounds per foot and now we're testing loading at over 2,000 pounds per foot. And as I mentioned on the call, it's -- or in my prepared remarks, it's different by zone and you're trying to balance t
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we've gotten as low, I think, as about 1,000 pounds per foot and now we're testing loading at over 2,000 pounds per foot. And as I mentioned on the call, it's -- or in my prepared remarks, it's different by zone and you're trying to balance that versus drainage versus the type of fracs you're getting and the well spacing and configuration that you have. So -- and as you mentioned, we have so many zones in so many of the sub basins that every answer's a little bit different. And generally, of course, the higher the sand loading, the bigger the wells. But that doesn't necessarily mean you're optimizing the economics that way. So we've been running experiments on how do we get the best capital efficiency of long laterals really is driving the answer. And then I mentioned a placement in the zone and fluid composition, things like that. So it's a complex experiment, but I would tell you that the results have been very encouraging in all our areas. And we think we can continue to drive efficiency through the things we're learning about the properties in the zones.

componenttext: Yes. Some of the changes that we're making are going to last, putting disposal water on pipe versus trucks, changing the lift in the wells. Those types of things should last. Cost of goods and services we know move up when there's pressure. But we think some of the important factors are sustainable.

componenttext: The composition of the wells we're drilling is as oily as ever. I mean, you pointed out the quarter we had that Ramsey plant come back online in the quarter that had a big effect on gas production. But at the same time, as far as timing, when you slow down and you don't drill as much, over time the GORs go back up. But as we -- as our activity increases and we continue to build on what we're doing, I think it's going to certainly be within our guidance.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Arun Jayaram of JPMorgan.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, I was wondering you gave us some outlook comments in terms of growth for 2016, '17. And I know you've held with that double-digit forecast, I think you provided that when oil was in the low 40s. So I was wondering if you could help us think about, gi
componenttext: Tim, I was wondering you gave us some outlook comments in terms of growth for 2016, '17. And I know you've held with that double-digit forecast, I think you provided that when oil was in the low 40s. So I was wondering if you could help us think about, given some of the well productivity gains, oil has moved a bit, maybe help us think about what you think growth could be in '17. I think The Street's at 11% and perhaps, I don't know if you and Jack have thought about a 3- to 5-year kind of outlook for Concho, and if you think this double-digit type of growth level is sustainable over the next 3 to 5 years, within cash flows?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're always thinking about the long term, that's kind of how we built the company. We think it's important to be able to talk about how we can grow in the current circumstance with the current price forecast, the current efficiencies that we
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're always thinking about the long term, that's kind of how we built the company. We think it's important to be able to talk about how we can grow in the current circumstance with the current price forecast, the current efficiencies that we've gained on our wells and things like that and then try to make it better. And so I think that the areas we're in, the way we're structured, how our cost structure is set up, that we will, for the long-term, we'll be able to compete with anybody in the industry on growth. And we're very pleased to be able to talk about growth within cash flow. And in fact, we've been under spending cash flow for several quarters and still growing. So I think we're well-positioned. And our goal is always to surprise you to the upside.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Great. And I did want to ask you a little bit about the Wolfcamp and some plans in the second half of '16. It sounded like you may be doing some testing in the northern Delaware Basin. I was wondering if you could give us some thoughts on some of t
componenttext: Great. Great. And I did want to ask you a little bit about the Wolfcamp and some plans in the second half of '16. It sounded like you may be doing some testing in the northern Delaware Basin. I was wondering if you could give us some thoughts on some of that delineation activity.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That Northern Delaware Basin, where you're talking about, I have some prepared comments on that. It's some of the best well results in the industry. And I think our acreage is well-positioned up there and most of our activity has been in the Avalon that w
componenttext: That Northern Delaware Basin, where you're talking about, I have some prepared comments on that. It's some of the best well results in the industry. And I think our acreage is well-positioned up there and most of our activity has been in the Avalon that we talked about. But we are drilling Wolfcamp and that's a real great area. We feel very encouraged by the well results.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Tim, do you plan to have some specific well results in the back half of this year? Or this may be a bleed in to '17?
componenttext: And Tim, do you plan to have some specific well results in the back half of this year? Or this may be a bleed in to '17?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. It will probably bleed into '17 to get 30 days of production history and have enough data that we think is meaningful.

componenttext: It's a very thick zone, over 1,000 feet. We've only talked about the upper and the lower -- or actually 2 zones at this point.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And I guess last one for me, on -- a question every quarter on M&A. Just wondering where you guys are seeing the best value right now or in the basin, either side?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, there's both the Delaware Basin and the Midland Basin really have some outstanding results. And there are opportunities in both basins, and I think we find the best opportunities in areas that are in and around our core and areas that give us oppo
componenttext: I mean, there's both the Delaware Basin and the Midland Basin really have some outstanding results. And there are opportunities in both basins, and I think we find the best opportunities in areas that are in and around our core and areas that give us opportunities to drill long laterals and get the efficiencies you get from being a large operator with pad drilling and lots of activity.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Singer of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: In the Southern Delaware, can you add more color on the Bone Spring 3, how far south do you think that could extend, and in future testing, including any spacing test?

componenttext: We've talked about the Southern Delaware a lot. As far as having rock characteristics that are similar to the North, and we've highlighted that North Harpoon area is kind of the core of the core. And we feel really good about the prospectivity there. And then as you move south, we're just going to have to test more to get more data on this extent down to the south.

componenttext: And so what are your next steps, further delineate the south of the Harpoon area? Or try to drill more within that area and try to figure the spacing and development plan?

componenttext: Yes, Brian, we're going to continue in that area for the remainder of this year. And then, as Tim said, look to expand beyond that after this year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, can you talk a bit more about the Midland opportunity from here? You highlighted in your comments the efficiency gains that you could see. If we look at the well rates adjusted for lateral length, it seems the Delaware Basin is so much lar
componenttext: Okay. And then, can you talk a bit more about the Midland opportunity from here? You highlighted in your comments the efficiency gains that you could see. If we look at the well rates adjusted for lateral length, it seems the Delaware Basin is so much larger than the Midland Basin. I know you've been kind of testing the proppant loadings there. But I just wonder what your expectations are for where well rates adjusted for laterals can go, and whether you view the Midland rates of return as equal to or better than the Delaware?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we do have projects in the Midland Basin that compete well with the Delaware Basin, just like we do in the New Mexico Shelf. So -- and return is what we focus on. So I would just answer that by saying, all of the core areas have projects that compet
componenttext: Well, we do have projects in the Midland Basin that compete well with the Delaware Basin, just like we do in the New Mexico Shelf. So -- and return is what we focus on. So I would just answer that by saying, all of the core areas have projects that compete well on a rate of return basis, Midland and Delaware.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so what would the -- would the efficiency gains that you talked to end up driving Midland basin returns to more widely be competitive with the Delaware? Or ultimately, where the Midland could exceed the Delaware? I'm just trying to think of kind of go
componenttext: And so what would the -- would the efficiency gains that you talked to end up driving Midland basin returns to more widely be competitive with the Delaware? Or ultimately, where the Midland could exceed the Delaware? I'm just trying to think of kind of going back to one of the earlier questions on capital allocation and thinking about that over the longer term.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the enhancements we've seen in the Midland Basin, namely water delivery system, ability to drill long laterals, have allowed that asset to compete with the Delaware. Going forward, when I look at the allocation this year, it’s about 25% to
componenttext: Yes, I think the enhancements we've seen in the Midland Basin, namely water delivery system, ability to drill long laterals, have allowed that asset to compete with the Delaware. Going forward, when I look at the allocation this year, it’s about 25% to the Midland Basin. That's a pretty good proxy going forward. As Tim said, we're looking for a balance between the Midland Basin, the Southern Delaware and the Northern Delaware.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Tameron of Wells Fargo.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, a lot has been asked. So let me just go big picture. Oil is sitting at $40, I know you guys had -- I guess, you're at 16 rigs and going to stay -- plans were to stay at that level for the rest of your -- I know you're hedged. But if we're $40 in 3, 4
componenttext: Tim, a lot has been asked. So let me just go big picture. Oil is sitting at $40, I know you guys had -- I guess, you're at 16 rigs and going to stay -- plans were to stay at that level for the rest of your -- I know you're hedged. But if we're $40 in 3, 4 months, does that change the way -- does that change the activity level? Or how should we frame that up?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, we've built our current plan around, as you've said, we are hedged, but we build it around kind of the current strip. So we're operating in an area that we kind of planned for when we put this together at the beginning of the year. So I think
componenttext: No, I mean, we've built our current plan around, as you've said, we are hedged, but we build it around kind of the current strip. So we're operating in an area that we kind of planned for when we put this together at the beginning of the year. So I think it's kind of steady as she goes, that's the way we'd characterize it when we started this. And I think the results and economics we're getting are okay at today's oil price.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I know you've talked about this probably a year ago, but when you start thinking about that at $100, before it was hey we get equivalent returns when oil is at $70 or $60 or whatever the number was on the way down. How should we think about fram
componenttext: Okay. And I know you've talked about this probably a year ago, but when you start thinking about that at $100, before it was hey we get equivalent returns when oil is at $70 or $60 or whatever the number was on the way down. How should we think about framing up returns? And I guess, in the current environment, with the service costs where they're at, what you've done on the operational efficiencies? I'm just trying to get a feel for where that breakeven number, how much that's come down for you guys over the last couple of years?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, one thing at Concho and the rest of the industry, we have really been focused on reducing our cost structure. And we had to do that because of the environment that we were in and what was happening with the cash margins. So we have gotten, we've h
componenttext: I mean, one thing at Concho and the rest of the industry, we have really been focused on reducing our cost structure. And we had to do that because of the environment that we were in and what was happening with the cash margins. So we have gotten, we've had great progress on LOE, G&A, just our total cost burden. And that's helped the economics of all the projects and the economics of the company. I think we told you before that one way Jack would characterize was that at $50, let see it was at $50, things worked -- $50 and above things worked really well, $40 to $50 things were okay, and below $40, things weren't any good. And I'd tell you because of the efficiency gains and cost reductions and things like that, I think that whole scale has slid now $5 or $10.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: And then North Harpoon has been an area you guys have been focused on for a while. How much delineation do you have left? And are you focused more on optimizing your well design at this point since you should have, I think, a decent amount of well control?

componenttextpreview: No, I always would like to have more information. I think there's still a large amount of delineation, both aerially to find out where the boundaries are because it's -- we have limited amount of data and then how many zones are productive? And you can re
componenttext: No, I always would like to have more information. I think there's still a large amount of delineation, both aerially to find out where the boundaries are because it's -- we have limited amount of data and then how many zones are productive? And you can read anything, you can come up with as many zones as you want to come up with based on what you read in the press. And -- but frankly, we've gotten really good test results on 2 zones and we'll continue to test other zones.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if we can go over to the Midland Basin for a second. You mentioned spacing pilot in the Spraberry and Wolfcamp. Do you have other pilots planned this year to evaluate spacing across the position? That's just a very large position in the Midland Basin.
componenttext: And if we can go over to the Midland Basin for a second. You mentioned spacing pilot in the Spraberry and Wolfcamp. Do you have other pilots planned this year to evaluate spacing across the position? That's just a very large position in the Midland Basin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, this was an intense one that we were -- we thought was very interesting to talk about. But as we said in past quarters, almost everything we're doing is some sort of spacing test. And that's true for the Midland Basin, especially.
componenttext: Yes. Well, this was an intense one that we were -- we thought was very interesting to talk about. But as we said in past quarters, almost everything we're doing is some sort of spacing test. And that's true for the Midland Basin, especially.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: On Slide 4, I found it interesting that production declined less in the first quarter of '16 on 10 fewer wells, then it increased in the second quarter '16 on only 5 additional wells. And I'm just wondering if you could discuss that a little bit. I was thinking maybe larger working interest or a stronger well performance, longer laterals or something else, I thought it was pretty striking.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it was just the timing of the completion and the style of wells. I wouldn't read a whole lot into that. We've had a pretty steady amount of activity in the first half of the year.
componenttext: Yes. I think it was just the timing of the completion and the style of wells. I wouldn't read a whole lot into that. We've had a pretty steady amount of activity in the first half of the year.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. On Slide 8, the 3 primary Northern Delaware targets. I'm just wondering how much per pad multi-zone potential do you have in your current development plans. Or put it in another way, what percentage of it maybe just attacking one zone versus the abi
componenttext: Okay. On Slide 8, the 3 primary Northern Delaware targets. I'm just wondering how much per pad multi-zone potential do you have in your current development plans. Or put it in another way, what percentage of it maybe just attacking one zone versus the ability to attack maybe more than one zone on a pad.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in general for the year, more than half of our wells are going to be drilled on pads. Some of those will be drilling wells in the same zones and some of those will be drilling wells in either 2 zones or multiple members of one zone. So it's all ac
componenttext: Yes. So in general for the year, more than half of our wells are going to be drilled on pads. Some of those will be drilling wells in the same zones and some of those will be drilling wells in either 2 zones or multiple members of one zone. So it's all across-the-board.

componenttext: Yes. We have a couple of rigs running in that area now. We've drilled as many wells as anybody in that area. So we're just continuing our work in that part of the Southern Delaware.

componenttext: Okay. componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Neal Dingmann of SunTrust.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Say, Jack, or for Tim, maybe, when you guys look at sort of drilling further going forward, I guess, for '17, how do you think -- you didn't mention on HPP, is that an issue, Tim? Or is it mostly just pure return basis as you were talking about allocation
componenttext: Say, Jack, or for Tim, maybe, when you guys look at sort of drilling further going forward, I guess, for '17, how do you think -- you didn't mention on HPP, is that an issue, Tim? Or is it mostly just pure return basis as you were talking about allocation?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's becoming less of an issue over time. It wasn't much of an issue this year. We've talked about in the past how the Midland Basin was pretty much held by production. And there was a portion of our capital budget that was kind of obligation-type thing
componenttext: That's becoming less of an issue over time. It wasn't much of an issue this year. We've talked about in the past how the Midland Basin was pretty much held by production. And there was a portion of our capital budget that was kind of obligation-type things we had to do, but it becomes much smaller over time.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, just lastly, you didn't mention kind of a return basis. I mean, obviously, like the Avalon after the density test and some of the returns you're getting, other parts of the Northern and Southern Delaware as well as the Midland. Does -- I t
componenttext: Okay. And then, just lastly, you didn't mention kind of a return basis. I mean, obviously, like the Avalon after the density test and some of the returns you're getting, other parts of the Northern and Southern Delaware as well as the Midland. Does -- I think Jack mentioned this, but I just want to kind of circle back to this because the New Mexico Shelf, with those 30-day rates of just sub-500 is because of the cost? Or did the returns compete there with the other 3 plays? Is that why you're still running the rigs there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The returns are really good, the cost are low. I think the cost there was like $2.5 million a well or something like that. And so those returns compete with anything we're doing. And we just don't have as big an inventory on the shelf as we do in oth
componenttext: Yes. The returns are really good, the cost are low. I think the cost there was like $2.5 million a well or something like that. And so those returns compete with anything we're doing. And we just don't have as big an inventory on the shelf as we do in other places and it's all held by production, it's a great asset.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Tim, you did mention, I think, it's Slide 7, it shows how much costs have come down since first quarter of '15, it's pretty amazing. Is that now on a go forward, I mean, can we think of that continuing in most areas? I mean, I guess, what I'm al
componenttext: And then, Tim, you did mention, I think, it's Slide 7, it shows how much costs have come down since first quarter of '15, it's pretty amazing. Is that now on a go forward, I mean, can we think of that continuing in most areas? I mean, I guess, what I'm alluding to is just basically service costs versus efficiencies. Do you see cost improvements still increasing? And if so -- or is cost still decreasing? And if so, is that more because of continued service costs declining a bit more? Is that more just efficiencies?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the majority of cost savings going forward is going to be efficiencies and not -- and service cost providers reducing the cost per specific items. We still have continued to experience lower cost from the service industry. The rig count hit a bott
componenttext: I think the majority of cost savings going forward is going to be efficiencies and not -- and service cost providers reducing the cost per specific items. We still have continued to experience lower cost from the service industry. The rig count hit a bottom in the Permian Basin of, I think, like 130 or 140 rigs and now it's up to 190. So we've seen some increase in activity out here. But at the same time, the Permian Basin's kind of where everybody wants to be. So there's been equipment and people moving in here from other basins. So I think we've got plenty of spare capacity in all respects. And so I don't think we feel any cost pressure on the upside and there may still be some room to move lower.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Deckelbaum of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was curious if you could provide us with any color on as you go ahead into '17, you've talked sort of about the double digits within cash flow staying within cash flow. What should we expect in terms of a progression of lateral length in your current de
componenttext: I was curious if you could provide us with any color on as you go ahead into '17, you've talked sort of about the double digits within cash flow staying within cash flow. What should we expect in terms of a progression of lateral length in your current designs? Or is that sort of conversation and that guidance is that more based on the current lateral lengths that you're drilling with?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's based on the current lateral length. We have found substantial efficiencies in drilling 2-mile laterals everywhere we can. So where we have the least configurations in the blocky acreage, you will see those kind of lateral lengths and it's predominan
componenttext: It's based on the current lateral length. We have found substantial efficiencies in drilling 2-mile laterals everywhere we can. So where we have the least configurations in the blocky acreage, you will see those kind of lateral lengths and it's predominantly in the Southern Delaware Basin and in the Midland Basin. But the double-digit production growth that we're talking about is kind of within the system that we see today for how we configure our wells and how we drill them.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you just remind me, or I'm not sure if you've provided this before, but roughly what percentage of your overall acreage, at least in the Delaware, is amenable to the 2-mile laterals?
componenttext: And can you just remind me, or I'm not sure if you've provided this before, but roughly what percentage of your overall acreage, at least in the Delaware, is amenable to the 2-mile laterals?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's -- you can kind of look at the map. It's in the Southern Delaware is where the majority of that ability would be. In the Northern, I think you will see us try to move the lateral length up, but we're talking hundreds of feet there of increase,
componenttext: David, it's -- you can kind of look at the map. It's in the Southern Delaware is where the majority of that ability would be. In the Northern, I think you will see us try to move the lateral length up, but we're talking hundreds of feet there of increase, not thousands, like you could see in the Southern.

componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. And last one for me. It just sounds like you're still testing in most of the areas, is there anywhere in the portfolio that you'd say you're at full field development now, maybe that state line area there? Or you're still testing even there?

componenttext: We're still testing all the areas. I mean, we have gotten better and better. The more wells we drilled, the more efficiency we've been able to get out of our program. But I think that will continue, I mean, the experimentation will continue, new technology will continue, trying new things all the time, it's been really encouraging. And I think when somebody starts to say that they've got to crack the code and they got it figured out, that's a sign of danger. So we've continued to get better and -- but I expect every year that we'll show some sorts of improvements.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Concho was early on recognizing the potential merits of the Southern Delaware Basin, it seems like the rest of the industry's catching up 1 year, 1.5 years later. Tim, I'd love to get your thoughts early on just look across the entire Permian right now an
componenttext: Concho was early on recognizing the potential merits of the Southern Delaware Basin, it seems like the rest of the industry's catching up 1 year, 1.5 years later. Tim, I'd love to get your thoughts early on just look across the entire Permian right now and what areas and formations in your mind have the potential to exhibit the greatest positive rate of change if we look out 1 year, 1.5 years going forward now?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the Delaware Basin, the entire Delaware Basin is still in early stages. We -- I mentioned we've drilled 600 horizontal wells in the north, that's probably the highest area of concentration of wells and information gathering and we're still learning
componenttext: Well, the Delaware Basin, the entire Delaware Basin is still in early stages. We -- I mentioned we've drilled 600 horizontal wells in the north, that's probably the highest area of concentration of wells and information gathering and we're still learning there. And I think there the Wolfcamp zone is -- hasn't been tested as much. It's probably more widespread than anybody recognizes, holds lots of upside potential. The Southern Delaware Basin is very early as far as getting enough information in wells to delineate all the productive zones. And so I think there's still a tremendous amount of work to be done there. And so we like the Delaware Basin and the top-tier areas of the Delaware Basin continue to grow. And the Midland Basin has -- there's lots of companies with lots of data and it's probably further along, industry's understanding of what works and what doesn't work and where the Wolfcamp works best, where the Spraberry works best. So in general I think for both the Midland Basin and the Delaware Basin, it's still early innings. And everybody's -- the number of wells that the companies are drilling have gone down. It's amazing to me that we have more rigs running in the Permian Basin, I think than, just about anybody. And we're only running 16. We were running almost 40 2 years ago. So it's -- lots of things have changed.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Good color. And then, secondly for me, just correct me if I'm wrong here, but on the long-term strategy, it seems like you guys have shifted somewhat to talk more about staying within cash flow and growth within cash flow. And I'm curious her
componenttext: Okay. Great. Good color. And then, secondly for me, just correct me if I'm wrong here, but on the long-term strategy, it seems like you guys have shifted somewhat to talk more about staying within cash flow and growth within cash flow. And I'm curious here, years past, you've had no problem outspending. And I'm curious what would get you to kind of go back to that mindset potentially look to outspend and push growth more?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would challenge you a little bit on the -- we have no problem outspending cash flow. Because I think that was a one-time moonshot kind of project where we saw our balance sheet was delevering naturally, acquisitions looked expensive and we announced tha
componenttext: I would challenge you a little bit on the -- we have no problem outspending cash flow. Because I think that was a one-time moonshot kind of project where we saw our balance sheet was delevering naturally, acquisitions looked expensive and we announced that 2-by-3 plan where we could double production within 3 years. That was not kind of our normal way we operate, but those were the conditions at the time. And we had great success in that program. We were well on our way to achieving all those goals. Today, it just seems like in the kind of time we find ourselves in with the volatility, having a strong balance sheet, being able to demonstrate capital discipline and improving capital efficiency is the way you set yourself apart from the rest of the field. And that's what we're focused on and we think we can show really dramatic results staying within cash flow. And I think we can show growth that's going to be very well received.

componenttext: Yes. I would just add that the Permian's a big place and it wasn't that long ago that our biggest concern about the Permian was just takeaway capacity. We think if you're going to be -- have concentrated assets, the Permian's the place you want them concentrated.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.I would now to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms.
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Megan Hays. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our third quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website.
Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectations this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. Forward-looking statements and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in the earnings release and corporate presentation and can be found at Concho's website.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it's a late night everybody on the call.Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, turns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has drive
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it's a late night everybody on the call.
Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, turns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has driven exceptional performance, as reflected by our operational financial results for the third quarter. The quarter also demonstrated that we don't just talk about capital discipline, we actually [ph] employ it. Cash flow exceeded capital spending for the fifth consecutive quarter, and excluding acquisitions, we're on track to underspend our cash flow by over $100 million for full year '16.
Production for the third quarter was very strong and exceeded the high end of our guidance. We're building a great deal of momentum as we head toward the end of the year, and are increasing our 2016 growth outlook to 5% from the previous range of 1% to 3%. Importantly, we expect to land our capital budget within our range at $1.3 billion, again, all of which will be funded comfortably within cash flow.
Looking ahead to 2017 and beyond, we expect to deliver peer leading growth. We're targeting 20% annualized growth through 2019 within cash flow at the current commodity price outlook. Our asset base, financial discipline and operational excellence fuel our confidence on what we believe is a truly differentiated long-term outlook. Jack will outline our plans for 2017 and the 3-year outlook in more detail, but first, I want to give you some of the highlights across our assets.
As we improve our drilling and completion technology, our capital efficiency continues to get better. Each of our operating areas illustrates this. The entire portfolio is performing extremely well and contributing to accelerated growth. In both the Northern and Southern Delaware Basin, our team delivered record 30-day production rates, and we achieved record average laterally across all assets. The resource potential in the Northern Delaware Basin is abundant, and with more than 350,000 gross acres, we have significant leverage to the stacked resource. Since 2015, we've completed more than 225 horizontal wells, targeting 9 different zones. Our activity over the past 2 years represents only 1/3 of the horizontal wells we've drilled in the Northern Delaware since 2011.
Our top priority today is optimizing well spacing, lateral placement, lateral length and completion design. This focus is improving recoveries and returns. The Avalon Shale is an excellent example. The 4 well-development pad in the Red Hills area, highlighted on Slide 10 of the earnings deck, continues to outpace expectations and supports tighter well spacing, as well as our completion technique. Also, on Slide 10, we highlight the Wolfcamp zone in Red Hills. I'll describe the Wolfcamp as the next big play for Concho, and we recently completed 2 wells targeting the Upper Wolfcamp sands. These 2 wells came online at an average 30-day peak rate of 2,000 barrels of oil per day. The results from the Avalon and Wolfcamp illustrates both the quality of our acreage position and the technical expertise of our team.
In the Southern Delaware basin, we continued to delineate the Third Bone Spring Sand play, bringing 2 strong wells online during the quarter. For 2017, we plan to optimize the development of the third Bone Spring and the Wolfcamp A. At the time of our last call, we were completing an 8-well stacked test in the Midland Basin. The Windham this, which is referred to on Slide 13, includes 4 wells targeting the Lower Spraberry and 4 wells targeting the Wolfcamp B. These wells were drilled with long laterals, spaced at approximately 660 feet between wells in the same zone, and represents some of the best results we've achieved in the play. In the first 30 days, these wells produced a cumulative 260,000 barrels of oil equivalent, of which 85% was oil. And for the past 10 days, they've produced at an average daily rate of more than 11,000 BOEs per day, also made up of 85% oil.
Additionally, our drilling team is constantly working to drill wells faster and longer by using the latest technology. They recently set the record by drilling a 2-mile Lower Spraberry well from spud to TD in less than 12 days.
And over on the Mexico shale, we're targeting longer laterals while maintaining productivity per 1,000 feet of lateral and cost around $2.5 million per well. Investing in high quality assets in the Permian is key to our strategy. During the third quarter, we announced acquisition of 40,000 core net acres in the Midland Basin. The acquisition closed in October, and we are running one rig on these assets today with plans to add a second rig in '17. This transaction is a great example of the high bar we set for acquisitions. It's value accretive, enhances our drilling inventory, and we believe our drilling machine can make it even better.
We also find considerable value in owning large blocky positions. This allows us to capture the growth and economic advantages scale. While we continue to see a great deal of consolidation opportunities in the basin, we remain committed to active portfolio management. This includes a disciplined strategy of pursuing the right acquisitions to build for the future and selling projects that have a hard time competing for capital within our portfolio.
It's hard to imagine that it's been nearly 2 years since Black Thursday OPEC meeting that sent oil prices lower. Our industry's adapted well to lower our prices, but Concho's track record has been excellent. Year-to-date, we've increased our production growth target from down 5 at the start of the year to up 5. We've reduced our capital budget to $1.3 billion from the initial $1.4 billion. We've demonstrated capital discipline by spending within cash flow. We significantly reduced our annual cash cost by more than $100 million. We've reduced long-term debt by more than $1 billion. We've consolidated more than $2 billion of core assets. We've enhanced the quality of our inventory and we've delivered leading debt-adjusted production growth per share. It's amazing that this success overlaps with the longest-running oil price down cycle in more than 30 years. I'm excited about our momentum and even more pleased about the long-term outlook for our company.
Thanks for your attention this morning and now let me turn it over to Jack.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and teh dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's f
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and teh dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's financial strategy. First, we believe that in order to build a leading energy company that excels in any environment that starts directing capital to the best asset and constantly working to improve performance.
On the first quarter earnings call, we outlined the inflection point in capital efficiency that's occurring in 2016. Our transition to long laterals and multi-well pads, combined with improving well productivity through new completion design, is enhancing the quality of our inventory. This really drilling opportunities are powerful engine for multi year growth within cash flow.
Cost control is the second component of Concho's financial strategy. We continue to work our cash cost lower. We lowered guidance for lease operating expense to $6 per BOE from the prior range of $6.50 to $7. Additionally, during the third quarter, we redeemed $600 million of 7% senior notes, further strengthening the balance sheet and reducing cash interest burden, which leads me to the third component of our financial strategy. A strong simple balance sheet continues to serve Concho well and provides significant flexibility. One goal we had for Concho is to come out the cycle in a stronger financial position than when we started and we've done that. We have significantly reduced our absolute debt and are within our leverage comfortable level based on debt-to-EBITDA.
As we approach the budget season, we can find ourselves planning for the long-term in an uncertain price environment. Depending on commodity prices and resulting cash flow, we expect to invest between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion in 2017 and grow oil volumes by more than 20% year-over-year. Total company production is expected to be 17% to 20% over 2016's increasingly strong base.
We're 18 rigs today and plan to run 18 rigs on average next year. So the rigs are ready to deliver on our growth target. We will continue to capture efficiencies as we increase long lateral and multi-well pad development. The average lateral length of the program is expected to increase 20% as compared to '16. Additionally, we expect more than 70% of the program to utilize multi-well pads, up from approximately 50% in '16, and 15% 2 years ago. We've drilled over 1,000 horizontal wells in the Permian, providing us with a significant amount of data and discover. But this business still has an incredible amount of running room in terms of delineating zones, well spacing and overall drilling and completion optimization. We like to think of it is as a big science experiment. So in addition to advancing efficiencies across the plays in 2017, the drilling program will also help answer important questions about optimal development of this world-class resource.
We're excited about outlook for next year, but ultimately Concho's a growth company capable of raising the industry bar for delivering differentiated performance over the long term. And even in this commodity price environment, our long-term growth outlook is robust. Over the next 3 years, at current strip price, we expect to generate 20% annualized production growth within cash flow. With our leverage ratio further improving as it trends to 1x over this 3-year period. The plan is simple: There are no assumptions for a higher price outlook or greater efficiencies than where we stand today. Our combined efforts in 2016 to expand profitability and improved capital productivity enhance the impact of each dollar we redeploy in the drilling program. This is how we're to deliver differentiated growth within cash flow relative to the field.
Our consistent execution provides a strong foundation for creating value for shareholders over the long term, operational excellence, structural cost improvement, and a fortress balance sheet will continue to set Concho apart. And as we look to the balance of the year and beyond, we are more focused than ever on enhancing capital productivity and translating that into a sustainable capital efficient growth per share for our shareholders.
With that, we'll now open up the call for your questions.

And where else in the world is the oil production went to come online. So and we've seen that within our ACC project. I mean, what a great project in South Eastern Mexico. So I think we have ample takeaway capacity today. I think their takeaway capacity will keep up with production and we're not that concerned about a [indiscernible] event.

We can deploy, we have the infrastructure, the properties, the rigs running, we can deploy more capital if that's the right thing to do.

componenttext: Well, we have a strong balance sheet, we have a strong cash flow. Our our drilling program is going to provide really just growth. So I've highlighted the importance of having blocky acreage. So most of our property management is going to be focused on creating bigger blocks of acreage, either through trades or selling stuff and redeploying through acquiring other bolt-on properties. And so when you look at something to, say, well, acreage looks expensive, well, if you're buying and selling the same value but improving your blockiness that's on what you're paying is continuing to get ever-increasing quality of acreage, I think that's okay. And we've demonstrated our ability to buy stuff at a good price. So I think we'll continue that as well.

componenttext: I mean, there are mechanical limitations based on the depth and the type of pipe you're using and all those kinds of things, but industry's continuing to experiment with different configurations to get longer laterals. I think it's going to become much more standard to get out the 2.5 miles as we continue to push the boundaries based on how wells are configured today. We told you in past years that the main restriction was just our leases. And as we work on our property base of our leases, we've gotten bigger and got blockier positions now that allow us to drill longer. But I mentioned in my prepared remarks that we're really focused on lateral length, well placement of the zone and the completion style. And those are our priorities on the science experiment of solving for all the different zones. I think we're well up the learning curve and I think we're zeroing in on optimization on those areas.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
