componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Megan Hays. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our third quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website.
Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectations this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. Forward-looking statements and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in the earnings release and corporate presentation and can be found at Concho's website.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it's a late night everybody on the call. Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, turns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has driven
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it's a late night everybody on the call. Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, turns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has driven exceptional performance, as reflected by our operational financial results for the third quarter. The quarter also demonstrated that we don't just talk about capital discipline. We actually employ it. Cash flow exceeded capital spending for the fifth consecutive quarter, and excluding acquisitions, we're on track to underspend our cash flow by over $100 million for full year '16.
Production for the third quarter was very strong and exceeded the high end of our guidance. We're building a great deal of momentum as we head toward the end of the year, and are increasing our 2016 growth outlook to 5% from the previous range of 1% to 3%. Importantly, we expect to land our capital budget within our range at $1.3 billion, again, all of which will be funded comfortably within cash flow.
Looking ahead to 2017 and beyond, we expect to deliver peer leading growth. We're targeting 20% annualized growth through 2019 within cash flow at the current commodity price outlook. Our asset base, financial discipline and operational excellence fuel our confidence on what we believe is a truly differentiated long-term outlook. Jack will outline our plans for 2017 and the 3-year outlook in more detail, but first, I want to give you some of the highlights across our assets.
As we improve our drilling and completion technology, our capital efficiency continues to get better. Each of our operating areas illustrates this. The entire portfolio is performing extremely well and contributing to accelerated growth. In both the Northern and Southern Delaware Basin, our team delivered record 30-day production rates, and we achieved record average laterally across all assets. The resource potential in the Northern Delaware Basin is abundant, and with more than 350,000 gross acres, we have significant leverage to the stacked resource. Since 2015, we've completed more than 225 horizontal wells, targeting 9 different zones. Our activity over the past 2 years represents only 1/3 of the horizontal wells we've drilled in the Northern Delaware since 2011.
Our top priority today is optimizing well spacing, lateral placement, lateral length and completion design. This focus is improving recoveries and returns. The Avalon Shale is an excellent example. The 4 well-development pad in the Red Hills area, highlighted on Slide 10 of the earnings deck, continues to outpace expectations and supports tighter well spacing, as well as our completion technique. Also, on Slide 10, we highlight the Wolfcamp zone in Red Hills. I'll describe the Wolfcamp as the next big play for Concho, and we recently completed 2 wells, targeting the Upper Wolfcamp Sands. These 2 wells came online at an average 30-day peak rate of 2,000 barrels of oil per day. The results from the Avalon and Wolfcamp illustrates both the quality of our acreage position and the technical expertise of our team.
In the Southern Delaware basin, we continued to delineate the Third Bone Spring Sand play, bringing 2 strong wells online during the quarter. For 2017, we plan to optimize the development of the third Bone Spring and the Wolfcamp A. At the time of our last call, we were completing an 8-well stack test in the Midland Basin. The Windham test, which is referred to on Slide 13, includes 4 wells targeting the Lower Spraberry and 4 wells targeting the Wolfcamp B. These wells were drilled with long laterals, spaced at approximately 660 feet between wells in the same zone, and represents some of the best results that we've achieved in the play. In the first 30 days, these wells produced a cumulative 260,000 barrels of oil equivalent, of which 85% was oil. And for the past 10 days, they've produced at an average daily rate of more than 11,000 BOEs per day, also made up of 85% oil. Additionally, our drilling team is constantly working to drill wells faster and longer by using the latest technology. They recently set a record by drilling a 2-mile Lower Spraberry well from spud to TD in less than 12 days.
And over onto the Mexico shale, we're targeting longer laterals, while maintaining productivity per 1,000 feet of lateral, and cost around $2.5 million per well. Investing in high quality assets in the Permian is key to our strategy. During the third quarter, we announced the acquisition of 40,000 core net acres in the Midland Basin. The acquisition closed in October, and we're running one rig on these assets today with plans to add a second rig early in '17. This transaction is a great example of the high bar we've set for acquisitions. It's value accretive, enhances our drilling inventory, and we believe our drilling machine can make it even better.
We also find considerable value in owning large blocky positions. This allows us to capture the growth and economic advantage of scale. While we continue to see a great deal of consolidation opportunities in the basin, we remain committed to active portfolio management. This includes a disciplined strategy of pursuing the right acquisitions to build for the future and selling projects that have a hard time competing for capital within our portfolio.
It's hard to imagine that it's been nearly 2 years since Black Thursday OPEC meeting that sent oil prices lower. Our industry's adapted well to lower our prices, but Concho's track record has been excellent. Year-to-date, we've increased our production growth target from down 5 at the start of the year to up 5. We've reduced our capital budget to $1.3 billion from the initial $1.4 billion. We've demonstrated capital discipline by spending within cash flow. We significantly reduced our annual cash cost by more than $100 million. We've reduced long-term debt by more than $1 billion. We've consolidated more than $2 billion of core assets. We've enhanced the quality of our inventory and we've delivered leading debt-adjusted production growth per share. It's amazing that this success overlaps with the longest-running oil price down cycle in more than 30 years. I'm excited about our momentum and even more pleased about the long-term outlook for our company.
Thanks for your attention this morning and now let me turn it over to Jack.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and the dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's f
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and the dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's financial strategy. First, we believe that in order to build a leading energy company that excels in any environment that starts directing capital to the best assets and constantly working to improve performance.
On the first quarter earnings call, we outlined the inflection point in capital efficiency that's occurring in 2016. Our transition to long laterals and multi-well pads, combined with improving well productivity through new completion design, is enhancing the quality of our inventory. This really drilling opportunities are powerful engine for multi year growth within cash flow.
Cost control is the second component of Concho's financial strategy. We continue to work our cash cost lower. We lowered guidance for lease operating expense to $6 per BOE from the prior range of $6.50 to $7. Additionally, during the third quarter, we redeemed $600 million of 7% senior notes, further strengthening the balance sheet and reducing cash interest burden, which leads me to the third component of our financial strategy. A strong simple balance sheet continues to serve Concho well and provides significant flexibility. One goal we had for Concho is to come out the cycle in a stronger financial position than when we started and we've done that. We have significantly reduced our absolute debt, and are within our leverage comfort level based on debt-to-EBITDA.
As we approach budget season, we can find ourselves planning for the long-term in an uncertain price environment. Depending on commodity prices and resulting cash flow, we expect to invest between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion in 2017, and grow oil volumes by more than 20% year-over-year. Total company production is expected to be 17% to 20% over 2016's increasingly strong base.
We're at 18 rigs today, and plan to run 18 rigs on average next year. So the rigs are ready to deliver on our growth target. We will continue to capture efficiencies as we increase long lateral and multi-well pad development. The average lateral length of the program is expected to increase 20%, as compared to '16. Additionally, we expect more than 70% of the program to utilize multi well pads, up from approximately 50% in '16, and 15% 2 years ago. We've drilled over 1,000 horizontal wells in the Permian, providing us with a significant amount of data and discovery. But there's still an incredible amount of running room in terms of delineating zones, well spacing and overall drilling and completion optimization. We like to think of it as a big science experiment. So in addition to advancing efficiencies across the plays in 2017, the drilling program will also help answer important questions about optimal development of this world-class resource.
We're excited about the outlook for next year, but ultimately, Concho is a growth company, capable of raising the industry bar for delivering differentiated performance over the long term. And even in this commodity price environment, our long-term growth outlook is robust. Over the next 3 years, at current strip price, we expect to generate 20% annualized production growth within cash flow, with our leverage ratio further improving as it trends to 1x over this 3-year period. The plan is simple. There are no assumptions for a higher price outlook or greater efficiencies than where we stand today. Our combined efforts in 2016 to expand profitability and improve capital productivity enhance the impact of each dollar we redeploy in the drilling program. This is how we were to deliver differentiated growth within cash flow relative to the field.
Our consistent execution provides a strong foundation for creating value for shareholders over the long term. Operational excellence, structural cost improvement, and a fortressed balance sheet will continue to set Concho apart. And as we look to the balance of the year and beyond, we are more focused than ever on enhancing capital productivity and translating that into a sustainable capital efficient growth per share for our shareholders.
With that, we'll now open up the call for your questions.

And I guess, scope wise, in terms of acreage, that would be for sale out there, can you give us a sense of what you might be looking at?

componenttextpreview: Well, we've talked about always managing our portfolio. So we're always looking to add bolt-on acreage in these core areas and peel off step that's outside the core areas, and that's kind of ongoing.
componenttext: Well, we've talked about always managing our portfolio. So we're always looking to add bolt-on acreage in these core areas and peel off step that's outside the core areas, and that's kind of ongoing.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is there -- do you have sort of an immediate need to try to sell something now?
componenttext: Okay. Is there -- do you have sort of an immediate need to try to sell something now?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. I mean, it's just -- I think prudent asset management. And I think one thing you're going to see in our industry is more trading going on. I also mentioned the blocky acreage and the power of having large blocks of acreage. And so as you see compa
componenttext: No, no. I mean, it's just -- I think prudent asset management. And I think one thing you're going to see in our industry is more trading going on. I also mentioned the blocky acreage and the power of having large blocks of acreage. And so as you see companies manage their portfolio of assets, I think you can see more and more trading around within core areas just to get blockier acreage.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: Tim, how should we think about -- you guys mentioned the past alpha crude connector and the potential for some type of monetization, any update there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, this is Jack. No, I'd put it in the same category that Tim talked about before on managing our portfolio. That asset is a great asset for the company, and it is -- it has and will continue to achieve all the goals that we set out when we started tha
componenttext: Dave, this is Jack. No, I'd put it in the same category that Tim talked about before on managing our portfolio. That asset is a great asset for the company, and it is -- it has and will continue to achieve all the goals that we set out when we started that project of putting our barrels on pipe, increasing the market access and increasing netbacks. So we're real happy with that, and we view that as we do our other properties in terms of managing them over time.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then trying to fare where to go with my second one. Let me ask, if I start thinking about these longer laterals, is that able -- do you think that will be able to offset any -- what you guys anticipate service cost inflation? So I'm thinking abo
componenttext: Okay. And then trying to fare where to go with my second one. Let me ask, if I start thinking about these longer laterals, is that able -- do you think that will be able to offset any -- what you guys anticipate service cost inflation? So I'm thinking about overall well cost. And obviously, capital efficiency gets better, but trying to figure what that magnitude look like in '17, '18. How should -- how do you think about, I guess, Jack, would you guys model the plan as far as service cost expectation, well cost expectation, and the impact of the efficiencies?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We talked about the plan, the long-term plan being modeled under the current economic circumstances. And we thought that was the best marker to put out there to show what we could do today at today's efficiencies and today's cost. And we talked before abo
componenttext: We talked about the plan, the long-term plan being modeled under the current economic circumstances. And we thought that was the best marker to put out there to show what we could do today at today's efficiencies and today's cost. And we talked before about how we think that commodity prices will continue to be volatile. And we've also given a range of where we can -- what we can do while we spend within cash flow. So I do think that it leaves us room for increasing efficiencies as we continue to get better. And so we're not anticipating any capital cost increases, and we don't have any in that planned nor do we have any additional efficiencies. So I think those are upsides for us.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jeanine Wai with Citigroup.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jeanine Wai with Citigroup.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: So back to your prepared remarks, you mentioned that you're uncapped, underspent for the year. I think you've underspent cash flow on an operating cash flow, the CapEx basis by roughly 25% on average over the past 5 quarters. So with the improving well results in efficiencies, can you just talk about whether or not your 2017 plan could be conservative? And maybe another way to ask that is what kind of commodity downside testing can your current 2017 plan would stand?

componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, still in our hedges, and you look at the range of capital, the way to think about that is low- to mid-40s up to where the strip is, up to kind of 50-ish. So that's the way I would think about that.
componenttext: Sure. I mean, still in our hedges, and you look at the range of capital, the way to think about that is low- to mid-40s up to where the strip is, up to kind of 50-ish. So that's the way I would think about that.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So your current plan is intact into the low-40s?
componenttext: Okay. So your current plan is intact into the low-40s?

componenttextpreview: That's fair enough.
componenttext: That's fair enough.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question pertains to the long-term production outlook that you put out, which very helpful, so thank you for that. But as you look out to 2020 and '19 and all, do you see enough takeaway pipeline capacity within the Midland? Or excuse me, within
componenttext: My first question pertains to the long-term production outlook that you put out, which very helpful, so thank you for that. But as you look out to 2020 and '19 and all, do you see enough takeaway pipeline capacity within the Midland? Or excuse me, within the Permian Basin, to move all the oil out? And what are your thoughts on differentials? Could we actually see oil differentials start to wide again like we saw a few years ago, and given -- specially given the growth agendas of so many different E&Ps in the Permian Basin? So I'd like to get your thoughts on that.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my thoughts are that there are various scenarios and various consultants that will advise on how much the Permian is going to grow. But I guess from where we sit and what we see, that there's ample takeaway capacity out in the Permian, and there's
componenttext: I guess my thoughts are that there are various scenarios and various consultants that will advise on how much the Permian is going to grow. But I guess from where we sit and what we see, that there's ample takeaway capacity out in the Permian, and there's additional capacity on the way. So we don't really foresee a pinchpoint or a problem. And it also highlights the amount of investments that's going into infrastructure in the Permian, and what a great place to build infrastructure. And where else in the world is all these oil production that went to come online, so -- and we've seen that with our ACC project. I mean, what a great project in South Eastern Mexico. So I think we have ample takeaway capacity today. I think the takeaway capacity will keep up with production, and we're not that concerned about a Mid-Cush event.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then Tim, my follow-up pertains to service cost, and where do you see those right now? Are you seeing any service cost inflation? And as you look out over the next 12 months, do you anticipate starting to see some of it, and are there any p
componenttext: Excellent. And then Tim, my follow-up pertains to service cost, and where do you see those right now? Are you seeing any service cost inflation? And as you look out over the next 12 months, do you anticipate starting to see some of it, and are there any particular areas where it could get a little tight?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, especially, with commodity prices, where they are, we don't -- we're not feeling any pressure on the service side. I think I mentioned in my prepared remarks the power of scale, and I do think for companies like Concho, where we're running this many
componenttext: Well, especially, with commodity prices, where they are, we don't -- we're not feeling any pressure on the service side. I think I mentioned in my prepared remarks the power of scale, and I do think for companies like Concho, where we're running this many rigs, and we're running 8 frac spreads. We're running -- all of them are running 24 hours a day, there's efficiencies built into the system. On the service side, it appears like there's excess capacity. So I think we feel pretty good about how we're sitting right now.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Neal Dingmann with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Neal Dingmann with SunTrust.

componenttext: My first question, guys, I just couldn't help but notice on your 2017 guided plan for the rig allocation versus what you kind of currently have running. Should we read anything into, I guess, I'm looking specifically at the amount of rigs. You're going to be adding that Northern Delaware basin play, maybe just talk about what you've kind of laid out for '17 versus the current plan.

componenttext: Sure. Like -- somebody mentioned earlier, the working interest is modestly lower, but the activity is picking up. That's an area -- core to the company. We have drilled over 600 horizontal wells there. And so it's just -- it's in its pretty consistent capital spending as we've had in the past. The big -- the real positive improvement there is continuing to push out that lateral length and drill more wells on pads.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Jack, really, just my follow-up is still to stay with that Northern Delaware area. How different, I know you guys don't lay out type curves yet, but how different should we think about if there was type curves when you start to get a little bit
componenttext: And then, Jack, really, just my follow-up is still to stay with that Northern Delaware area. How different, I know you guys don't lay out type curves yet, but how different should we think about if there was type curves when you start to get a little bit further in the Central or Northern Eddy versus that state line area? I mean, we hear a lot of other peers talk more specifically about just how fantastic the State Line. We maybe don't get as many results starting to trend a little bit further north. I'm just wondering, when you look at that area, you've got, I guess, slides, what, 9 and 10 both laid out pretty well in that area. How much variability do you see there?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we like that area a lot. You can see the most recent results we've highlighted would get anybody excited. So we like the whole Northern Delaware and we like the optionality we have up there.
componenttext: Well, we like that area a lot. You can see the most recent results we've highlighted would get anybody excited. So we like the whole Northern Delaware and we like the optionality we have up there.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Drew Venker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Drew Venker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping on the 3-year plan if you could talk more about your spending appetite in, let's say, if price happen to be higher, you would generate significant free cash flow relative to the plan you laid today at the strip. Is there any target leverage y
componenttext: I was hoping on the 3-year plan if you could talk more about your spending appetite in, let's say, if price happen to be higher, you would generate significant free cash flow relative to the plan you laid today at the strip. Is there any target leverage you're hoping to get down to or is there any appetite at any point to pay a dividend or anything like that?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the answer to most of those questions is no. We're dedicated to running this business within cash flow. And so higher oil prices generate higher cash flow. We have the ability to ramp-up or slow down. We've tried to put out a range that we think i
componenttext: I think the answer to most of those questions is no. We're dedicated to running this business within cash flow. And so higher oil prices generate higher cash flow. We have the ability to ramp-up or slow down. We've tried to put out a range that we think is a reasonable range to think of over the next year. And then as we go forward, we're flexible. We've always thought that maintaining flexibility was important to our business. So we can slow it down or speed it up if conditions change, but I think we're really well prepared. We can deploy. We have the infrastructure, the properties, the rigs running. We can deploy more capital if that's the right thing to do.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess, Tim, as a follow-up to that, it sounds like the outspending cash flow is pretty much off the table for the foreseeable future then? Do I have that right?
componenttext: And I guess, Tim, as a follow-up to that, it sounds like the outspending cash flow is pretty much off the table for the foreseeable future then? Do I have that right?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's right. Now I would differentiate between reinvesting our cash flow in this property management that we've described that the buying and selling of properties and high-grading our asset base. So we're going to spend within cash flow. We're a
componenttext: I think that's right. Now I would differentiate between reinvesting our cash flow in this property management that we've described that the buying and selling of properties and high-grading our asset base. So we're going to spend within cash flow. We're also going to manage our property base. Those are the 2 fundamental core activities.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the results in the Upper Wolfcamp Sand that you highlighted looked really great. So just curious how much activity you can have there in 2017? And if you feel like you have sufficient mapping of the reservoir to run a high level of activity next
componenttext: Okay. And the results in the Upper Wolfcamp Sand that you highlighted looked really great. So just curious how much activity you can have there in 2017? And if you feel like you have sufficient mapping of the reservoir to run a high level of activity next year?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We'll come out with more detail on 2017 next time. But I would think about our spending mix relatively similar in the future as it's been recently.
componenttext: Yes. We'll come out with more detail on 2017 next time. But I would think about our spending mix relatively similar in the future as it's been recently.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious kind of, actually, on that Wolfcamp Sands. Can you talk about just how prospective you see that as across all your Northern Delaware acreage if you just limit it to Lea County or how far West do you see that potentially gaining perspective?
componenttext: Just curious kind of, actually, on that Wolfcamp Sands. Can you talk about just how prospective you see that as across all your Northern Delaware acreage if you just limit it to Lea County or how far West do you see that potentially gaining perspective?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do not think it's limited to Lea County. And like all new and emerging plays, we'll learn a lot more as we drill more wells, but it's -- we like it, and we're going to progress through it like we have all these other 9 zones in the Northern Delaware.
componenttext: We do not think it's limited to Lea County. And like all new and emerging plays, we'll learn a lot more as we drill more wells, but it's -- we like it, and we're going to progress through it like we have all these other 9 zones in the Northern Delaware.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And thinking about that Northern Delaware program, I mean, is there anything that requires you or do you have any substantial requirements in 2017 to continue drilling down in the lower Wolfcamp? Or will you be focused on higher oil
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And thinking about that Northern Delaware program, I mean, is there anything that requires you or do you have any substantial requirements in 2017 to continue drilling down in the lower Wolfcamp? Or will you be focused on higher oil cut areas or intervals, rather, there in the 2017 program?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have obligations that are -- that significantly impact our thinking on spending. So we're able to allocate the money across all 4 plays, really, based on rate of return.
componenttext: We don't have obligations that are -- that significantly impact our thinking on spending. So we're able to allocate the money across all 4 plays, really, based on rate of return.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then last, on my end, you've talked a good bit about the portfolio management thought process. I'm just curious how you think about, like you say, peeling off acreage parts of the portfolio? Just in the context of rapidly changing acreage
componenttext: Okay, great. And then last, on my end, you've talked a good bit about the portfolio management thought process. I'm just curious how you think about, like you say, peeling off acreage parts of the portfolio? Just in the context of rapidly changing acreage values in the Permian, how do you think about that from a long-term value preservation standpoint? And how you balance need for cash or desire for cash now versus potential value in the future?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a strong balance sheet. We have strong cash flow. Our drilling program is going to provide really good growth. So I've highlighted the importance of having blocky acreage. So most of our property management is going to be focused on creating
componenttext: Well, we have a strong balance sheet. We have strong cash flow. Our drilling program is going to provide really good growth. So I've highlighted the importance of having blocky acreage. So most of our property management is going to be focused on creating bigger blocks of acreage, either through trades or selling stuff and redeploying through acquiring other bolt-on properties. And so when you look at something and, say, well, acreage looks expensive, well, if you're buying and selling at the same value, but improving your blockiness, that seem on -- what you're paying, as long as you're continuing to get ever-increasing quality of acreage. I think that's okay, and we've demonstrated our ability to buy stuff at a good price. So I think we'll continue that as well.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Sullivan with Alembic Global Advisors.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: Apologize if you already hit this. I jumped around a little bit this morning. But it's in the '17 guidance, you talked about increasing the average lateral lengths across the portfolio for the '17 program to 8,300 feet from, I think, the plus 7,000. Is that part of the -- is that baked into the guidance? Or is that one of those uncaptured upsides you guys talked about in terms of the '17 numbers?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is baked in to our numbers.
componenttext: That is baked in to our numbers.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our question comes from the line of Jeff Robertson with Barclays.
componenttext: And our question comes from the line of Jeff Robertson with Barclays.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, can you talk about any limitations with respect to the lateral length and the size of stimulations that you all or what the industry is putting in the Permian Basin?
componenttext: Tim, can you talk about any limitations with respect to the lateral length and the size of stimulations that you all or what the industry is putting in the Permian Basin?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, there are mechanical limitations based on the depth and the type of pipe you're using and all those kinds of things, but industry is continuing to experiment with different configurations to get longer laterals. I think it's going to become much m
componenttext: I mean, there are mechanical limitations based on the depth and the type of pipe you're using and all those kinds of things, but industry is continuing to experiment with different configurations to get longer laterals. I think it's going to become much more standard to get out the 2.5 miles, as we continue to push the boundaries based on how wells are configured today. We told you in past years that the main restriction was just our leases. And as we worked on our property base of our leases, we've gotten bigger and we've got blockier positions now that allow us to drill longer. But I mentioned in my prepared remarks that we're really focused on lateral length, well placement in the zone and the completion style. And those are our priorities on the science experiment of solving for all the different zones. I think we're well up the learning curve, and I think we're zeroing in on optimization on those areas.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: Just curious, you talked about 20% increase in average lateral length in '17. Do you have a rough number for the amount of lateral feet you hope to drill in 2017 versus what you will have done in 2016?

componenttext: It's significantly more.

componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll follow-up with Megan with that.
componenttext: Maybe I'll follow-up with Megan with that.

componenttext: I think what we're looking at is almost a 50% increase year-over-year to north of the 1.5 million. Yes, net.

componenttext: You talked about optimized -- optimizing well spacing and development patterns in the Midland Basin in 2017. So I guess, just following the Wyndham pilot, what are the next concepts you want to test in that basin, both from a spacing and completion perspective?

componenttext: Plus or minus, that's where we are right now, but like in all the areas, we're not stagnant. We're going to adapt to what yields the best results.

componenttext: We're at about 30 today, and I think that's roughly where we think we'll end the year. But I do think you'll see the completions tick up in the last quarter.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext:
Well, thank you. It was a great quarter. I enjoyed talking to you about it. I'm sure that we'll follow up with you offline. But thanks for following Concho. We're pretty excited about the next 3 years, and we appreciate your interest in the company.
Thank you very much.

Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Megan Hays. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our third quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website.
Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectations this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. Forward-looking statements and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in the earnings release and corporate presentation and can be found at Concho's website.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it was a late night everybody on the call. Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, returns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has dr
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it was a late night everybody on the call. Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, returns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has driven exceptional performance, as reflected by our operational financial results for the third quarter. The quarter also demonstrated that we don't just talk about capital discipline. We actually employ it. Cash flow exceeded capital spending for the fifth consecutive quarter, and excluding acquisitions, we're on track to underspend our cash flow by over $100 million for full year '16.
Production for the third quarter was very strong and exceeded the high end of our guidance. We're building a great deal of momentum as we head toward the end of the year, and are increasing our 2016 growth outlook to 5% from the previous range of 1% to 3%. Importantly, we expect to land our capital budget within our range at $1.3 billion, again, all of which will be funded comfortably within cash flow.
Looking ahead to 2017 and beyond, we expect to deliver peer leading growth. We're targeting 20% annualized growth through 2019 within cash flow at the current commodity price outlook. Our asset base, financial discipline and operational excellence fuel our confidence of what we believe is a truly differentiated long-term outlook. Jack will outline our plans for 2017 and the 3-year outlook in more detail, but first, I want to give you some of the highlights across our assets.
As we improve our drilling and completion technology, our capital efficiency continues to get better. Each of our operating areas illustrates this. The entire portfolio is performing extremely well and contributing to accelerated growth. In both the Northern and Southern Delaware Basin, our team delivered record 30-day production rates, and we achieved record average lateral length across all assets. The resource potential in the Northern Delaware Basin is abundant, and with more than 350,000 gross acres, we have significant leverage to the stacked resource. Since 2015, we've completed more than 225 horizontal wells, targeting 9 different zones. Our activity over the past 2 years represents only 1/3 of the horizontal wells we've drilled in the Northern Delaware since 2011.
Our top priority today is optimizing well spacing, lateral placement, lateral length and completion design. This focus is improving recoveries and returns. The Avalon Shale is an excellent example. The 4 well-development pad in the Red Hills area, highlighted on Slide 10 of the earnings deck, continues to outpace expectations and supports tighter well spacing, as well as our completion technique. Also, on Slide 10, we highlight the Wolfcamp zone in Red Hills. I've described the Wolfcamp as the next big play for Concho, and we recently completed 2 wells, targeting the Upper Wolfcamp Sands. These 2 wells came online at an average 30-day peak rate of 2,000 barrels of oil per day. The results from the Avalon and Wolfcamp illustrate both the quality of our acreage position and the technical expertise of our team.
In the Southern Delaware basin, we continued to delineate the Third Bone Spring Sand play, bringing 2 strong wells online during the quarter. For 2017, we plan to optimize the development of the third Bone Spring and the Wolfcamp A. At the time of our last call, we were completing an 8-well stack test in the Midland Basin. The Windham test, which is referred to on Slide 13, includes 4 wells targeting the Lower Spraberry and 4 wells targeting the Wolfcamp B. These wells were drilled with long laterals, spaced at approximately 660 feet between wells in the same zone, and represents some of the best results that we've achieved in the play. In the first 30 days, these wells produced a cumulative 260,000 barrels of oil equivalent, of which 85% was oil. And for the past 10 days, they've produced at an average daily rate of more than 11,000 BOEs per day, also made up of 85% oil. Additionally, our drilling team is constantly working to drill wells faster and longer by using the latest technology. They recently set a record by drilling a 2-mile Lower Spraberry well from spud to TD in less than 12 days.
And over on the New Mexico Shelf, we're targeting longer laterals while maintaining productivity per 1,000 feet of lateral, and cost around $2.5 million per well. Investing in high quality assets in the Permian is key to our strategy. During the third quarter, we announced the acquisition of 40,000 core net acres in the Midland Basin. The acquisition closed in October, and we're running one rig on these assets today with plans to add a second rig early in '17. This transaction is a great example of the high bar we've set for acquisitions. It's value accretive, enhances our drilling inventory, and we believe our drilling machine can make it even better.
We also find considerable value in owning large blocky positions. This allows us to capture the growth and economic advantage of scale. While we continue to see a great deal of consolidation opportunities in the basin, we remain committed to active portfolio management. This includes a disciplined strategy of pursuing the right acquisitions to build for the future and selling projects that have a hard time competing for capital within our portfolio.
It's hard to imagine that it's been nearly 2 years since Black Thursday OPEC meeting that sent oil prices lower. Our industry's adapted well to lower our prices, but Concho's track record has been excellent. Year-to-date, we've increased our production growth target from down 5 at the start of the year to up 5. We've reduced our capital budget to $1.3 billion from the initial $1.4 billion. We've demonstrated capital discipline by spending within cash flow. We’ve significantly reduced our annual cash cost by more than $100 million. We've reduced long-term debt by more than $1 billion. We've consolidated more than $2 billion of core assets. We've enhanced the quality of our inventory and we've delivered leading debt-adjusted production growth per share. It's amazing that this success overlaps with the longest-running oil price down cycle in more than 30 years. I'm excited about our momentum and even more pleased about the long-term outlook for our company.
Thanks for your attention this morning, and now let me turn it over to Jack.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and the dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's f
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and the dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's financial strategy. First, we believe that in order to build a leading energy company that excels in any environment it starts with directing capital to the best assets and constantly working to improve performance.
On the first quarter earnings call, we outlined the inflection point in capital efficiency that's occurring in 2016. Our transition to long laterals and multi-well pads, combined with improving well productivity through new completion design, is enhancing the quality of our inventory. These drilling opportunities are a powerful engine for multiyear growth within cash flow.
Cost control is the second component of Concho's financial strategy. We continue to work our cash cost lower. We lowered guidance for lease operating expense to $6 per BOE from the prior range of $6.50 to $7. Additionally, during the third quarter, we redeemed $600 million of 7% senior notes, further strengthening the balance sheet and reducing cash interest burden, which leads me to the third component of our financial strategy. A strong simple balance sheet continues to serve Concho well and provides significant flexibility. One goal we had for Concho was to come out the cycle in a stronger financial position than when we started, and we've done that. We have significantly reduced our absolute debt, and are within our leverage comfort level based on debt-to-EBITDA.
As we approach budget season, we again find ourselves planning for the long term in an uncertain price environment. Depending on commodity prices and resulting cash flow, we expect to invest between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion in 2017, and grow oil volumes by more than 20% year-over-year. Total company production is expected to be 17% to 20% over 2016's increasingly strong base.
We're at 18 rigs today, and plan to run 18 rigs on average next year. So the rigs are ready to deliver on our growth target. We will continue to capture efficiencies as we increase long lateral and multi-well pad development. The average lateral length of the program is expected to increase 20% as compared to '16. Additionally, we expect more than 70% of the program to utilize multi well pads, up from approximately 50% in '16, and 15% 2 years ago. We've drilled over 1,000 horizontal wells in the Permian, providing us with a significant amount of data and discovery. But there's still an incredible amount of running room in terms of delineating zones, well spacing and overall drilling and completion optimization. We like to think of it as a big science experiment. So in addition to advancing efficiencies across the plays in 2017, the drilling program will also help answer important questions about optimal development of this world-class resource.
We're excited about the outlook for next year, but ultimately, Concho is a growth company, capable of raising the industry bar for delivering differentiated performance over the long term. And even in this commodity price environment, our long-term growth outlook is robust. Over the next 3 years, at current strip price, we expect to generate 20% annualized production growth within cash flow, with our leverage ratio further improving as it trends to 1x over this 3-year period. The plan is simple. There are no assumptions for a higher price outlook or greater efficiencies than where we stand today. Our combined efforts in 2016 to expand profitability and improve capital productivity enhance the impact of each dollar we redeploy in the drilling program. This is how we were able to deliver differentiated growth within cash flow relative to the field.
Our consistent execution provides a strong foundation for creating value for shareholders over the long term. Operational excellence, structural cost improvement, and a fortressed balance sheet will continue to set Concho apart. And as we look to the balance of the year and beyond, we are more focused than ever on enhancing capital productivity and translating that into a sustainable capital efficient growth per share for our shareholders.
With that, we'll now open up the call for your questions.

componenttext: My first question pertains to the long-term production outlook that you put out, which very helpful, so thank you for that. But as you look out to 2020 and '19 and all, do you see enough takeaway pipeline capacity within the Midland? Or excuse me, within the Permian Basin, to move all the oil out? And what are your thoughts on differentials? Could we actually see oil differentials start to widen again like we saw a few years ago, and given -- especially given the growth agendas of so many different E&Ps in the Permian Basin? So I'd like to get your thoughts on that.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my thoughts are that there are various scenarios and various consultants that will advise on how much the Permian is going to grow. But I guess from where we sit and what we see, that there's ample takeaway capacity out of the Permian, and there's
componenttext: I guess my thoughts are that there are various scenarios and various consultants that will advise on how much the Permian is going to grow. But I guess from where we sit and what we see, that there's ample takeaway capacity out of the Permian, and there's additional capacity on the way. So we don't really foresee a pinch point or a problem. And it also highlights the amount of investments that's going into infrastructure in the Permian, and what a great place to build infrastructure. And where else in the world is all these oil production that going to come online, so -- and we've seen that with our ACC project. I mean, what a great project in southeast New Mexico. So I think we have ample takeaway capacity today. I think the takeaway capacity will keep up with production, and we're not that concerned about a Mid-Cush event.

componenttext: Well, especially with commodity prices where they are, we don't -- we're not feeling any pressure on the service side. I think I mentioned in my prepared remarks the power of scale, and I do think for companies like Concho, where we're running this many rigs, and we're running 8 frac spreads. We're running -- all of them are running 24 hours a day, there's efficiencies built into the system. On the service side, it appears like there's excess capacity. So I think we feel pretty good about how we're sitting right now.

componenttext: And then, Jack, really, just my follow-up is still to stay with that Northern Delaware area. componenttext: I think the answer to most of those questions is no. We're dedicated to running this business within cash flow. And so higher oil prices generate higher cash flow. We've always thought that maintaining flexibility was important to our business. So we can slow it down or speed it up if conditions change, but I think we're really well prepared. We can deploy. We have the infrastructure, the properties, the rigs running. We can deploy more capital if that's the right thing to do.

componenttext: Well, we have a strong balance sheet. We have strong cash flow. Our drilling program is going to provide really good growth. So I've highlighted the importance of having blocky acreage. So most of our property management is going to be focused on creating bigger blocks of acreage, either through trades or selling stuff and redeploying through acquiring other bolt-on properties. And so when you look at something and, say, well, acreage looks expensive, well, if you're buying and selling at the same value, but improving your blockiness, that seem on -- what you're paying, as long as you're continuing to get ever-increasing quality of acreage, I think that's okay, and we've demonstrated our ability to buy stuff at a good price. So I think we'll continue that as well.

componenttext: I mean, there are mechanical limitations based on the depth and the type of pipe you're using and all those kinds of things, but industry is continuing to experiment with different configurations to get longer laterals. I think it's going to become much more standard to get out to 2.5 miles, as we continue to push the boundaries based on how wells are configured today. We told you in past years that the main restriction was just our leases. And as we worked on our property base, our leases, we've gotten bigger and we've got blockier positions now that allow us to drill longer. But I mentioned in my prepared remarks that we're really focused on lateral length, well placement in the zone and the completion style. And those are our priorities on the science experiment of solving for all the different zones. I think we're well up the learning curve, and I think we're zeroing in on optimization on those areas.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.I would now to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms.
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Concho Resources Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now to introduce your host for today's conference, Ms. Megan Hays. Ma'am, you may begin.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management t
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Welcome to Concho's third quarter 2016 earnings call. On the call with me today in Midland is Tim Leach, Chairman, President and CEO; and Jack Harper, Executive Vice President and CFO; and members of the Concho senior management team.
Our third quarter earnings release and corporate presentation are both available on our website.
Please note that we will make forward-looking statements based on current expectations this morning. Also, some of our comments may reference non-GAAP financial measures. Forward-looking statements and other disclaimers as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures are provided in the earnings release and corporate presentation and can be found at Concho's website.
Now I'll turn the call over to Tim.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it was a late night everybody on the call. Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, returns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has dr
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning. Thanks for joining. I'm sure it was a late night everybody on the call. Over the past year, we've emphasized the 4 philosophies of our strategy: Our people, assets, returns and balance sheet. Our commitment to this strategy has driven exceptional performance, as reflected by our operational financial results for the third quarter. The quarter also demonstrated that we don't just talk about capital discipline. We actually employ it. Cash flow exceeded capital spending for the fifth consecutive quarter, and excluding acquisitions, we're on track to underspend our cash flow by over $100 million for full year '16.
Production for the third quarter was very strong and exceeded the high end of our guidance. We're building a great deal of momentum as we head toward the end of the year, and are increasing our 2016 growth outlook to 5% from the previous range of 1% to 3%. Importantly, we expect to land our capital budget within our range at $1.3 billion, again, all of which will be funded comfortably within cash flow.
Looking ahead to 2017 and beyond, we expect to deliver peer leading growth. We're targeting 20% annualized growth through 2019 within cash flow at the current commodity price outlook. Our asset base, financial discipline and operational excellence fuel our confidence of what we believe is a truly differentiated long-term outlook. Jack will outline our plans for 2017 and the 3-year outlook in more detail, but first, I want to give you some of the highlights across our assets.
As we improve our drilling and completion technology, our capital efficiency continues to get better. Each of our operating areas illustrates this. The entire portfolio is performing extremely well and contributing to accelerated growth. In both the Northern and Southern Delaware Basin, our team delivered record 30-day production rates, and we achieved record average lateral length across all assets. The resource potential in the Northern Delaware Basin is abundant, and with more than 350,000 gross acres, we have significant leverage to the stacked resource. Since 2015, we've completed more than 225 horizontal wells, targeting 9 different zones. Our activity over the past 2 years represents only 1/3 of the horizontal wells we've drilled in the Northern Delaware since 2011.
Our top priority today is optimizing well spacing, lateral placement, lateral length and completion design. This focus is improving recoveries and returns. The Avalon Shale is an excellent example. The 4 well-development pad in the Red Hills area, highlighted on Slide 10 of the earnings deck, continues to outpace expectations and supports tighter well spacing, as well as our completion technique. Also, on Slide 10, we highlight the Wolfcamp zone in Red Hills. I've described the Wolfcamp as the next big play for Concho, and we recently completed 2 wells, targeting the Upper Wolfcamp Sands. These 2 wells came online at an average 30-day peak rate of 2,000 barrels of oil per day. The results from the Avalon and Wolfcamp illustrate both the quality of our acreage position and the technical expertise of our team.
In the Southern Delaware basin, we continued to delineate the Third Bone Spring Sand play, bringing 2 strong wells online during the quarter. For 2017, we plan to optimize the development of the third Bone Spring and the Wolfcamp A. At the time of our last call, we were completing an 8-well stack test in the Midland Basin. The Windham test, which is referred to on Slide 13, includes 4 wells targeting the Lower Spraberry and 4 wells targeting the Wolfcamp B. These wells were drilled with long laterals, spaced at approximately 660 feet between wells in the same zone, and represents some of the best results that we've achieved in the play. In the first 30 days, these wells produced a cumulative 260,000 barrels of oil equivalent, of which 85% was oil. And for the past 10 days, they've produced at an average daily rate of more than 11,000 BOEs per day, also made up of 85% oil. Additionally, our drilling team is constantly working to drill wells faster and longer by using the latest technology. They recently set a record by drilling a 2-mile Lower Spraberry well from spud to TD in less than 12 days.
And over on the New Mexico Shelf, we're targeting longer laterals while maintaining productivity per 1,000 feet of lateral, and cost around $2.5 million per well. Investing in high quality assets in the Permian is key to our strategy. During the third quarter, we announced the acquisition of 40,000 core net acres in the Midland Basin. The acquisition closed in October, and we're running one rig on these assets today with plans to add a second rig early in '17. This transaction is a great example of the high bar we've set for acquisitions. It's value accretive, enhances our drilling inventory, and we believe our drilling machine can make it even better.
We also find considerable value in owning large blocky positions. This allows us to capture the growth and economic advantage of scale. While we continue to see a great deal of consolidation opportunities in the basin, we remain committed to active portfolio management. This includes a disciplined strategy of pursuing the right acquisitions to build for the future and selling projects that have a hard time competing for capital within our portfolio.
It's hard to imagine that it's been nearly 2 years since Black Thursday OPEC meeting that sent oil prices lower. Our industry's adapted well to lower our prices, but Concho's track record has been excellent. Year-to-date, we've increased our production growth target from down 5 at the start of the year to up 5. We've reduced our capital budget to $1.3 billion from the initial $1.4 billion. We've demonstrated capital discipline by spending within cash flow. We’ve significantly reduced our annual cash cost by more than $100 million. We've reduced long-term debt by more than $1 billion. We've consolidated more than $2 billion of core assets. We've enhanced the quality of our inventory and we've delivered leading debt-adjusted production growth per share. It's amazing that this success overlaps with the longest-running oil price down cycle in more than 30 years. I'm excited about our momentum and even more pleased about the long-term outlook for our company.
Thanks for your attention this morning, and now let me turn it over to Jack.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and the dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's f
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim. All around it was an exceptional quarter that supports our focused strategy and the dedication of our team to operational excellence. Good capital allocation, cost control and a strong simple financial position are the 3 pillars of Concho's financial strategy. First, we believe that in order to build a leading energy company that excels in any environment it starts with directing capital to the best assets and constantly working to improve performance.
On the first quarter earnings call, we outlined the inflection point in capital efficiency that's occurring in 2016. Our transition to long laterals and multi-well pads, combined with improving well productivity through new completion design, is enhancing the quality of our inventory. These drilling opportunities are a powerful engine for multiyear growth within cash flow.
Cost control is the second component of Concho's financial strategy. We continue to work our cash cost lower. We lowered guidance for lease operating expense to $6 per BOE from the prior range of $6.50 to $7. Additionally, during the third quarter, we redeemed $600 million of 7% senior notes, further strengthening the balance sheet and reducing cash interest burden, which leads me to the third component of our financial strategy. A strong simple balance sheet continues to serve Concho well and provides significant flexibility. One goal we had for Concho was to come out the cycle in a stronger financial position than when we started, and we've done that. We have significantly reduced our absolute debt, and are within our leverage comfort level based on debt-to-EBITDA.
As we approach budget season, we again find ourselves planning for the long term in an uncertain price environment. Depending on commodity prices and resulting cash flow, we expect to invest between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion in 2017, and grow oil volumes by more than 20% year-over-year. Total company production is expected to be 17% to 20% over 2016's increasingly strong base.
We're at 18 rigs today, and plan to run 18 rigs on average next year. So the rigs are ready to deliver on our growth target. We will continue to capture efficiencies as we increase long lateral and multi-well pad development. The average lateral length of the program is expected to increase 20% as compared to '16. Additionally, we expect more than 70% of the program to utilize multi well pads, up from approximately 50% in '16, and 15% 2 years ago. We've drilled over 1,000 horizontal wells in the Permian, providing us with a significant amount of data and discovery. But there's still an incredible amount of running room in terms of delineating zones, well spacing and overall drilling and completion optimization. We like to think of it as a big science experiment. So in addition to advancing efficiencies across the plays in 2017, the drilling program will also help answer important questions about optimal development of this world-class resource.
We're excited about the outlook for next year, but ultimately, Concho is a growth company, capable of raising the industry bar for delivering differentiated performance over the long term. And even in this commodity price environment, our long-term growth outlook is robust. Over the next 3 years, at current strip price, we expect to generate 20% annualized production growth within cash flow, with our leverage ratio further improving as it trends to 1x over this 3-year period. The plan is simple. There are no assumptions for a higher price outlook or greater efficiencies than where we stand today. Our combined efforts in 2016 to expand profitability and improve capital productivity enhance the impact of each dollar we redeploy in the drilling program. This is how we were able to deliver differentiated growth within cash flow relative to the field.
Our consistent execution provides a strong foundation for creating value for shareholders over the long term. Operational excellence, structural cost improvement, and a fortressed balance sheet will continue to set Concho apart. And as we look to the balance of the year and beyond, we are more focused than ever on enhancing capital productivity and translating that into a sustainable capital efficient growth per share for our shareholders.
With that, we'll now open up the call for your questions.

componenttextpreview: Well, it's all part of a big science experiment that we talked about in the script. And it, I mean, it excites us, and emboldens our thinking about what we've got laid out. And the Midland Basin is going to be a big part, along with the Delaware Basin of
componenttext: Well, it's all part of a big science experiment that we talked about in the script. And it, I mean, it excites us, and emboldens our thinking about what we've got laid out. And the Midland Basin is going to be a big part, along with the Delaware Basin of that growth.

Does that also mean that, basically, that if you have a 20% increase in lateral length in '17 that you don't have further increases in lateral lengths in '18 and '19?

componenttext: Well, we've talked about always managing our portfolio. So we're always looking to add bolt-on acreage in these core areas and peel off stuff that's outside the core areas, and that's kind of ongoing.

componenttext: No, no. I mean, it's just -- I think prudent asset management. And I think one thing you're going to see in our industry is more trading going on. I also mentioned the blocky acreage and the power of having large blocks of acreage. And so as you see companies manage their portfolio of assets, I think you can see more and more trading around within core areas just to get blockier acreage.

componenttext: Dave, this is Jack. No, I'd put it in the same category that Tim talked about before on managing our portfolio. That asset is a great asset for the company, and it is -- it has and will continue to achieve all the goals that we set out when we started that project of putting our barrels on pipe, increasing the market access and increasing netbacks. So we're real happy with that, and we view that as we do our other properties in terms of managing them over time.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then trying to figure out where to go with my second one. Let me ask, if I start thinking about these longer laterals, is that able -- do you think that will be able to offset any -- what you guys anticipate service cost inflation? So I'm thinki
componenttext: Okay. And then trying to figure out where to go with my second one. Let me ask, if I start thinking about these longer laterals, is that able -- do you think that will be able to offset any -- what you guys anticipate service cost inflation? So I'm thinking about overall well cost. And obviously, capital efficiency gets better, but trying to figure what that magnitude look like in '17, '18. How should -- how do you think about, I guess, Jack, what you guys model the plan as far as service cost expectation, well cost expectation, and the impact of the efficiencies?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We talked about the plan, the long-term plan being modeled under the current economic circumstances. And we thought that was the best marker to put out there to show what we could do today at today's efficiencies and today's cost. And we talked before abo
componenttext: We talked about the plan, the long-term plan being modeled under the current economic circumstances. And we thought that was the best marker to put out there to show what we could do today at today's efficiencies and today's cost. And we talked before about how we think that commodity prices will continue to be volatile. And we've also given a range of where we can -- what we can do while we spend within cash flow. So I do think that it leaves us room for increasing efficiencies as we continue to get better. And so we're not anticipating any capital cost increases, and we don't have any in that planned nor do we have any additional efficiencies. So I think those are upsides for us.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: So back to your prepared remarks, you mentioned that you're uncapped, underspent for the year. I think you've underspent cash flow on an operating cash flow, to D&C CapEx basis by roughly 25% on average over the past 5 quarters. componenttext: Sure. I mean, still in our hedges, and you look at the range of capital, the way to think about that is low- to mid-40s up to where the strip is, up to kind of 50-ish. So that's the way I would think about that.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay. So your current plan is intact into the low-40s?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Pearce Hammond with Simmons & Company.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question pertains to the long-term production outlook that you put out, which very helpful, so thank you for that. But as you look out to 2020 and '19 and all, do you see enough takeaway pipeline capacity within the Midland? Or excuse me, within
componenttext: My first question pertains to the long-term production outlook that you put out, which very helpful, so thank you for that. But as you look out to 2020 and '19 and all, do you see enough takeaway pipeline capacity within the Midland? Or excuse me, within the Permian Basin, to move all the oil out? And what are your thoughts on differentials? Could we actually see oil differentials start to widen again like we saw a few years ago, and given -- especially given the growth agendas of so many different E&Ps in the Permian Basin? So I'd like to get your thoughts on that.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my thoughts are that there are various scenarios and various consultants that will advise on how much the Permian is going to grow. But I guess from where we sit and what we see, that there's ample takeaway capacity out of the Permian, and there's
componenttext: I guess my thoughts are that there are various scenarios and various consultants that will advise on how much the Permian is going to grow. But I guess from where we sit and what we see, that there's ample takeaway capacity out of the Permian, and there's additional capacity on the way. So we don't really foresee a pinch point or a problem. And it also highlights the amount of investments that's going into infrastructure in the Permian, and what a great place to build infrastructure. And where else in the world is all these oil production that going to come online, so -- and we've seen that with our ACC project. I mean, what a great project in southeast New Mexico. So I think we have ample takeaway capacity today. I think the takeaway capacity will keep up with production, and we're not that concerned about a Mid-Cush event.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then Tim, my follow-up pertains to service cost, and where do you see those right now? Are you seeing any service cost inflation? And as you look out over the next 12 months, do you anticipate starting to see some of it, and are there any p
componenttext: Excellent. And then Tim, my follow-up pertains to service cost, and where do you see those right now? Are you seeing any service cost inflation? And as you look out over the next 12 months, do you anticipate starting to see some of it, and are there any particular areas where it could get a little tight?

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, especially with commodity prices where they are, we don't -- we're not feeling any pressure on the service side. I think I mentioned in my prepared remarks the power of scale, and I do think for companies like Concho, where we're running this many r
componenttext: Well, especially with commodity prices where they are, we don't -- we're not feeling any pressure on the service side. I think I mentioned in my prepared remarks the power of scale, and I do think for companies like Concho, where we're running this many rigs, and we're running 8 frac spreads. We're running -- all of them are running 24 hours a day, there's efficiencies built into the system. On the service side, it appears like there's excess capacity. So I think we feel pretty good about how we're sitting right now.

headline: Concho Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2016

componenttext: My first question, guys, I just couldn't help but notice on your 2017 guided plan for the rig allocation versus what you kind of currently have running. Should we read anything into, I guess, I'm looking specifically at the amount of rigs you're going to be adding that Northern Delaware basin play, maybe just talk about what you've kind of laid out for '17 versus the current plan.
